results.description: JOBE Watson’s rumoured new girlfriend is set to follow the Essendon star back down under after announcing she’s heading to Melbourne in two months on social media.
results.subscriptionSummary: JOBE Watson’s rumoured new girlfriend is set to follow the Essendon star back down under after announcing she’s heading to Melbourne in two months on social media.

results.body:
Virginia Slaghekke posted on Instagram: “Last day in NYC with this one, off to Melbourne in two months. Accepted into the Australian Exchange program”. 

Watson was first seen with Ms Slaghekke at his sister Billie’s Bali wedding earlier this month.

READ MORE: ESSENDON STAR JOBE WATSON CELEBRATES HIS SISTER’S WEDDING WITH NEW YORK MODEL ON HIS ARM

The returning Bomber was pictured with Ms Slaghekke in a series of images from the wedding

Ms Slaghekke posted pictures of the pair together on Instagram on October, 9, describing the wedding as the “best night ever”.

It is unclear how the pair met, but Watson spent time in New York during his 12-month ban as part of the ­Essendon supplements saga.

Ms Slaghekke is a model from Manhattan and medical student.

results.title: Kitschy films of life in the 60s
results.subtitle: These films showed the world how 1960s Melbourne, Geelong worked and played
results.description: WAS Australia an idyllic workers’ paradise in the 1960s?
results.subscriptionSummary: WAS Australia an idyllic workers’ paradise in the 1960s? That’s the image the federal government projected when it produced a series of films about life in Australian cities.

thumbnailImage.title: Kitschy films of life in the 60s
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 182d6710-9be2-11e6-a6cc-8bf57620ea71
thumbnailImage.description: Kitschy films of life in the 60s

results.seoHeadline: Melbourne lifestyle, Geelong lifestyle in the 1960s shown in hilarious films
results.body:
That’s the image the federal government projected when it produced a series of films about life in Australian cities.

Twelve such films, now held by the National Film and Sound Archive, were made between 1964 and 1966, including  and , to encourage migrants to settle here.

Both present some long lost images of Melbourne and Geelong at work and play and capture life in the Menzies era, but how accurate is that picture, and does it really matter?

The short film loosely follows a young couple.

The man leaves his mother’s brick veneer house in the suburbs in his gleaming Holden and picks up his girlfriend at then new Housing Commission flats.

He drops her at work at a city department store and commutes to the Holden factory in Port

Melbourne.

The film features glimpses of footy at the MCG, well kept suburban streets, the engine line at Holden. workers at Station Pier, bustling city streets, commerce at city shops and the Queen Victoria Market and modern and Victorian era architecture in what was still a very low-rise Melbourne CBD.

Later, the couple meets a priest to discuss marriage, hits a swinging discothèque and strolls through clean, neon-lined city streets.

The Geelong film focuses on a family of five in the city’s industrial northern suburbs.

We see a primary and secondary school, the Corio bookmobile and the City of Geelong library, a pastiche of Geelong street scenes, children playing in the water at Eastern Beach and workers toiling away at Geelong Cement, Ford, Corio Quay, a meatworks, the Shell Refinery and various factories devoted to producing wool yarn and weaving yarns.

The Geelong mum is seen preparing a roast dinner in a modern kitchen, served as Dad arrives home in the family Holden.

At the weekend, they head to a surf beach for a picnic and a swim.

Christian religion features strongly in both films but especially in the Geelong film, which features scenes of several churches.

NFSA production co-ordinator Richard Carter says there is not a lot of official information about the films, but that they were used to attract British and European migrants.

The films are not narrated, relying on natural audio to help convey realism and allow live presenters to speak in the language of the audience to convey information about Australia.

But Mr Carter said the films do not refer to the Vietnam War or the social and political upheavals of those days, and no indigenous people featured in them.

“They are a propaganda film and in some ways aren’t too dissimilar to films that came out of Korea or China or Russia,” Mr Carter said.

“They are all a very middle class, white, prosperous people that are portrayed. It’s always

very family oriented.

“The families that are in them aren’t necessarily real families. Because people have now seen

them on YouTube … I know that in the Geelong film some of the kids have said, ‘That wasn’t

my real family. I was chosen as the son and someone else was chosen as the daughter and

they mixed up the parents’.”

But for many, the films strike a nostalgic chord.

“We get a lot of people saying, ‘That was my life growing up in the 1960s’. So they are a great time capsule,” Mr Carter said.

“Even though they were highly constructed, the images that they have captured are now a fantastic record of parts of life in Australia at that time.”

The 12  films have proven popular on the NFSA’s YouTube channel.

The Sydney film alone has attracted more than half a million hits.

“They get thousands of hits a day from all over the world, but particularly Australia, and they elicit a lot of nostalgia for people who would have been growing up at that time, in the ‘50s and ‘60s.”

Film-makers have used them to illustrate Menzies-era Australia including the recent ABC documentary series , Mr Carter said.

jamie.duncan@news.com.au
results.standFirst: THESE sun-drenched 1960s films gave migrants a glimpse of what life was like in Melbourne and Geelong. But was it really how we lived?
bulletList: Honest Autocorrect: Melbourne edition
Things Melburnians never say
Massacre in the Botanic Gardens
A history of the Melbourne tram

results.title: Cats won’t rule out Gazza bid
results.subtitle: Geelong open to luring champ Gary Ablett back in coming trade periods
results.description: GEELONG says it won’t rule out another tilt at favourite son Gary Ablett, aware its path to secure him might be smoothed by the end of next season.
results.subscriptionSummary: GEELONG was surprised when it learned favourite son Gary Ablett wanted a trade home. But now they know he’s keen, they won’t be ruling out trying to woo him back.

thumbnailImage.title: Cats won’t rule out Gazza bid
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 62782442-9c0d-11e6-a6cc-8bf57620ea71
thumbnailImage.description: Cats won’t rule out Gazza bid
thumbnailImage.imageName: AFL Rd 14 - Hawthorn v Gold Coast 543112002

results.seoHeadline: Gary Ablett trade shock:
results.body:
The Cats on Wednesday confirmed to the Herald Sun Ablett had been keen to return to the club despite his captaincy of the Gold Coast.

That prospect was quickly shut down by the Suns, who conceded he had made the request despite president Tony Cochrane labelling the story a “massive beat-up”.

Geelong chief executive Brian Cook said the Cats could never rule out another tilt at Ablett given his cherished status at Geelong.

Ablett’s main impediment in moving was the $2 million owed to him in 2017-18, but leaving with a single year left would be much easier.

Cook revealed it was Ablett who had come to the Cats to raise the prospect of a move home, rather than Geelong pushing him to leave the Suns.

But even with Ablett turning 33 next May, the Cats can never totally rule out luring him home.

“Who knows? I don’t think you can plan for these things,” Cook said.

“It came a bit out of the blue for us. We understand why the Gold Coast closed it down quickly. It all depends on what Gaz wants to do. There are all sorts of options.

“(The approach) was more from Gary’s part. We reacted and reacted positively. Why wouldn’t you?”

Gold Coast could never agree to Ablett leaving given they were already reeling from the loss of stars Jaeger O’Meara and Dion Prestia.

But in 12 months Ablett might agree to a pay cut on his $1 million-per-year deal to return home and Gold Coast might be in a better position to let him leave.

“Then again he might have the best season of all time and really want to stick around for a premiership charge. There are a lot of days in between,’’ Cook said.

Gold Coast has confirmed Ablett’s approach to them but said he quickly realised why he needed to see out his deal.

Head of football Marcus Ashcroft said Ablett’s determination to lure players north during the trade period showed how much he cares.

“The club regularly has private conversations with players and their managers,” he said. 

“Our discussions with Gary were no different. But following recent media reports, Gary and the club have agreed it’s in everyone’s best interests to be as transparent as possible in regards to his end of year meeting.

“At the end of the season, and well before the exchange period, Gary asked a question relating to the possibility of him returning to Geelong. The club’s response was an emphatic no. An answer Gary both accepted and understood.

“Gary is absolutely committed to the Gold Coast Suns. This is best exemplified by his active role in recruiting mature players to our club during the recent exchange period.”
results.standFirst: GEELONG was surprised when it learned favourite son Gary Ablett wanted a trade home. But now they know he’s keen, they’re not ruling out trying to woo him back.

results.title: Rinehart, Chinese bid higher for S. Kidman land
results.subtitle: Gina Rinehart, Chinese group increase bid for S. Kidman pastoral empire to $386.5 million
results.description: GINA Rinehart and her Chinese partners have upped the ante in the fight to buy the S. Kidman & Co pastoral empire, submitting a revised bid late on Thursday that betters an all-Australian offer — by just $500,000.

thumbnailImage.title: Rinehart, Chinese bid higher for S. Kidman land
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 1d0e215c-9c0f-11e6-a6cc-8bf57620ea71
thumbnailImage.description: Rinehart, Chinese bid higher for S. Kidman land
thumbnailImage.imageName: Parkerville Children and Youth Care Lunch Crown Perth

categories.value: /taxonomy/iptc.org/economy, business and finance/company information/merger, acquisition and takeover/

results.body:
The $386.5 million bid by Australian Outback Beef — a joint venture between Mrs Rinehart’s Hancock Prospecting and Chinese real estate company Shanghai CRED — has been unanimously recommended to shareholders by the Kidman board “in the absence of a superior proposal”.

However, a spokesman for rival bidder BBHO — made up of the wealthy Brinkworth, Buntine, Harris and Oldfield families — told The Advertiser last night that the consortium remained “strongly committed” to its bid and that a higher offer was now being considered. 

Australian Outback Beef, 67 per cent controlled owned by Mrs Rinehart’s Hancock Prospecting, initially bid $365 million before being topped by BBHO. Its latest move again omits the politically sensitive Anna Creek station. 

One sticking point for Australian Outback Beef has been that, unlike BBHO, its bid must receive approval from Australia’s Foreign Investment Review Board and the Chinese government. However, Mrs Rinehart said on Thursday her company would go it alone if the joint venture was knocked back by either party. 

“I stand behind the bid and should FIRB or People’s Republic of China approvals not be achieved, then Hancock will proceed with the acquisition on a 100 per cent basis,” Mrs Rinehart said in a statement. 

“I hope this provides shareholders with significant comfort and that when they consider the offer, they can do so in the knowledge that there is no FIRB or PRC execution risk, and further that we have the money to invest to properly maintain the stations and their hardworking staff.” 

Mrs Rinehart said Australian Outback Beef has the capacity and ability to access additional markets without breaking up the core business. 

“This will result in valuable jobs being retained in Adelaide and also, importantly, create more jobs in rural communities where they are so desperately needed,” she said. 

The BBHO group would likely break up the properties between the families but keep them all under the Kidman brand. If BBHO was successful, it would more than treble the size of the herd currently marketed under the Kidman name to in excess of 500,000 cattle.

Mrs Rinehart said Kidman directors had carefully considered her group’s increased offer and had unanimously recommended that Kidman shareholders accept the offer “in the absence of a superior proposal”. 

Kidman chair John Crosby said the board welcomed the new offer and acknowledged the strong credentials of the company led by Mrs Rinehart.

“Under the Hancock JV offer, the core Kidman business will remain intact and the Kidman staff and legacy will be looked after,” he said.

Kidman holds approximately 1.3 per cent of Australia’s total land area, with its holdings spanning more than 100,000sq km across Queensland, SA, NT and WA.

As preferred bidder, if Kidman was to back out of the Rinehart deal, it would trigger a $3.8 million “break fee” payment.

Morrison happy with Australian bid for Kidman
results.standFirst: GINA Rinehart and her Chinese partners have upped the ante in the fight to buy the S. Kidman & Co pastoral empire, submitting a revised bid that betters an all-Australian offer — by just $500,000.

results.title: ’Cowboys’ will rebuild smashed pub
results.subtitle: State moves fast to stop Corkman pub redevelopers from profiting
results.description: “COWBOY” developers who illegally knocked down Corkman’s Pub in Carlton have apologised and vowed to rebuild.
results.subscriptionSummary: THE State Government says it has moved swiftly to prevent cowboy developers who knocked down a historic Carlton pub from profiting from the move.

thumbnailImage.title: ’Cowboys’ will rebuild smashed pub
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 10628546-9c88-11e6-8fd2-0406407fb4e6
thumbnailImage.description: ’Cowboys’ will rebuild smashed pub

results.seoHeadline: Carlton pub demolished: Developers won’t profit from Corkman fiasco
results.body:
But Planning Minister Richard Wynne said the State Government would still be taking the matter to the Victorian Civil and Administrative Council to officially order the developers to reinstate the pub.

Developers last week knocked down the 159-year-old hotel without proper planning permits, attracting immense criticism from the City of Melbourne and heritage experts.

In a letter sent to Mr Wynne, the developers said they were sorry for knocking down the pub, but also denied having any involvement in the suspicious fire just days before.

“In effect, (the letter) concedes that the developers have done the wrong thing and they’ve apologised for that,” he said.

“They indicate unequivocally that they will rebuild the hotel, and they expect to enter into a five to 10 year lease with an operator for a new hotel there.”

Mr Wynne said the Government was determined to hold the developers to account. 

“I think it’s important the developer has acknowledged that their behaviour was completely inappropriate, but we will continue the action to get an order from VCAT, and we would expect the developer, if we are successful, to abide by that VCAT decision, because heritage is important,” Mr Wynne said.

The State Government says it has moved swiftly to prevent the developers from profiting from the move.

As revealed in yesterday’s Herald Sun, the State Government and the City of Melbourne launched joint action to compel the site owners to rebuild the pub.

Mr Wynne has also imposed a two-year planning control on the site on the corner of Leicester and Pelham streets to maintain the size and scale of the original building.

BRICK BY BRICK: Pub demolishers may be ordered to rebuild

ENVIRONMENTAL THREAT: Dumped asbestos from Carlton pub site: EPA

EX-OWNERS DEVASTATED: Wrecking historic pub ‘disgraceful’ act

Owners Stefce Kutlesovski and Raman Shaqiri paid $4.76 million for the 160-year-old pub last August, with the vacant land initially estimated to be worth between $8 and 10 million. 

Mr Wynne said the restrictive overlay would prevent the owners profiting from any uplift in value of the site.

Lord Mayor Robert Doyle said any plans the developers had for the site were “no longer relevant.”

“If we are successful in VCAT, then the value of that site is very much determined by what you can put on that site, and we’re saying you’ve got to put the pub back,” Mr Doyle said.

“We don’t want people getting away with a wanton act of vandalism and then just washing their hands of it and taking a windfall profit.”

Opposition Planning Minister David Davis said Mr Wynne already had the power to act without the need for VCAT action.

“Minister Wynne could undertake a site specific amendment of the planning scheme that would ensure the developers cannot profit from their destructive misdeeds,” Mr Davis said. 

“We invite Minister Wynne to work with us on this goal so the Victorian Parliament can send a strong unequivocal message to developers that cheaters won’t prosper.”

Property Council of Australia spokeswoman Sally Capp said it did not support rushed Government action.

“The penalties in this case have clearly not acted as a deterrent, but a knee-jerk reaction without proper stakeholder consultation is not the solution,” she said.

andrew.jefferson@news.com.au

@AndyJeffo
results.standFirst: UPDATE: “COWBOY” developers who illegally knocked down Corkman’s Pub in Carlton have apologised and vowed to rebuild.

results.title: Dreamworld reopening cancelled
results.subtitle: Dreamworld’s grim reopening cancelled at last minute
results.description: DREAMWORLD has cancelled its plans for a controversial memorial day just three days after four people died in horrific circumstances at the park.

thumbnailImage.title: Dreamworld reopening cancelled
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 54ef5902-9c04-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: Dreamworld reopening cancelled

categories.value: /organisation/newscorpaustralia.com/International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement/otca/

keywords: International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement
results.seoHeadline: Dreamworld accident: Theme park no longer reopening on Friday
results.body:
Hours before it was due to throw open its doors to the public tomorrow morning, the theme park called off the reopening after talks with police.

“Dreamworld has been advised by Queensland Police Services (QPS) that we are unable to proceed with tomorrow’s memorial service as planned,” the park said in a statement.

“Obviously the integrity of the Coronial Investigation is of paramount importance and postponing the service will give QPS the time it needs to conduct this investigation.

“We will provide an update to the media on Monday with regard to the memorial service and re-opening of the Park.”

Neil Balnaves, outgoing chairman of Dreamworld owner Ardent Leisure, this morning announced at the firm’s AGM that the park would reopen following 24 hours of deliberation. He said it was “better that people get back to work”, and that plans were driven by the “utmost respect” for the families, adding: “We can’t return the four lives.”

But Queensland Assistant Commissioner Brian Codd this afternoon threw plans into doubt, saying he was concerned the reopening might cause security issues for the investigation at Thunder River Rapids, which is still a crime scene.

“We are not going to compromise the speed or thoroughness in order for us to vacate the area and acquire the evidence or facts we need,” he said “Let’s be aware of what the implications might be for our ongoing security of the crime scene.” 

Police investigating the tragedy have a crime scene warrant for the park that lasts until at least next Tuesday and can be extended if required.

A Queensland police media spokesman told news.com.au the force was “focusing on the investigation”.

“It’s going to take as long as it takes to finish processing the scene,” he said. “It could be a few days or a couple of weeks.”

Mr Codd said the investigation could yet shift to other parts of the theme park, although it was unlikely. “If there are perhaps other electrical or water or hydraulic sources, or switches from another part of the park that impact on that ride, they form part of the investigation,” he said. 

“We’re going through this meticulously, in great depth, the scope of this is quite considerable.” 

Dreamworld had planned to hold a private ceremony for staff and emergency services tomorrow morning and open smaller rides and animal attractions to the public to raise money for the Australian Red Cross. It was intended to precede an official reopening on Saturday, which will now also be postponed.

“After discussion with counsellors and a lot to do with the issues of people grieving, the decision was taken to turn tomorrow into a fundraising event to support the Red Cross and all the admission, the fees, will be donated to them,” Mr Balnaves said at Ardent’s AGM today.

“The advice we have from psychologists and a lot of the people working with the staff, it is better that people get back to work and basically get together with their comrades and talk and deal with this issue rather than they are concerned about their jobs, and they’re sitting at home in isolation, and we’re just adding to their issues. 

“At some point the park will open. And it’s driven by the utmost respect for the families and the deaths, and it will open again on Saturday to basically repair the damage with a lot of our people as well. We can’t return the four lives.

“The safety auditors have been through the park yesterday and provided a report late last night that all the audit of all the maintenance records has been done, it was carried out by a team yesterday. We will be doing our own internal report and the engineering department and the safety team will be going through that park with a fine-tooth comb in the next 24 hours.”

Mr Codd said any evidence would be protected if the park was reopened to the public. “Steps have been taken about securing the scene already to maintain the security of that area,” he added.

Many questioned whether it was too soon for workers and the public to return to Dreamworld, where Canberra mother Kate Goodchild, 32, her brother Luke Dorsett, 35, his partner Roozi Araghi, 38, and 42-year-old Sydney-based New Zealander Cindy Low were killed when their raft overturned on a conveyor-belt on Tuesday. Ms Goodchild’s 12-year-old daughter Ebony and Ms Low’s 10-year-old son Kieran were miraculously thrown clear.

Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk this afternoon laid flowers outside the park “on behalf of all Queensland families who cannot be at Dreamworld” at the makeshift memorial established near the entrance of the park. 

She refused to be drawn into the debate about when the park should reopen, but instead said she would leave it in the hands of police. 

“The issue of Dreamworld reopening tomorrow is a matter between the organisation and police,” she said. “The police commissioner I understand will be having a conversation and it is up to those parties to make that decision.

“Please let the police do their job, and the police will be having discussions with Dreamworld about the timing of their opening.

“That is the matter entirely because it is a crime scene involved. It is entirely an operation matter and the organisation needs to respond to police in relation to that.”
results.standFirst: THE park has cancelled plans for a controversial memorial day just three days after four died at the park in horrific circumstances.

results.title: Mum’s frantic triple-0 call revealed
results.subtitle: Murdered toddler Nikki Coslovich’s mother Peta-Ann Francis says false information given to police was due to panic
results.description: THE mother of murdered toddler Nikki Coslovich says false information she gave 000 when she first reported her daughter missing was not deliberate, and was the result of her panicked state of mind.
results.subscriptionSummary: THE mother of murdered toddler Nikki Coslovich says false information she gave 000 when she first reported her daughter missing was the result of her panicked state of mind. LISTEN TO THE CALL

thumbnailImage.title: Mum’s frantic triple-0 call revealed
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 180c8606-9c07-11e6-ab69-22cb8f6501a3
thumbnailImage.description: Mum’s frantic triple-0 call revealed
thumbnailImage.imageName: Peta-Ann Francis under Police escort to Mildura Co

results.seoHeadline: Nikki Coslovich murder: 000 call by mum Peta-Ann Francis released by Supreme Court
results.body:
Peta-Ann Francis was grilled for a third day straight today during the trial of John Torney, her former boyfriend who is charged with Nikki’s murder.

Torney has confessed to hiding Nikki’s body in the ceiling of her Oram Court home, but claims the toddler was killed by Ms Francis on August 25 last year.

Torney’s defence team have accused Ms Francis of lying about the events on the day and have accused her of killing the toddler after losing her temper and throwing little Nikki on to her bed — a claim she denies.

Torney’s barrister Julie Condon has previously told the jury the 000 call is a vital piece of evidence in the case.

“Listen closely to that call, members of the jury, and ask yourselves this: is the tone out, in that call? And I don’t mean the ringtone. I mean, is her tone out?” Ms Condon said during her opening last week

“Listen closely to how she stumbles over the most fundamental question that the D24 operator asks her, which is, “When did you see your daughter last?” The D24 operator has to ask it twice, because Peta-Ann Francis doesn’t know how to respond.”

But Ms Francis today told the jury false details in the call — including a claim that she put Nikki to bed at 11am — were not deliberate lies, and were caused by her state of panic.

“I wasn’t coherent. I was just worried about where my daughter was. I wasn’t paying too much attention to what the lady was saying, to her questions, and I didn’t know half the answers,” Ms Francis said.

In other evidence, Belinda Torney, John Torney’s mother and a nearby neighbour of the couple, said Ms Francis’ eyes were red and she was unusually quiet when she saw her about five hours before Nikki’s body was found.

“Normally you can’t shut her up ... (but) she barely said a word,” Ms Torney said.

The trial, before Justice Elizabeth Hollingworth, continues.

padraic.murphy@news.com.au
results.standFirst: THE mother of murdered toddler Nikki Coslovich says false information she gave 000 when she first reported her daughter missing was the result of her panicked state of mind. LISTEN TO THE CALL

results.title: Youth jail bid by gangbanger thugs
results.subtitle: Suspected Apex gang members to assessed for youth jail over spate of attacks
results.description: TWO young thugs who terrorised unsuspecting Melburnians who had been asleep in their beds look set to meet up at youth detention for a giant, gangbanger reunion party.
results.subscriptionSummary: TWO young thugs who terrorised unsuspecting Melburnians who had been asleep in their beds look set to meet up at youth detention for a giant, gangbanger reunion party.

thumbnailImage.title: Youth jail bid by gangbanger thugs
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 8127ce54-9c05-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: Youth jail bid by gangbanger thugs

results.seoHeadline: Apex gang Melbourne: Thugs behind attacks set to meet in youth jail
results.body:
Suspected Apex gangsters Peter Paulino, 18, and Bill Tang, 19, helped ruin the life of a hardworking Brighton East father who was brutally bashed while trying to defend his family from an early morning home invasion. 

The teenagers appeared before the County Court today, where a judge directed they be assessed for a possible stint in youth detention. 

The direction came just days after another wannabe teen Tupac, gangster Mursal Biel, was directed by the County Court for an identical assessment. 

Like Paulino and Tang, Biel and his gang terrorised unsuspecting citizens in violent robberies across Melbourne. 

In a victim impact statement read to the court, Paulino and Tang’s victim said he woke to find a gang of African offenders smashing their way into his home. 

“I was full of rage … thinking how can I protect my family from all of them,” he said. 

The petrified father attempted to defend himself with two wooden poles, but was brutally assaulted with rocks and an umbrella pole. 

The man told the court his entire life had been altered by the attack and he now lived in a constant state of fear. 

His luxury BMW X5 was stolen in the April raid, but later recovered by police.

The court heard Paulino — who was whacked on the drug ice at the time — was involved in another home invasion hours later on a house full of Chinese students in Ormond. 

A hammer was used by the gang of thugs in the attack. 

Many of the students lost their computers in the terrifying raid and later failed their exams. 

Both of the men were on bail at the time of their offending and face up to 30 years behind bars. 

The pair has pleaded guilty to a swag of charges, including aggravated burglary and assaults. 

Tang is already enjoying an 18-month stint in youth detention after being sentenced over similar offending in August. 

He will be sentenced next month while Paulino will be sentenced at a later date while an effort to consolidate further offences is processed. 

wayne.flower@news.com.au
results.standFirst: TWO young thugs who terrorised unsuspecting Melburnians who had been asleep in their beds, look set to meet up in youth detention for a giant, gangbanger reunion party.

results.seoHeadline: Melbourne Cup Carnival Birdcage 2016: what to expect inside
results.body:
What goes on behind the scenes? 

Herald Sun reporters Anna Byrne and Jackie Epstein were given a sneak peek at the glamour, themes, decor, entertainment, food, menus and drinks the A-list will be treated to.

Bec Hewitt, the Lavazza racing ambassador, said she couldn’t wait to hit the track on Derby Day, Cup Day and Oaks Day.

“I’m very excited because I’ve only been to Cup Day and this year I’ve got quite a few and I’ll get to see the fashion over the course of the week,’’ she said.

The Birdcage’s first ever swimming pool will be featured this year in the Mumm marquee. 

Here is what else is sure to impress in the Carnival’s hot spots this year.

Theme: Australia

Menu: Tony Cimmino from Epicure has curated a menu of iconic Australian flavours with a modern makeover including a gourmet BBQ with sausages, rissoles, lamb and crayfish; milo mousse and berry pavlova. 

In the restaurant five locally produced dishes created by Nancy Kinchella will be served in Emirates’ sit down restaurant, inspired by Emirates five Australian cities that it flies to — Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney, Perth and Brisbane. Grazing dishes will be served each day.

Guests: Rachel Griffiths, Olympia Valance, Carrie Bickmore, Molly Meldrum

Features:

- Entertainment paying tribute to Australia’s heritage and indigenous culture with a contemporary dance performance in collaboration with Stan Yarramunua, a well-known Aboriginal artist and didgeridoo player.

- The Parlour, featuring hairdresser Joey Scandizzo and Lancome make up director Lara Srokowski

- An Autore showcase of some of Australia’s finest south sea pearls 

- The largest balcony in the marquees history, with a wraparound decking that includes views of the home straight

Theme: Milan 

Menu: Adam D’Sylva has designed dishes especially for the marquee with an Italian flavour

Guests: Bec Hewitt, Megan Gale and Bec Judd as well as Olympic gold medallists Mack Horton, Cate and Bronte Campbell, captain of the rugby sevens Charlotte Caslick, shooter Catherine Skinner, sailor Tom Burton and Chloe Esposito.

Features:

- Liz Cambage will make her DJ-ing debut on the dance floor on Cup Day

- Melbourne ruckman Max Gawn will be the guest barista on Cup Day

- Designed by Neale Whitaker, the marquee features a 360 degree view of Milan’s Galleria, the epicentre of the fashion capital, with the walls and ceiling of the marquee replicating the magnificence of the Italian mid-century building.

Theme: ‘Harnessed’ By James Boag Birdcage Experience.

Menu: James Viles will prepare dishes for The Harnessed Culinary Experience. Each dish tells a story of the ingredients’ origin and natural habitat.

Features: The private dining room will be transformed into a cheese room where racegoers will be able to sample some of Tasmania’s finest cheeses, matched with premium James Boag beer. There is a light projection illustrating Tasmania’s natural and untouched beauty on the ceilings; with the centrepiece bar and hanging lights being draped with native greenery and vines.

Theme: Club de la Plage (“Beach Club”) marquee

Guests: Mumm Ambassador Pia Muehlenbeck, DJ Didier Cohen, E! News anchor Maria Menounos, Devious Maids star and former Melrose Place heart-throb Grant Show

Features: 

- An indoor swimming pool

- Theatrical performances from Rosé Soleil participating in aerial stunts and synchronised swimming with vocals from Australian singer songwriter and Melbourne local, Paris Wells.

Theme: European Atelier salon

Food: A crepe station, cheese bar,

Guests: Jennifer Hawkins, Rachael Finch, Jodi Anasta, Lauren Phillips, Nicole Trunfio, Andy Lee, Tim Cahill, Ronan Keating

Features:

- 200 metres of velvet used to create the feel of a European salon 

- The marquee is higher than in the past allowing views of the track

Theme: anticipation inspired by Milan design week 

Food: Ground floor: Mr Miyagi salmon taco, ‘frose’ frozen rose hip drink

Mid floor: restaurant 44 seat by David Moyle 

Top floor: very bespoke with food by Ben Shewry from Attica; 8 seats only with six sittings with an experience you can’t get anywhere else. 

Guests: Emma Freedman, Jessica Gomes, Dion Lee, Olympia Valance, Cheyenne Tozzi, Shane Jacobson, Gyton Grantley, Lisa Wilkinson. 

Features:

- 4000 tubes of cardboard interiors by Etic famed for Aesop interiors. 

- Personalised monograms race books from The Daily Edited 

- Modular structure that clicks together and to carry soil and garden on rooftop which provides insulation and is a fire retardant. 

- Full truckload of apple blossom and 4000 roses 

Theme: David Bromley

Features: David Bromley mural on the exterior of the marquee 

- Chris Hatcher and David Bromley tasting the new Bromley by Wolf Blass wine

- 3 x original Bromley paintings from which the new wine series labels are derived from (Birds, Nudes and Butterflies series)

Theme: Digital innovation 

Food: the famed Mulberry Group, owners of Top Paddock, Higher Ground and The Kettle Black, in collaboration with epicure have created a menu that evokes the changing theme of the marquee with items that celebrate the traditional colours of the race days, with black and white crisp barramundi burger with squid ink on DerbyDay, yellow sweet corn custard on Cup Day and red yellowfin tuna carpaccio on Oaks Day.

Guests: DJ Ed Fisher, Alex Dimitriades, Havana Brown, Grant Smilie as well as world-class music acts Barbara Tucker, Paces, DJ Q (Quinta Young, Disco Diva Tucker, Usain Bolt’s cousin DJ Erica and another special international guest soon to be announced.

Features:

- Selfie wall

- Model and artist Jess Bush creating murals on the walls over the four days of the carnival

- Samantha Jade singing on Cup Day

- A unique digital facade of LED screens that will show passers by the activity inside to create an inclusive environment

Theme: European Haute Couture Fashion Houses 

Food: As the only self-catering marquee in the Birdcage, this year’s menu has been designed and made by Hilton Melbourne South Wharf’s executive chef Vas Caldera. 

Guests: Corporates, partners and customers

Theme: Secrets of Schweppes 

Food: Every menu item and cocktail is a sensory experience with heroes ingredients from Schweppes’ famous drinks such as a prawn and ginger dumpling with citrus and chilli oil dipping sauce; taking inspiration from the ginger and chilli in Schweppes dry ginger ale and ceviche tacos with fresh lemon and lime, taking inspiration from their lemonade.

Guests: Customers and corporates

Features:

- The marquee is scented with lemon and orange in the morning and ginger and chilli in the afternoon

Theme: Contemporary designer garden

Food:

Jacques Reymond fusion food takes you on a culinary journey around the world, including more than 800 pork belly sliders. Guests with a sweet tooth will be treated to a Burch and Purchese sweets station featuring edible flowers.

Guests: Barry Hall, Jack Watts, Lucy and Ruby Brownless, Adam Goodes, Katelyn Mallyon

Features:

- Internationally acclaimed landscape architect Jack Merlo is behind the exclusive and unique design

- A feature pergola with more than 150 white orchids suspended over the main bar

- 7 self-serve betting terminals
results.standFirst: THE nation’s top celebs and VIPs, plus international guests, are treated to a variety of drinks and food in the exclusive Birdcage marquee precinct during the Melbourne Cup Carnival. We check it out.

results.title: 3000 greyhounds killed in Victoria
results.subtitle: Greyhound racing deaths in Victoria remain unacceptably high
results.description: MORE than 3000 greyhounds — equivalent to eight a day — were euthanased in the past year despite a push to clean up the industry after the live baiting scandal.
results.subscriptionSummary: MORE than 3000 greyhounds — equivalent to eight a day — were euthanased in the past year despite a push to clean up the industry after the live baiting scandal.

thumbnailImage.title: 3000 greyhounds killed in Victoria
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 1c851b64-9c00-11e6-ab69-22cb8f6501a3
thumbnailImage.description: 3000 greyhounds killed in Victoria
thumbnailImage.imageName: From left to right Volantis, Presh, Arnhem Chaos a

results.body:
Greyhound Racing Victoria’s latest annual report, tabled in parliament today, revealed “owners unable to find homes” and “end-of-career decisions by owners” among the reasons provided on veterinarian euthanasia certificates for the 3012 dogs.

The shocking statistics have renewed calls from animal welfare advocates to ban the sport.

Animals Australia campaign director Lyn White said: “If you wanted a single figure that speaks to why greyhound racing should end, you’ve now got one.

“Any compassionate human being would be shocked by the shameful, unnecessary deaths of these beautiful and gentle dogs.”

Greens animal welfare spokeswoman Sue Pennicuik said a ban was the only solution to stop the deaths.

“Dog racing is responsible for the death of more than 3000 greyhounds in the past year,” Ms Pennicuik said.

“The NSW special commission of inquiry found that the greyhound racing industry is incapable of reducing the number of deaths.

“Cruelty towards greyhounds won’t end while this sport is allowed to operate.”

In the report, GRV conceded the euthanasia figures were “completely unacceptable”.

GRV chief executive Alan Clayton said initiatives to reduce wastage — the killing of slow, injured or unwanted greyhounds — would be rolled out in the next year, including:

A $3.5 MILLION expansion of the Greyhound Adoption Program (GAP);

BETTER management of breeding; and

EDUCATION and training programs focused on whole of life plans for greyhounds.

“The absolute key priority for the sport in the 21st century is to make sure that every racing greyhound registered in Victoria will have the opportunity to live out its life in full, whether it makes it to the track or not,” Mr Clayton said.

Mr Clayton said euthanasia would only be considered appropriate on “justifiable medical or behavioural grounds” and that by 2018-19, it is hoped all greyhounds bred in Victoria would be rehomed.

“This is a very big challenge and one we do not shy away from,” Mr Clayton said.

Shocking revelations of live baiting, animal cruelty and wastage has thrown the industry into disrepair in recent years.

The NSW government even went as far as to announce it was ending dog racing in the state — a decision premier Mike Baird has since ditched saying he “got it wrong”.

Despite all the controversy shrouding the industry, a record 208,000 people — up five per cent on the previous year — attended race meetings across Victoria in the year to June 30.

A record $1.83 billion was also wagered on Victorian greyhound races, a yearly rise of 13 per cent.

The GRV committed its net profit of $5.8 million would be reinvested in animal welfare, integrity initiatives and club infrastructure.

rebekah.cavanagh@news.com.au
results.standFirst: MORE than 3000 Victorian greyhounds — equivalent to eight a day — were euthanased in the past year despite a push to clean up the industry after the live baiting scandal.

results.title: What happens after tragedy strikes
results.subtitle: All eyes are on Dreamworld to see what comes next — so how did other parks respond to tragic incidents?
results.description: HISTORY has shown what happens to theme parks around the world when tragedy strikes. While some are able to put the incidents behind them and move on, others are forced to shut their doors as business dries up.
results.subscriptionSummary:
HISTORY has shown us what happens to theme parks when tragedy strikes. 
 As Dreamworld looks to its future here are how the management of other venues responded when tragedy struck.

thumbnailImage.title: What happens after tragedy strikes
thumbnailImage.subtitle: c016ef14-9be7-11e6-ab69-22cb8f6501a3
thumbnailImage.description: What happens after tragedy strikes

results.socialTitle: How theme parks move on from tragic events
results.seoHeadline: Dreamworld Thunder River Rapids ride: What next for theme park?
results.body:
Dreamworld is no doubt hoping they can move on from the horrific accident which saw four people die on the Thunder River Rapids ride.

The park’s operator, Ardent Leisure, has come under fire for their decision to open the park just two days after the incident.

“After discussion with counsellors and a lot to do with the issues of people grieving, the decision was taken to turn tomorrow (Friday) into a fundraising event to support the Red Cross,” Ardent chairman Neil Balnaves told reporters. All admission fees will be donated to the charity. 

“It is better that people get back to work and basically get together with their comrades and talk and deal with this issue rather than ... sitting at home in isolation,” Mr Balnaves said. 

“It’s driven by the utmost respect for the families and the deaths.” The theme park will open for normal business on Saturday.

“We can’t return the four lives,” he said.

Here’s how other theme parks around the world responded to tragic accidents.

One of the worst roller coaster tragedies in history happened in May 1972 on the old wooden Big Dipper reported The Mirror.

The rope that hauls the cars to the top of the launch hill snapped and then the anti-rollback mechanism failed.

It caused a chain of cars to hurtle back into the boarding area, smashing into a wall and killing five children and injuring 13 more.

After the accident the Big Dipper was permanently closed and dismantled. It was replaced by a more modern steel roller coaster known as The Cyclone reported the Londonist. But the iconic dipper’s retirement led to a swift decline and coupled with development disputes, the fair’s fortunes diminished until it finally closed its doors in 1974. From time to time during the 1970s temporary fairgrounds occasionally set up in the park, but a permanent attraction never took hold.

Built in 1970, Exploland covered 20 hectares in Osaka and became one of the most popular destinations in Japan for thrillseekers.

Fujin Raijin II, a six-car rollercoaster that travelled along more than a kilometre of track at speeds in excess of 120km/h, operated without issue for 15 years. Then, on May 5, 2007, it derailed, tossing passengers off the track and claiming the life of a 19-year-old woman.

Yoshino Kogowara died instantly when her head struck a guardrail. Eighteen others were injured.

Expoland closed briefly as investigators tried to determine the cause of the accident. They found fault in an axle that had not been replaced in 15 years.

When the park reopened, visitor numbers were way down. Less than two years later, it closed for good.

“We couldn’t regain the people’s trust”, a spokesman told The Japan Times.

In late 2015, six long years after it closed, a much tamer version of Expoland reopened. Now, its drawing cards are a giant ferris wheel and a burgeoning retail and entertainment precinct.

On June 9, 1979 six children and one adult died when Sydney’s Luna Park’s Ghost Train caught fire. An electrical fault was blamed for sparking the inferno but rumours have long persisted that it was deliberately lit. 

In 2007 the niece of one of Sydney’s most notorious crime figures, nightclub owner and developer Abe Saffron, told media outlets that her uncle was the one who had started the fire.

Anne Buckingham said that Saffron wanted to purchase the park and hadn’t meant for anyone to die.

Saffron had long been rumoured to be involved in the fire but had always denied he was responsible.

Jenny Poidevin, who lost her husband and two sons in the fire, said she had also heard different theories.

“But I truly don’t know. I don’t know what to believe anymore.

“To this day I still believe that there is someone out there that knows the exact truth and I don’t believe justice has been done in terms of what truly happened there that night.”

After the fire the park was forced to close as people stayed away. Most of the park was demolished, and a new amusement park was constructed, which opened in 1982 under the name of Harbourside Amusement Park before resuming the Luna Park name.

In June 2015 Victoria Balch and Leah Washington both had to have a leg amputated after a car on The Smiler ride at Alton Towers collided with an empty one in front of it.

Despite 16 people suffering injuries in the crash, the ride reopened again in April this year after the parent company Merlin said the accident was down to “human error” by staff who are being prosecuted under Health and Safety laws.

Speaking of the reopening, Balch said, “I can’t bear to think of the ride reopening. I hoped they would destroy it”.

Three people died when the carriages on the world’s largest indoor triple loop roller coaster, The Mindbender, flew off the track.

The ride was described as one of the “safest rides in the world” when it was built reported The Express UK.

But in June 1986 missing bolts caused the four-car-train to fly from the track.

The last car collided with support structures before crashing into a concrete pillar in front of a packed audience watching a concert. Three people fell to their deaths and the fourth suffered serious neck and chest injuries.

But despite the tragedy the ride opened seven months later with new safety measures, and since then has had an excellent safety record reported The Mirror.

A superman-themed ride at Darien Lake ended the life of an Iraq war veteran who had lost both his legs in the conflict reported The Express UK.

James Hackener, a US Army vet, was thrown from the Ride of Steel roller coaster and fell to his death in July 2011. It was later found that the safety barriers were not designed for amputees and he should never have been allowed on.

It was then revealed that a man was thrown from the same ride three days after the park first opened in 1999, but he was lucky enough to escape with only injuries. 

The death of Hackener hasn’t turned people away from the theme park which remains open to this day. The actual ride is still in operation.

The infamous Action Park is known for being one of the most deadly theme parks ever built, as six people have died since its opening in 1978.

The first recorded death at the theme park was in July 1982, when a 15 year old drowned in the Tidal Wave Pool.

Then in 1984, a 20 year old drowned and during the summer of 1987, an 18 year old died while in the pool.

After three further deaths, caused by a drowning, an electrocution and a heart attack, the pool developed the name “Grave Pool”.

The park was forced to shut down in 1996 due to legal action over the deaths. It reopened under a new name in 1998 but reverted back to its original name in 2014.

In August 2016, Caleb Schwab, 10, was decapitated while riding on the 51 metre high Verruckt attraction at Schlitterbahn Waterpark in Kansas City, as horrified witnesses looked on.

Kansas City Police said Schwab suffered a “fatal neck injury at the end of the ride”.

Witnesses claim Caleb went down the first drop of the world’s tallest waterside, then flew out and hit netting enclosing the ride.

The ride remained shut for rest of the summer season and details of the ride can no longer be found on the website. The park remained open however. There is no word yet on whether the ride will reopen next season.

On June 21, 2010, Gemma Savage, 20, died while riding on the Treetop Twister rollercoaster at the Lightwater Valley theme park in Yorkshire after a collision with two other cars.

The student suffered fatal head injuries and a damaged spine when her carriage accelerated up a U-bend, crashed into the car in front, before sliding back down and hitting the car behind.

Park owners and ride manufacturers were fined a total of £155,000 (AU$247,993) after it was discovered wiring on the ride was faulty.

The ride eventually reopened under the slightly different name, Twister Ride.

Fourteen years after Savage’s death a worker was sacked for turning on the ride as a joke while a colleague was carrying out safety checks reported The Mirror.

Sasha Higgins was forced to cling on for life and scream out for help while she spun around in the waltzer style carriage. She was uninjured. 

In April 2004 Hayley Williams, 16, was killed after she fell out of a car while riding on the Hydro water rollercoaster at Oakwood Theme Park.

Williams, who was visiting family in the area, fell 30 metres to the ground and died of internal injuries. The park was fined almost £250,000 (AU$400,00) for negligence after a report found employees weren’t regularly performing the correct safety checks.

The ride was closed for a year after William’s death and then reopened with the new name, Drenched.
results.standFirst: HISTORY has shown us what happens to theme parks when things go horribly wrong. As Dreamworld looks to its future, here are how other venues responded to tragic accidents.

results.title: Turnbull denies ‘war’ with Abbott
results.subtitle: Malcolm Turnbull says ties with Tony Abbott ‘cordial’ despite leaked document suggesting they are at ‘war’
results.description: FRIENDS or enemies?

thumbnailImage.title: Turnbull denies ‘war’ with Abbott
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 75c79532-9bf4-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: Turnbull denies ‘war’ with Abbott

results.socialTitle: Malcolm Turnbull rejects he is at war with Tony Abbott
results.seoHeadline: Malcolm Turnbull says ties with Tony Abbott ‘cordial’ despite leaked document suggesting they are at ‘war’
results.body:
Malcolm Turnbull’s relationship with Tony Abbott is anyone’s guess really.

For his part, the Prime Minister maintains there is no feud.

“Ofcourse not,” Mr Turnbull told 3AW Melbourne radio host Neil Mitchell this morning.

Pushed further, the PM kept his response diplomatic.

“I have a cordial relationship with Tony Abbott as I do with all my colleagues in parliament.”

His comments come after Sky News yesterday obtained an unnamed Coalition MP’s talking points, which are titled “Abbott-Turnbull war”. 

The document shows contradictory messages about the relationship between the Mr Turnbull and Mr Abbott, who is the Member for Warringah. 

The statement reads: “Malcolm Turnbull and Tony Abbott are both working in the same direction of strengthening our democratic processes to open up opportunities for increased member participation.”

The MP went on to say there was “no sign of any conflict between their positions”, contradicting the title of the point. 

But Opposition Leader Bill Shorten isn’t convinced. At a press conference yesterday, Mr Shorten said the Turnbull government was more interested in “fighting amongst each other” than it was in fighting for the jobs of Australians. 

“This is a government who will need more than spin to paper over the fundamental divisions in this government,” he told reporters.

“The Turnbull government should be fighting for the jobs of Australians but they are more interested in fighting amongst each other about their own jobs, at a time when Medicare has been grievously cut, real wage levels are flatlining, wage rises are flatlining and living standards are falling — all we’ve got is a Liberal Government focused on fighting themselves, not standing up for Australians.”

Tensions between Mr Turnbull and Mr Abbott have boiled over at several points during the past week.

Last Thursday, both men flatly contradicted each other in Parliament over whether there was a deal to end a ban on a lever-action shotgun in return for a senator’s vote.

Mr Turnbull fired shots at his predecessor over the issue, accusing Mr Abbott of being fully aware of a “deal” to change gun laws in exchange for support Liberal Democrat David Leyonhjelm’s support in the Senate.

But Mr Abbott said the debate had not been represented fairly by Labor, accusing the Opposition of using “smoke screens” and “mirrors”.
results.standFirst: THE Prime Minister says he has a ‘cordial relationship’ with Tony Abbott, after a leaked document suggested they are at ‘war’.

results.title: Bishop’s Jakarta ‘fashion diplomacy’
results.subtitle: Foreign Minister Julie Bishop hits Jakarta Fashion Week
results.description: FOREIGN Minister Julie Bishop mixed trade and security talks with fashion diplomacy while in Indonesia for her eighth official visit to the archipelago since taking over the portfolio.
results.subscriptionSummary:
FOREIGN Minister Julie Bishop mixed trade and security talks with fashion diplomacy while in Indonesia for her eighth official visit to the archipelago since taking over the portfolio.
 After a full day of meetings with Government officials, Ms Bishop changed into a figure-hugging black Rachel Gilbert dress and Margot McKinney jewellery for a Jakarta Fashion Week event on Wednesday night.

thumbnailImage.title: Bishop’s Jakarta ‘fashion diplomacy’
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 30415a88-9bf0-11e6-a6cc-8bf57620ea71
thumbnailImage.description: Bishop’s Jakarta ‘fashion diplomacy’

results.body:
After a full day of meetings with Government officials, Ms Bishop changed into a figure-hugging black Rachel Gilbert dress and Margot McKinney jewellery for a Jakarta Fashion Week event on Wednesday night. 

The annual festival showcases the latest trends by local and foreign designers and this year included Melbourne siblings Alex and Georgia Cleary from Melbourne label, Alpha60 and Brisbane designer Khim Hang.

The fashion-loving Foreign Minister also met with Indonesian designers including Peggy Haranto and Restu Anggraini.

The self-described “friend of fashion” also mingled and took selfies with Indonesian stars including actor Bunga Citra Lestari, even agreeing to requests for a “duck face” pose. 

Ms Bishop said she’s happy to be a proponent of “fashion diplomacy” as the industry adds $12 billion to Australia’s economy annually.

“We are known for traditional industries like mining, resources and agriculture but it’s our creative industries that contribute about $90 billion to the Australian economy,” Ms Bishop said.

“Through what I call fashion diplomacy ... we have been using our diplomatic resources around the world to connect Australian fashion designers with the fashion magazines, fashion houses and buyers around the world.

“Australia and Indonesia are neighbours, we do co-operate and collaborate across a whole range of areas but I think one of the most exciting, one of the most dynamic, one of the most innovative is our collaboration in the world of fashion.”

It’s the third year Australian fashion designs have been showcased at the festival.

annika.smethurst@news.com.au

@annikasmethurst
results.standFirst: FOREIGN Minister Julie Bishop mixed trade and security talks with fashion diplomacy while in Indonesia for her eighth official visit to the archipelago since taking over the portfolio.

results.title: Fresh inquest for double-murder
results.subtitle: Portland double murder of Margaret Penny and Claire Acocks to be re-examined by coroner
results.description: A 25-YEAR-OLD double murder mystery will be re-examined by the coroner after the man charged with the brutal killings died awaiting trial.

thumbnailImage.title: Fresh inquest for double-murder
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 4d04be0e-9bea-11e6-a6cc-8bf57620ea71
thumbnailImage.description: Fresh inquest for double-murder
thumbnailImage.imageName: EMBARGOED UNTIL: 11/03/12... Robert And Margaret Penny Picture: Supplied

results.body:
The 1991 murders of Margaret Penny, 58, and her hairdresser Claire Acocks, 49, inside a Portland hair salon are considered among Victoria’s most chilling killings.

Now the families of both women hope evidence collected in the case against Mrs Penny’s husband Robert can finally solve the case at a second coronial inquest.

Robert Penny, 84, was last year charged over the murders but died while his lawyers fought to have the case discontinued.

MORE: Robert Penny dies waiting to face court

Shocking Portland murders remain unsolved

New evidence included statements from Mr Penny’s children and granddaughter police said were critical to finally solving the baffling murder mystery.

It also included a covertly recorded conversation shortly before Mr Penny’s arrest in which he talked about the murders and murder weapon.

An original inquest into the murder, held in 1995, concluded in an open finding.

Police interviewed 6000 people in relation to the killings.

Both the Penny and Acocks families requested a second inquest.

Police said evidence by Mr Penny’s estranged son was to be critical in the case against him.

He had also allegedly disclosed chilling detail to Mrs Acocks’ husband the morning after the murders.

Police said Mr Penny visited the Acocks’ family home and said: “Claire died very quickly. She was killed with a tail comb.”

At that time no one, including police, was aware of puncture marks or injuries.

Mr Penny’s son also told police his dad phoned him the night his mum was killed and told him what weapon was used.

A similar call was allegedly made to his daughter.

Investigators believed Mr Penny was cheating on his wife with a woman he married shortly after his wife’s murder.

On the morning of the murders police believed the couple had an explosive fight over their granddaughter.

Mrs Penny had wanted to take the five-year-old to the hairdressers with her but police allege Mr Penny refused because “he knew what was to occur there later that day”.

Ahead of his death Mr Penny persistently denied any involvement in the killings.

“This case has a long and complex history,” said coroner Jacqui Hawkins. 

“It’s most unfortunate that the criminal process was unable to be completed due to Mr Penny’s death.” 

The inquest will begin on November 23.

with AAP

shannon.deery@news.com.au

@s_deery
results.standFirst: A 25-year-old double murder mystery will be re-examined by the coroner after the man charged with the brutal killings died awaiting trial.

results.title: Mozzie invasion: You’re not imagining it
results.subtitle: Mosquito plague in Melbourne thanks to perfect conditions
results.description: PESKY mosquitoes have mobbed the state ahead of season with dozens of councils forced to take early action to put a bite on the problem.
results.subscriptionSummary: PESKY mosquitoes have mobbed the state ahead of season with dozens of councils forced to take early action to put a bite on the problem.

thumbnailImage.title: Mozzie invasion: You’re not imagining it
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 30d590be-9b40-11e6-a6cc-8bf57620ea71
thumbnailImage.description: Mozzie invasion: You’re not imagining it

results.seoHeadline: Mosquito plague: Swarms of mosquitoes descend on Melbourne thanks to almost perfect breeding conditions
results.body:
The outbreak has sparked a warning from public health authorities who predict a bumper season after recent floods and heavy rain provided perfect breeding grounds for the pests.

The biggest concern is the risk of Victorians contracting mosquito-borne diseases.

WHY MOZZIES BITE SOME PEOPLE AND NOT OTHERS

The state’s chief health officer Charles Guest warned Victorians to be prepared and protect their families as experts on the ground predict “a serious problem” this summer.

Have you encountered a swarm of mosquitoes lately? Tell us where below. 

“More than anything, mosquitoes are a nuisance. However, their bite can turn nasty for the few who get infected with a mosquito-borne disease,” Professor Guest said.

“There are simple and inexpensive steps you can take to protect yourself and your loved ones.

“Most importantly, people should ensure there are no pools of stagnant water on their property.”

Professor Guest said Victoria’s ‘Beat the Bite’ public awareness campaign, mosquito surveillance and control program had been brought forward a month early in response to increased reports of mosquito populations.

Flood-affected areas in the Murray River region including Mildura, Swan Hill, Gannawarra, Campaspe, Moira, Wodonga and Shepparton are among those taking early action.

Melbourne and its surrounding suburbs are also on the brink of a plague with residents reporting swarms of mosquitoes in recent days.

A mosquito monitor is already working full time in some areas and parkland and open spaces with stagnant water are being sprayed with control agents.

Traps have also been set up in breeding sites to count numbers and conduct tests to ensure the mozzies aren’t carrying deadly diseases.

Last year, 301 cases of Ross River virus and 11 cases of Barmah Forest virus were reported across the state, with those affected suffering joint inflammation, pain and rash.

Mosquitoes can also carry the deadly Murray Valley encephalitis virus (MVE) — an infection that can cause the brain to swell, leading to brain damage or death.

The last human case was detected was in 1974 but the virus has since been found in sentinel chicken flocks as part of the Victorian Government’s surveillance program. 

* Cover up. Wear light-coloured, loose-fitting clothing when outdoors.

* Use mosquito repellents containing DEET or picaridin on exposed skin.

* Try to limit outdoor activity if lots of mosquitoes are about (usually dusk and dawn).

* Make sure there is no stagnant water where mosquitoes can breed around your home by emptying flower pots, tyres, buckets, tins, bird baths and pet bowls weekly. 

* Empty children’s wading pools when not being used and keep fishponds stocked with fish.

For more health tips and advice, visit betterhealth.vic.gov.au/campaigns/beat-the-bite

rebekah.cavanagh@news.com.au
results.standFirst: PESKY mosquitoes have mobbed the state ahead of season with dozens of councils forced to take early action to put a bite on the problem.

results.seoHeadline: Police shoot armed man in Dandenong
results.body:
The dramatic footage shows the moment two officers opened fire on a man on Stud Rd, who had attempted to carjack a BMW moments earlier, while trying to escape police. 

Footage shows one of the policemen with his gun in his hand while chasing the 26-year-old. 

Cameras also captured the moment the man fell to the ground after being shot.

He was arrested soon afterward.

The injured man was taken to Dandenong Hospital where he underwent surgery, after being shot just before 4pm past night.

Stud Rd was closed between Clow St and David St as a result.

Victoria Police Assistant Commissioner Bob Hill said uniform police officers on patrol from Dandenong police station pulled over a car on Grey St, Dandenong, before a male driver ran off. 

The police officers chased the man on foot, when the man pulled out a gun.

“That foot chase continued through the back blocks, across fences, three garages of homes,” he said.

Man wounded in police shooting

Mr Hill said the man — who was known to police — ran along Stud Rd before pointing a gun at the officers.

Both police officers, “who were in fear of their safety” shot the man.

He suffered two gunshot wounds to his torso.

Mr Hill said he had attended Dandenong police station and spoken to the pair

“The two constables ... have done an exceptional job as far as I’m concerned, facing some very trying and challenging sets of circumstances, giving this individual ample opportunity to drop his weapon,” Mr Hill said.

“But unfortunately they have had to resort to using their firearms in fear of their safety. 

“They have done an exceptional job in very trying circumstances as far as I’m concerned they acted with utmost professionalism; I’m quite proud of the work they’ve done.” 

It was the second shooting in the Dandenong area yesterday.

Police were forced to fire shots at a woman who attempted to shoot them in Keysborough early this morning.
results.standFirst: UPDATE: DRAMATIC footage shows the moment police twice shot an armed man trying to flee them in Melbourne’s southeast last night.

results.subtitle: Melbourne Cup Carnival racegoers warned drunk and disorderly behaviour will result in big fines
results.description: VICTORIA Police have issued a stern warning to all Melbourne racegoers that bad behaviour will not be tolerated and on the spot fines will be handed out to anyone flouting the rules.

thumbnailImage.title: Drunken racegoers set for huge fines
thumbnailImage.subtitle: deaab4de-9b3c-11e6-a6cc-8bf57620ea71
thumbnailImage.description: Drunken racegoers set for huge fines

results.seoHeadline: Melbourne Cup carnival drunken racegoers: Girl in the blue dress
results.body:
With hundreds of thousands of fans set to descend on Flemington Racecourse over the next 10 days, police will be out in full force and those deemed drunk in public will face immediate fines of $622.

Those deemed to be drunk and disorderly will pay $777.

“It’s a significant penalty,” Commander Russell Barrett said.

GALLERY: How not to behave at the races

“I’m particularly keen to see everyone come and enjoy themselves, respect other patrons and respect the police.

“We’ve got a job to do, and our job is to enable other people to enjoy the event.”

“I’ve worked this event for many many years and I’ve seen a steady gradual improvement in behaviour,” he said.

Last year Sarah Finn aka “the girl in the blue dress” went viral after she was seen pushing over a senior police officer in full view of television cameras.

The 25-year-old sent Acting Superintendent Steven Cooper flying backwards into a flower bed after the Melbourne Cup, and was be charged with assaulting police.

results.seoHeadline: Kevin Muscat FFA Cup goal comments: Melbourne Victory coach faces FFA Code of Conduct breach, Melbourne Derby, Luke Brattan
results.body:
Muscat was seething after the match referee overruled the linesman after Luke Brattan’s controversial opener was disallowed, due to the presence of Tim Cahill in an off-side position.

“If you have to get out of the way of the ball travelling towards the goal then I’d suggest you’re obstructing the keeper, I can’t see how there’s any other explanation.

“Don’t try and cover it up, you’re just insulting our intelligence.”

The FFA issued a statement this afternoon.

MORE: Cahill grabs Muscat in fiery encounter

“The citing relates to comments made in the official post-match Fox Sports interview and the press conference following the Westfield FFA Cup semi-final match between Melbourne Victory and Melbourne City FC,” the statement read.

Muscat has until 5pm on Thursday to make a submission and may face a reprimand, a fine and/or suspension.
