results.title: Turnbull accused of keeping a ‘bully’
results.subtitle: George Brandis under pressure to resign instead of Justin Gleeson
results.description: BILL Shorten has lashed out at Malcolm Turnbull for keeping “bully” Attorney-General George Brandis while the Solicitor-General was “tormented into resignation”.

thumbnailImage.title: Turnbull accused of keeping a ‘bully’
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 63ac32ae-9a69-11e6-ab69-22cb8f6501a3
thumbnailImage.description: Turnbull accused of keeping a ‘bully’

results.seoHeadline: George Brandis under pressure to resign instead of Solicitor-General Justin Gleeson
results.body:
Mr Shorten said Justin Gleeson’s resignation was “shameful, unprecedented, and ruthless”.

“Malcolm Turnbull is so weak, devoid of strength that he has had to keep his bullying Attorney General,” Mr Shorten said.

“Everyone knows this Attorney-General is an accident waiting to happen.”

The Opposition Leader also said Gleeson was pushed into resigning.

This comes as shadow attorney-general Mark Dreyfus said the government “shot the messenger” over Gleeson’s resignation as pressure mounts for Brandis to go.

Mr Dreyfus said Australians can no longer trust Mr Brandis over the way he treated Mr Gleeson.

He also said the Coalition has set out to attack people appointed by Labor.

“It has been regrettably the way in which this Government has operated, including the removal of secretaries of departments, the sacking of Paul Grimes, the attack on Gillian Triggs and now this Solicitor-General and there are other examples,” Mr Dreyfus said.

“This Government cannot take criticism.

“This government shoots the messenger every time.”

Paul Grimes announced in 2015 that his role as head of the agriculture department was terminated citing differences in direction with Barnaby Joyce.

Earlier Mr Dreyfus said he believed Senator Brandis should go.

“The wrong person has gone,” he told ABC radio. 

“How many more disasters do Australians have to endure before Malcolm Turnbull sacks 

this appalling attorney-general?

“Everything he touches turns to ashes.” 

Mr Dreyfus denied it was improper for him to call Mr Gleeson during the caretaker period before the recent election. 

He questioned what the country has come to when a member of parliament can’t ask the solicitor-general, or any other senior public servant, a few questions. 

Malcolm Turnbull is standing by Brandis amid the pressure for him to resign.

Australia’s second law officer decided his relationship with Senator Brandis was irretrievably broken following changes to his role and he could no longer serve in the position. 

Labor says Brandis should be the one to go instead of Gleeson because he “misled” parliament.

But the Prime Minister today stood by the AG.

“The solicitor-general has done the right thing ... and he’s resigned,” Mr Turnbull told ABC radio.

“I thank Justin Gleeson for his service as Solicitor-General and the Attorney-General is doing a very good job as well.

“It’s a pity the relationship broke down, but that does happen in other circumstances.” 

Senator Nick Xenophon also rejected calls for Brandis to be sacked.

“Essentially he stuffed up,” Mr Xenophon said.

“I don’t believe he misled the Senate. 

“I won’t be supporting a censure motion against the Attorney-General.” 

However, Mr Xenophon said there needs to be reform in how statutory officers are appointed. 

Labor MP Brendan O’Connor said Brandis was “a problem for the government”.

“The person who told the truth got sacked and the person who told lies is still there and that’s a problem for the government,” he told Sky News this morning.

Prominent lawyer Julian Burnside QC has echoed the opposition’s claim. 

“The person who should have gone was Brandis, I mean Justin Gleeson is a very fine lawyer, Brandis isn’t,” he told ABC Radio. 

Mr Burnside said he feared other lawyers of Mr Gleeson’s quality won’t want to replace him, if they are going to be overridden by Senator Brandis. 

“I suppose Justin Gleeson could have toughed it out,” he said.

“I think he did the honourable thing which puts him in marked contrast with the way Brandis behaved.” 

Senator Brandis said Mr Gleeson’s resignation was the proper course of action. He will step down on November 7. 

The top two government lawyers fronted a legal and constitutional affairs committee hearing in Canberra last week over allegations Senator Brandis failed to consult Mr Gleeson over a controversial new directive ruling that no-one in government, including the Prime Minister, could seek the Solicitor-General’s advice without first obtaining written permission.

Labor claimed Senator Brandis had “misled” Parliament by saying Mr Gleeson was on-board with the changes.
results.standFirst: BILL Shorten has lashed out at Malcolm Turnbull for keeping ‘bully’ Attorney-General George Brandis while the Solicitor-General was ‘tormented into resignation’.

results.title: Delisted Blue’s worst Photoshop ever
results.subtitle: Carlton delists six players including Andrejs Everitt, Mark Whiley
results.description: CARLTON has cut six players from its list including its leading goalkicker last year as the Blues continue their aggressive rebuild.

thumbnailImage.title: Delisted Blue’s worst Photoshop ever
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 62324ff0-9a67-11e6-a6cc-8bf57620ea71
thumbnailImage.description: Delisted Blue’s worst Photoshop ever

results.seoHeadline: Carlton delistings: Andrejs Everitt, Mark Whiley among six Blues players cut
results.body:
Andrejs Everitt, Dillon Viojo-Rainbow, Jason Tutt and Mark Whiley have all been told they won’t be offered contracts for next year.

DELISTINGS AND RETIREMENTS: ALL YOUR CLUB’S LIST CHANGES

Rookies Andrew Galluci and Billy Gowers have also been cut, although the pair will continue to train with the Blues in the hope of being picked up again in this year’s rookie draft.

Everitt has now been moved on from a third club after being traded from the Western Bulldogs to Sydney, and from the Swans to Carlton.

He has played 131 games in total and led the Blues’ goalkicking in 2015 with 31. He managed only 17 goals from 13 matches this year but that still placed him in the Blues’ top four behind Matthew Wright (22), Bryce Gibbs and Levi Casboult (both 18).

While many players have responded to their off-season moves with messages of support and gratitude on social media, Everitt instead posted a so-bad-it’s-funny Photoshop image of himself.

He captioned the image: “Went with the subtle blue number to convince the jury I’m still one of the Blues”.

Former teammate Cameron Wood replied: “S--- news, elite pic.”

Tutt played 40 career games including 14 for Carlton after being traded from the Bulldogs.

Whiley arrived at Carlton as part of a trade in 2014 with GWS that also netted Kristian Jaksch and pick 19 in the draft — used on Blaine Boekhorst — in return for pick 7. The Giants used the selection on Paul Ahern, traded last week to North Melbourne for pick 69 in this year’s draft.

Whiley played nine games in two seasons at the Blues for a career total of 21.

The moves bring to 13 the number of list changes at Ikon Park — and an incredible 28 over the past two seasons — following the retirements of Andrew Walker and Michael Jamison and trading Zach Tuohy to Geelong.

Carlton football manager Andrew McKay thanked the six delisted players for their service.

“Since arriving at the club all six players have been professional in their approach to their careers and have shown dedication and commitment in developing their football,” McKay said. 

“We sincerely thank them for their contribution to Carlton and wish them all the best for the future.”
results.standFirst: CARLTON has cut six players from its list and one has responded to the news with a so-bad-it’s-funny post on social media.

results.title: Eight Aussies step up for new NBA season
results.subtitle: NBA: Dellavedova, Bogut, Exum, Baynes, Mills headline big Aussie contingent for new season
results.description: BEN Simmons’ much-hyped NBA debut may have been torpedoed by a foot fracture, but with a record number of Australians in the NBA this season there’s plenty of other enticing storylines.

thumbnailImage.title: Eight Aussies step up for new NBA season
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 943f880e-9a4f-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: Eight Aussies step up for new NBA season

results.seoHeadline: 2016-17 NBA; Matthew Dellavedova; Andrew Bogut; Ben Simmons; Dante Exum; Aron Baynes; Patty Mills
results.body:
DELLY A LEADER OF YOUNG BUCKS

Can veteran big man Andrew Bogut stay healthy and make the Golden State Warriors regret shipping him off to the Dallas Mavericks to make space for superstar free agent Kevin Durant?

Is Matthew Dellavedova worth the $50 million the Milwaukee Bucks tossed at him?

Will Aron Baynes’ freshly broken nose and face mask, combined with his bushy ginger beard and samurai inspired, latte-making barista hipster dude man bun hairstyle give the Queenslander the title of fiercest-looking NBA enforcer (and maybe score him the role as the villain in the next 007 film)? 

The 2016-17 NBA season begins on Wednesday (EDT) with Patty Mills’ San Antonio Spurs taking on the Golden State Warriors, the Joe Ingles-Dante Exum Utah Jazz playing the Portland Trail Blazers and the reigning champion Cleveland Cavaliers against the retooled New York Knicks.

Bookmakers predict the Warriors and the Cavaliers will, for the third straight year, meet in the NBA Championship, with the San Francisco Bay area squad with four All-Stars in their starting five — Durant, Steph Curry, Draymond Green, and Klay Thompson — victorious.

Here’s how Australia’s record eight NBA players shape up.

BEN SIMMONS (Philadelphia 76ers)

Poor old Brett Brown, the former Australian Olympic coach who has suffered 199 losses and just 47 wins the past three seasons at the helm of the pitiful Philadelphia 76ers.

2016/17 was supposed to be the turning point for the 76ers, with the wretched 2015/16 season (72 losses, 10 wins) putting them in pole position to score their saviour — Simmons — as the No. 1 pick in this year’s draft.

Their top pick in 2014, 213cm tall Joel Embiid, has never played a regular season game for the 76ers because of a fractured foot, but he is fit and was expected to join forces with 20-year-old Simmons.

Nope. Simmons fractured his foot last month and he might not play until January and the 76ers, who apparently like to walk under ladders and hang out with black cats, announced this week their string bean shot-blocker Nerlens Noel needs knee surgery.

Bookmaker prediction: 76ers will be the NBA’s third worst team. 

Odds to win NBA title: 500/1 (only Brooklyn Nets and Phoenix Suns have longer odds) 

ANDREW BOGUT (Dallas Mavericks) 

Bogut, the 31-year-old, 11 NBA season veteran, has a lot at stake after the Warriors gave up on him and teammate Harrison Barnes to sign Durant. If Bogut and the Mavericks’ longtime star Dirk Nowitzki both stay healthy, they will likely make the playoffs and pose some problems for other Western Conference squads.

Bogut is at the end of his three-year, $47 million contract so if his creaky knees, ankles and back survive the season he will cash in with one last major deal.

Bookmakers: Expected to just miss playoffs.

Title odds: 100/1 

MATTHEW DELLAVEDOVA & THON MAKER (Milwaukee Bucks) 

Buckle up because the Bucks are going to be fun to watch with Aussie duo Dellavedova and 19-year-old, 216cm Maker joining forces with the athletic 211cm Giannis “Greek Freak” Antetokounmpo.

Opposing players might detest the scrappy Dellavedova, but he has never had an NBA coach (opposing coaches don’t count) who did not love him. With one of the highest great NBA point guards and current Bucks coach Jason Kidd pencilling Delly in to start at point guard (after expected starter Michael Carter-Williams was recently shipped off to the Chicago Bulls), Milwaukee looks like a great career move for the Victorian.

Maker is a work in progress, but the Bucks love his enthusiasm, work ethic and unlimited potential.

Bookmakers: Will just miss playoffs 

Title odds: 100/1 

PATTY MILLS (San Antonio Spurs)

It’s a big year for Canberra point guard Mills Coming off an exemplary Olympic campaign, this will be Mills’ eighth NBA season and the perfect opportunity to show he can be more than a reserve and fill the ageing shoes of Spurs’ veteran starter Tony Parker.

He is also on the final year of his three-year $17 million contract and will be looking to cash in with a Delly-sized deal.

As always, the Spurs are expected to be in the top two in the Western Conference and strong title chances.

For the first time in 19 seasons the Spurs will be without great big man Tim Duncan, but his retirement has been soothed by the signing of proven winner forward/centre Paul Gasol.

Bookmakers: Second in Western Conference 

Title odds: 8/1 

JOE INGLES & DANTE EXUM (Utah Jazz)

The Utah Jazz could be the surprise team of the NBA.

Exum is back after sitting out last season with a torn ACL and the team added veterans Boris Diaw, George Hill and Joe Johnson.

Ingles might be a bit bleary-eyed from 3am nappy changing duties with the arrival of twins Jacob and Milla, but bookmakers and shrewd NBA analysts believe the Jazz will not only end their playoff drought but achieve a respectable playoff position in the stacked Western Conference.

Bookmakers: 5th to 8th playoff position.

Title odds: 50/1 

ARON BAYNES (Detroit Pistons) 

The burly Queenslander Baynes arrived in Detroit last season on an eyebrow-raising three-year $25.5 million deal, but he proved his worth as a key backup to starting centre Andre Drummond.

It helps Baynes can shoot free throws, with Drummond (shooting an historically bad 35.5 per cent last season) targeted with hack-a-Drummond in the final minutes of games.

Pistons coach Stan Van Gundy has enough confidence to toss Baynes, who also had a great Rio Olympics, in when the game is on the line.

Baynes did break his nose in a pre-season game last week, but after surgery he is expected to play in the Pistons’ opener.

Bookmakers: Just miss playoffs 

Title odds: 100/1
results.standFirst: CAN Andrew Bogut stay healthy? Is Matthew Dellavedova worth $50m? Will Patty Mills step up? There are plenty of enticing Aussie storylines in the NBA this year.

results.title: Hockey hits taxpayers for babysitters
results.subtitle: US ambassador Joe Hockey bills Australian taxpayers for babysitters
results.description: JOE Hockey, who once declared that the “age of entitlement” was over, has billed taxpayers thousands of dollars for babysitters to mind his three children, despite earning almost half a million dollars a year.

thumbnailImage.title: Hockey hits taxpayers for babysitters
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 99c962fa-9a67-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: Hockey hits taxpayers for babysitters

results.body:
As the Coalition moves to end so-called “double dipping” — where new mums receive taxpayer-funded parental leave at the same time to employer-provided payments — Mr Hockey has run up a $2500 bill for child minding in just his first few months as US ambassador.

The babysitting bill is revealed in Government documents released under Freedom of Information which detail the annual expenditure for the head of Mission in Washington D.C. in the 2014-15 and 2015-16 financial years.

The Former treasurer who delivered the infamous 2014 slash-and-burn budget moved to Washington in January with his wife and three children for his new role.

In the 2015-16 financial year, Mr Hockey and former US ambassador Kim Beazley charged taxpayers more than $120,000 to wine and dine guests.

Mr Hockey, who earns more than $360,000 a year as ambassador and has access to an annual pension worth almost $100,000 also billed taxpayers thousands of dollars to restock the cellar and for decorative flowers.

The latest figures come just months after the Herald Sun revealed Mr Hockey had charged taxpayers $8500 to spruce up his palatial Washington home after staff reported there was “no space available” for him to host visitors.

Earlier this year the Hockeys’ also advertised for a new ­housekeeper in Washington to “prepare and serve meals for members of the family and their guests”.

The position cames with a taxpayer-funded salary of $45,750.

It is believed Mr Hockey is renting out his multimillion-dollar, six-bedroom family home in the Sydney suburb of Hunters Hill.

More to come
results.standFirst: JOE Hockey, who once declared that the “age of entitlement” was over, has billed taxpayers thousands of dollars for babysitters to mind his three children, despite earning almost half a million dollars a year.

results.title: Young thug struggling in adult jail
results.subtitle: Young thug doesn’t like adult jail, Melbourne court told
results.description: A LYING thug has complained he doesn’t like it in an adult jail and wants out.
results.subscriptionSummary:
A LYING thug has complained he doesn’t like it in an adult jail and wants out. 
 Mursal Biel complained he’d watched a bloke severely bashed while awaiting sentence in Port Phillip prison over a series of terrifying armed robberies.

thumbnailImage.title: Young thug struggling in adult jail
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 54bff124-9a62-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: Young thug struggling in adult jail
thumbnailImage.imageName: Hands grip bars of a prison cell. Thinkstock.

results.body:
Mursal Biel complained he’d watched a bloke severely bashed while awaiting sentence in Port Phillip prison over a series of terrifying armed robberies.

But the cowardly 18-year old may yet get his wish, with County Court Judge Felicity Hampel considering his plea.

Biel faces up to 25-years behind bars after pleading guilty to a series of armed robberies against unsuspecting citizens.

The court heard Biel and two others who were dealt with in the Children’s Court embarked on a crime rampage across Melbourne on April 10 last year.

Driving about in a stolen ex-taxi, Biel and his mates attacked random strangers, bashing them with an extendible baton and stealing their phones and cash.

One man was robbed in Southbank and another two in Richmond.

In each of the attacks, the goons approached passers-by and asked for their phones before robbing them.

One man was struck in the head before being kicked while another was ruthlessly beaten in his own car.

The thugs told the man they would track him down and kill him if he went to police and later used his bank cards to withdraw cash.

The brazen bandits were captured on CCTV using the cards at Chadstone, but the unrepentant Biel denied he was involved.

He eventually ratted on his mates to police while attempting to minimise his involvement in the crimes.

In Biel’s defence, barrister Caitlin Blakeney said her young client found he preferred to go out socialising than doing schoolwork.

She said Biel migrated to Australia from Sudan and picked up an ice habit in 2014.

His habit turned into an addiction, which she claimed was aided by good-willed drug fiends, who freely handed-over drugs to Biel.

Ms Blakeney told the court her client had a borderline mental impairment and was struggling to cope in an adult jail.

Biel has been locked-up since committing the offences.

She said Biel had been bullied in jail and witnessed an inmate cop a severe beating.

Crown prosecutors did not object to Biel being assessed for juvenile detention.

He will be sentenced on November 22.

wayne.flower@news.com.au
results.standFirst: A LYING thug has complained he doesn’t like it in an adult jail and wants out.

results.title: New law to seize and crush monkey bikes
results.subtitle: Premier Daniel Andrews to introduce new laws in state parliament to crush monkey bikes
results.description: MONKEY bikes used on public roads will be seized and crushed by police under tough new powers introduced by the State Government.
results.subscriptionSummary: MONKEY bikes used on public roads will be seized and crushed by police under tough new powers introduced by the State Government.

thumbnailImage.title: New law to seize and crush monkey bikes
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 880d4104-9a39-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: New law to seize and crush monkey bikes

results.body:
Premier Daniel Andrews announced the crackdown on the “wretched” miniature motorbikes this morning and will introduce laws to Parliament today to help police take them off the road.

Assistant Commissioner Doug Fryer said the dangerous vehicles were not allowed on public roads and that police were sick of youths harassing people while riding them.

It comes after Carrum mum Andrea Lehane was hit and killed by a teenager riding a monkey bike in a shopping centre last year.

“The Lehane family today still grieve the loss of somebody so close to them, the tragic death ... all of us I think were touched by, at the hands of one of these miniature motorcycles,” Mr Andrews said.

Under the new laws, monkey bike riders who are caught on the roads by police will be taken to court, charged with a new specific offence that carries a fine of up to $3109.

The bike can also be impounded and crushed.

“These are exactly the laws that Victoria Police have asked for when it comes to dealing with the menace of monkey bikes on our roadways,” Mr Andrews said.

Mr Fryer said the changes would help police keep the streets safe.

“Kids might think it’s good fun, we know that this causes serious injury and it can cause death and we’ve seen that,” he said.

“Our streets are not for monkey bikes ... They’re dangerous little motorised vehicles that can cause death.”

Police received about 6000 calls about people riding monkey bikes last year.

tom.minear@news.com.au
results.standFirst: MONKEY bikes used on public roads will be seized and crushed by police under tough new powers introduced by the State Government.

results.title: PM’s $600m South Yarra rail ultimatum
results.subtitle: Turnbull Government makes $600m South Yarra railway station ultimatum
results.description: THE State Government is refusing to add a new South Yarra station to the Melbourne Metro tunnel project, despite moves by the Federal Government to send Victoria $600 million to pay for it.
results.subscriptionSummary: THE Turnbull Government is threatening to pay $600 million that is owed to Victoria only if South Yarra railway station is included in the Melbourne Metro Rail Project.

thumbnailImage.title: PM’s $600m South Yarra rail ultimatum
thumbnailImage.subtitle: e8a9f44c-99cd-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: PM’s $600m South Yarra rail ultimatum

results.seoHeadline: South Yarra railway station Melbourne Metro ultimatum made by Turnbull Government
results.body:
The Turnbull Government is threatening to pay the money that is owed to Victoria only if South Yarra railway station is included.

The $10.9 billion Melbourne Metro does not currently include plans for a stop at South Yarra, despite proposed new rail lines passing within 80 metres of the station.

The State Government says it would cost too much.

This morning Public Transport Minister Jacinta Allan said the South Yarra extension did not stack up financially and would only provide a minimal return on investment.

She said the potential federal offer was simply about saving Liberal MP Kelly O’Dwyer in the seat of Higgins, and accused the Turnbull Government of playing politics with money that was owed to Victoria.

Victoria is in a standoff with Canberra over a bonus owed the state under the federal Asset Recycling Initiative for the Port of Melbourne sale.

The Andrews Government argues that under the original terms of the federal scheme, Victoria should receive $1.45 billion — 15 per cent of the $9.7 billion the state will get from selling the port.

The Commonwealth has agreed in principle to give Victoria $877 million.

But it is now debating whether to offer the rest only if a new South Yarra station is linked to the Metro project.

The push to tie the $600 million to South Yarra is being led by Assistant Treasurer Kelly O’Dwyer, whose seat of Higgins takes in the station and who has been a vocal critic of its omission. 

Senior federal Victorian Liberals are understood to have told Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull it would be unacceptable for the state to get only $877 million, and that the matter needs to be resolved as quickly as possible. 

Victoria has rejected attempts by Canberra to dictate what the cash is spent on.

Treasurer Tim Pallas said in June that any money from the Asset Recycling Initiative would go towards removing more level crossings. 

The standoff comes as the Andrews Government argues Victoria is only getting 9c in every infrastructure dollar Canberra currently spends.

A senior federal Victorian Liberal called the construction of Melbourne Metro is “a once in a generation project”.

 The source said the project passes within 80 metres of South Yarra station, and “if South Yarra station isn’t connected to the Melbourne Metro, the millions of commuters who use the Frankston, Cranbourne, Pakenham and Sandringham lines will be worse off.”

Chapel Street Precinct Association president John Lotton said an estimated 30,000 people passed through the station every day, despite the State Government’s estimate of closer to 24,000. “South Yarra station (is) the second busiest train station in Victoria, after Flinders Street station, in the mornings,” he said.

“We need the Metro Rail to link to the second busiest station, and it doesn’t make sense that Metro Rail will come within 100m of the station.

“We have Kelly O’Dwyer offering federal government funds, but we have a State Government refusing to say whether they are going to stump up the cash.

“The core issue is about the substantial increase of the population in the area. It’s a considerable issue for a government which continues to grant permits for high-rises in the area, increasing the local population, but refuses to include South Yarra in upgrade plans,” Mr Lotton said.

“Commuters are sick of seeing several trains, chocker block, in the morning, having to bypass South Yarra without stopping, because they’re too full for people to get on.”

james.campbell@news.com.au

MELBOURNE METRO CREATIVE CONSULTANTS TO CASH IN ON PROJECT’S ‘LOOK AND FEEL’

results.seoHeadline: Best bottles of champagne and sparkling
results.body:
The weather is turning for the better and so is our desire for the fun things in life — and when it comes to a little something to kickstart a great event, nothing beats the pop of a cork and the froth and bubble of a great little sparkler.

From now until the New Year, we drink way more fizz than the rest of the calendar as the great annual celebrations dominate our diaries. 

The rise and rise of Australian sparklings as Tasmania gains increasing kudos as an elite source is a heartening domestic trend. 

Other cooler-climate areas also can’t be denied — think the Yarra Valley in Victoria and the Adelaide Hills. 

Larger wine companies have excellent programs for sparklings, arguably one of the most complex of all wines to create with intricate blending processes and many years of bottle maturation required to attain the best expressions.

And then there are the French. Australia is the seventh largest champagne market in the world, growing threefold since 2009. We obviously love the sense of luxury that the Champagne region brings to a bottle of celebratory wine. 

The best thing about a great bottle of fizz is that it can be enjoyed in so many ways.

It’s a party-starter, a romance, a special occasion highlight, and also a fabulous dining companion across just about any food style you can imagine. 

Here’s a selection across many price points for you to get the season off to a cracking start.

Yellowglen Yellow Brut Cuvee

$13

Region: Various

Value: Good

Best with: Sunny daytime party

***1/2 

Champagne fanciers might turn up their noses, but this little crowd pleaser does a mighty fine job at its price. It’s crisp and clean with lemon sherbet senses, the bubbles are fine, and even a little maturation adds light pith in its mouthfeel. Super easy to splash around, it’s smartly balanced between sweeter flavours and refreshing acidity. You can also find it in a gold bottle these days. 

Yarra Burn Vintage 2013

$25

Region: Yarra Valley

Value: Attractive

Best with: Stronger cheeses

**** 

One of the key producers under the excellent Accolade Wines bubbles program directed by master sparkler Ed Carr, this single region, single vintage expression reflects the fuller flavoured YB house style. This certainly shows in the turn of power and depth in the palate here, the fruit spectrum varying from citrus, pear and apple with a creamy mouthfeel and after two years maturation in the bottle a nice little yeast bun complexity. 

Yarrabank Crème de Cuvee NV

$30

Region: Yarra Valley

Value: Sweet

Best with: Strawberry tartlets 

****1/2

The colour immediately sets the mood — the producers call it “strawberry blonde” yet there’s a surprise here, it’s delicately sweeter in style with the palate suggesting fruit ripeness rather than honey while retaining its acidity and freshness. The balancing act is not surprising given it’s a collaboration between Yering Station and French Champagne house Devaux. Think of it more for desserts. 

Bay of Fires Pinot Noir Chardonnay Brut

$35

Region: Tasmania

Value: Cool

Best with: Sashimi

****1/2

Another from the Accolade program and also benefiting from being sourced across several of the exciting regions of Tasmania. There’s no shirking here — this is a fully expressive style, cast in a mid-rich spectrum, showing a light note of honey drizzled over apple in the initial aromatic and flavour senses. Move on through and with four years maturation in the bottle on the yeast lees, a technique that defines all the best fizzes, you see more complexity, woody herbs and florals and a lovely lemon sherbet finish. 

Coldstream Hills 2013 Pinot Noir Chardonnay

$35

Region: Yarra Valley

Value: Dependable

Best with: Cocktail party

****1/2

A consistently excellent Yarra based sparkling, this vintage finds its place in the fresher, more aperitif spectrum to begin, before all the complexities of better sparkling techniques mesh together so you come across yeast, polish, zest and pith from various citrus, superfine bubbles and mouth-watering yet harmonious acidity — all sorts of goodness and joy and with enough layering to be a solid dining companion too.

Arras Brut Elite Cuvee No. 901

$50

Region: Tasmania

Value: Top class

Best with: Your best friend

*****

The House of Arras leads the way in Australian sparkling wines, this core of the range up to super-elite vintage styles equal to anything the best of France can make. The “901” cuvee number indicates a dominant 2009 vintage component and thus five years bottle ferment and maturation time to encourage engaging yeasty complexity with amazing freshness. Subtle, salivating with crunchy apple and pear flavours. Very smart. 

Bromley by Wolf Blass pinot noir Chardonnay NV

$30 

Region: Adelaide Hills

Value: Stylish

Best with: Browned butter scallops

**** 

You might think this is mostly about the packaging — the label a bright bird and butterfly artwork by popular painter David Bromley — but the wine itself is beyond all that, fresh and zesty with lemon peel and juice, perhaps a slice of grapefruit too to enhance its mouth-watering appeal. Then look again and three years bottle maturation also has added depth in a lemon butter and bun character. Yum.

Chandon Altius Vintage 2012 

$59

Region: Yarra Valley

Value: Cellar special

Best with: Finest seafoods

****1/2

The Chandon house has plenty of sparkling options and this is a cellar door style only, so if you’re in the Yarra region, drop in and get one. Specifically noting cooler terroir Upper Yarra fruit, you’ll see it in a delightful chardonnay/ pinot noir duet that begins with a distinctive mature, yeasty note — a plus in sparkling appreciation — then excellent palate precision: pithy, lemons, crisp apples, with a fine mousse and bubbles. Excellent. 

Jacquart Brut Mosaic NV

$70

Region: Champagne, France

Value: Terrific

Best with: Morning tea

**** 

This Champagne house drives its cuvee with a serious component of chardonnay, so its delicacy is a feature as well as its fresher fruit notes that tend more towards the pear spectrum of flavours with some orange florals as well. It’s juicy and refreshing with easy going popular styling, yet also will please aficionados with five years on lees resulting in some baked yeast and honey bun complexity too. 

Mumm Cordon Rouge NV

$70

Region: Champagne, France

Value: Discounted well

Best with: A happy crowd

**** 

This regular Mumm is one of the best introductions to the world of Champagne as it’s such an smoothly crafted expression of the style, the depth of its 45 per cent pinot noir balanced supremely with a more subtle 30 per cent chardonnay, opening with wafts of cut orange and mandarin peel, those fragrant citrus notes continuing and lifted with fine bubbles. Pleasing, easy going, and often heavily discounted.

Bollinger Special Cuvee NV

$80

Region: Champagne, France

Value: Why not

Best with: Party crowd

****1/2

The name of course conjures plenty of fun-filled moments as well as James Bond imagery, and the wine itself is a classic expression of the three Champagne varieties with 85 per cent grand and premier cru components. It’s fresh and floral to start with a subtle polish in the background. A core of sweet fruit like compote apples drives the flavour notes before a long dry finish with lemon gelati impressions. 

Pol Roger Pure NV

$125

Region: Champagne France

Value: Rare

Best with: Oysters, natural

****1/2

This palate teasing style is definitely not for every taste — very much an aperitif with what’s known as “zero dosage” of liqueuring in its final stages of production so the wine’s acidity has been left to do the talking. The result: green apple crunch and bite, super fresh palate edge, with a pithy and minerally finish. There’s not too much of it around but worth looking out for if that’s your thing. 

@TonyLoveTaste

results.title: Would you ask Usain Bolt to run 1500m?
results.subtitle: Winx running at Stakes Day would be like asking Usain Bolt to run the 1500m, says Chris Waller
results.description: CHRIS Waller has provided further explanation about his decision to end Winx’s Spring Carnival campaign early likening the champion mare to Usain Bolt.

thumbnailImage.title: Would you ask Usain Bolt to run 1500m?
thumbnailImage.subtitle: d4909068-9a5b-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: Would you ask Usain Bolt to run 1500m?
thumbnailImage.imageName: TOPSHOT - Gold medallist Usain Bolt stands on the

results.seoHeadline: Usain Bolt v Winx: Melbourne Cup and Spring Carnival
results.body:
Following her sensational Cox Plate victory at the weekend, Waller confirmed Winx will go for a spell immediately and would not run in the Group 1 $2 million Emirates Stakes (2000m) at Flemington on November 5 in order to be set for a Sydney autumn campaign.

“(Asking her to run) it’s like asking Usain Bolt to run, I wouldn’t say a marathon, but the 1500m,” he told reporters at Flemington.

“It calls on different resources from a horse, they’re under pressure at different stages, their bodies are set up differently.

“We might have missed the boat with Winx (to race both). You could have probably done it last year, but she was only a shadow of what she’s at now.”

Bolt is the talk of the town in Melbourne after it was confirmed the nine-time Olympic gold medallist will be trackside at Flemington during the Melbourne Cup Carnival and will be a guest of Crown Melbourne, appearing in their marquee on Oaks Day, November 3.

“It will be my first time to attend this type of event. I hear it is the place to be in Melbourne in November and people like to dress up,” Bolt said last week.

Winx extended her winning streak to 13 when she won the Cox Plate by a staggering eight lengths — the biggest margin ever in the race — and lifted her prizemoney to $9.34 million to be third on the all-time list of leading prizemoney earners.

Winx’s next main target is likely to be the $4 million Queen Elizabeth Stakes (2000m) at Royal Randwick during The Championships but she is expected to return to racing in February.
results.standFirst: CHRIS Waller has provided further explanation about his decision to end Winx’s Spring Carnival campaign early likening the champion mare to Usain Bolt.

results.title: Prison rioter to spend extra year behind bars
results.subtitle: Melbourne Remand Centre riots: First prisoner sentenced to spend extra year behind bars
results.description: THE first prisoner to be sentenced over the violent prison riots that left a $12 million clean-up bill will spend an extra year behind bars.
results.subscriptionSummary: THE first prisoner to be sentenced over the violent prison riots that left a $12 million clean-up bill will spend an extra year behind bars.

thumbnailImage.title: Prison rioter to spend extra year behind bars
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 8f97d816-99a9-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: Prison rioter to spend extra year behind bars

results.body:
Jonathon Luca, 22, was on remand for a string of offending including beating a woman with a pole when he enthusiastically took part in the 15-hour Ravenhall rampage.

He was later sentenced to 42 months’ imprisonment, and ordered to serve at least two years of that term, for that offending.

Today, in a sign that the rioters wouldn’t be dealt with lightly, County Court chief judge Peter Kidd sentenced Luca to another two years and five months.

The Chief Judge ordered that 21 months of Luca’s latest sentence be added to a term he is already serving.

A new 18-month non-parole period, that starts today, means for all his offending Luca must spend a total of three years behind bars.

“The courts cannot permit the law of the jungle to take hold in prisons,” Chief Judge Kidd told him.

“The riot had a major impact on the staff at the MRC (Metropolitan Remand Centre),” he said

“It has affected the way they now interact with the prisoners on a day-to-day basis.”

Up to 300 people were involved in the wild prison brawl, the largest in Victorian history, but just 102 have been charged.

Luca was the first to plead guilty to his involvement in the violent protest that erupted over a looming smoking ban in Victorian correctional facilities.

Hundreds of prisoners came close to breaking free from Melbourne’s Metropolitan Remand Centre as fearful prison staff fled for their safety.

Prisoners stormed the centre’s gatehouse and control centre, crashed through fences with vehicles, lit fires and attacked guards.

They also ransacked the prison’s canteen and used allen keys to free prisoners from their cells.

In a letter to a friend in the wake of the riot Luca bragged that “the whole joint is smashed to bits. We got the allen keys from maintenance and got all the people out from the slot.”

Luca pleaded guilty to a single count of riot.

Judge Kidd said his youth was a significant mitigating factor because of his potential for rehabilitation.

shannon.deery@news.com.au
results.standFirst: THE first prisoner to be sentenced over the violent prison riots that left a $12 million clean-up bill will spend an extra year behind bars.

results.title: Delly a leader of young Bucks
results.subtitle: Matthew Dellavedova opens up on the Bucks, Boomers, Cavs, life and love ahead of his Milwaukee debut
results.description: MATTHEW Dellavedova says he’s gone from being “a younger guy on an old team, to an older guy on a younger team” as he gears up for his Milwaukee Bucks debut.
results.subscriptionSummary:
MATTHEW Dellavedova says he’s gone from being “a younger guy on an old team, to an older guy on a younger team” as he gears up for his Milwaukee Bucks debut. 
 The Australian Boomer confirmed he will be in the Bucks’ starting line-up when the Charlotte Hornets visit the Bradley Center on Thursday.

thumbnailImage.title: Delly a leader of young Bucks
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 79dce00c-9990-11e6-8115-b332b3c612c3
thumbnailImage.description: Delly a leader of young Bucks

results.seoHeadline: Matthew Dellavedova Milwaukee Bucks NBA debut: Delly on Bucks, Boomers, Cavs, life and love, Cleveland
results.body:
The Australian Boomer confirmed he will be in the Bucks’ starting line-up when the Charlotte Hornets visit the Bradley Center on Thursday.

LIVE BLOG: Bogut, Delly make NBA debuts with new clubs

Dellavedova joined a talent-laden Milwaukee roster on a massive four year, $US38 million deal in the off-season, after winning the title with Lebron James and the Cleveland Cavaliers.

And his new club has given him a huge vote of confidence after it traded his main rival for the starting spot, Michael Carter-Williams to the Chicago Bulls.

MORE: Matthew Dellavedova’s tennis playing cousin is named Matthew Dellavedova

While the Bucks have a young, multi-talented star in Giannis Antetokounmpo leading the way and third-year big man Jabari Parker, he’s joined a side that is still finding its way in the NBA, having missed the playoffs last season.

“We’ve only had six preseason games, so it’s still pretty early on, but Giannis obviously is an amazing talent and he really has no limit on how good he can be,” Dellavedova said.

“I’m here to fit in with him and just try to help him become as good as he can be.”

And he says it is his job to help his teammates improve, with the goal of make it back to the postseason — even without injured marksman Khris Middleton.

“The feeling is we have to get back into the playoffs and then go from there,” Dellavedova said.

“You have to take it step by step, but the first thing is getting back in the playoffs and then I think we reset our goals and talk about what we want to do next after that.

MORE: Delly on Pat Beverley toughness questions

“It’s something we’ve talked about in training camp and it’s great to have big goals, but you need to know how you’re going to get there.”

Dellavedova’s first task in a deer emblem will be to curtail Hornets’ jet Kemba Walker.

And he says he knows he will need the help of his teammates to keep the high-scoring guard in check.

MORE: Title win still sinking in: Delly

“He’s pretty tough to cover, he’s very quick and crafty with the ball and a good shooter as well,” he said.

“We’re going to be a defensive team and that’s where our strength is and our athleticism and getting out and running.

“So every night we have to do it on the defensive end and that’s where it begins with us.”

Dellavedova says he has warmed to Bucks NBA journeyman Steve Novak, who attended local Marquette University.

MORE: Why we’re looking forward to the NBA season

“He’s the local guy here ... so he’s been showing me around Milwaukee,” Dellavedova said.

“He knows (Boomer’s teammate and Utah Jazz forward) Joey Ingles and Joey said he was a good bloke, which was true, so it’s good.”

He says coming back from 3-1 down to win the NBA title against Golden State last season after losing to the Warriors in 2015 was one of his greatest career highlights.

“It’s a marathon of a season and to come up short the year before after being so close was really disappointing and then just to get back there again and have the chance to compete for the title and get it done was pretty awesome,” he said.

While his focus is on the Bucks, Dellavedova says the Boomers’ bronze medal game capitulation against Spain at the Olympics still stings — and that means Tokyo 2020 is always in the back of his mind.

“It’s still a tough one to digest how it all ended, but that was as fun a group as I’ve been a part of,” he said.

“Just how close everybody was, all that mattered was the team, which is how it is in Australian sport.

“Everybody is fully committed to the Boomers program and wants to do something special for Australia, but, unfortunately, we couldn’t finish off the job in Rio and it's a disappointing one that’s going to sting for a long time.

“But that’s what happens in sport sometimes and hopefully we can regroup and go better in 2020.”

He desperately wants the NBL to succeed and says his Aussie NBA brethren follow the competition from afar.

“I think all of us over here follow the NBL and want it to do really well and it looks like it’s definitely heading in the right direction,” he said.

He’s torn between his home state club, Melbourne United, and the reincarnated Brisbane Bullets, when it comes to support.

“I definitely want United to do well, obviously, being a Victorian, but my best mate (Mitch Young) plays with Brisbane, so I’ve been following them pretty closely this year as well,” he said.

The pair spent three years at the Australian Institute of Sport and then four years at US college St Mary’s as roommates.

He still heads back to St Mary’s every off season.

“I follow them and still talk to the coaches and always drop in before and after the season to catch up with everybody,” he said.

Dellavedova says while he’s not a big-spender, the big money deal has allowed him to buy his first house, which gives him a base, “rather than living out of a suitcase”.

It’s been the year of dreams for Delly.

He has an NBA title, a big money deal, a starting role — and a new fiancee.

He popped the question to his college sweetheart Anna Schroeder in the off season.

“(It’s) definitely exciting times,” he said.

“I had a bit of a plan and it worked out pretty well, and it was something you would never forget for sure.”

When asked to elaborate on his plan, he just laughed.

“I’ll probably keep that one a secret, but it was very romantic,” he said.

Let’s hope the romantic from Maryborough’s dream run can continue this NBA season.

The NBA season tips off on Wednesday with a triple header featuring the new-look New York Knicks up against James and the Cavs, the Utah Jazz taking on the Portland Trailblazers and the post-Tim Duncan era San Antonio Spurs visiting the Golden State Warriors’ super team in Oakland.

Delly’s Bucks take on the Hornets on Thursday from 11am, while Aussie centre Andrew Bogut’s debut with the Dallas Mavericks (against Indiana) is an hour earlier at 10am.

*All times AEDT
results.standFirst: MATTHEW Dellavedova says he’s gone from being “a younger guy on an old team, to an older guy on a younger team”, as he gears up for his Milwaukee Bucks debut.

results.title: Best-kept secrets of Victoria’s west
results.subtitle: Victoria’s hidden gems: Best-kept secrets of our state’s west
results.description: VICTORIA’S west has everything from a stunning coastline to incredible inland sand dunes, from amazing art to fabulous wines.
results.subscriptionSummary: VICTORIA’S west has everything from a stunning coastline to incredible inland sand dunes, from amazing art to fabulous wines. Here’s the hidden gems of Victoria’s diverse west.

thumbnailImage.title: Best-kept secrets of Victoria’s west
thumbnailImage.subtitle: f35f57ae-99b1-11e6-ab69-22cb8f6501a3
thumbnailImage.description: Best-kept secrets of Victoria’s west

results.seoHeadline: Victoria’s hidden gems: Best-kept secrets of Victoria’s west to visit, eat, explore
results.body:
Here’s the hidden gems of Victoria’s diverse west.

harrow.org.au

Is Harrow the oldest inland settlement in Victoria? The locals — and there are 100 of them — reckon it is. 

One thing’s for sure: this quaint spot in the Wimmera, overlooking the Glenelg River Valley, 

is on a new list of the “most irresistible, historic and postcard-worthy small towns in Australia’’. 

Look around and you can see why. 

Harrow’s hotel and general store laid their foundations in the 1840s and are still in use today. The town — straddling sheep and crop country — also fields a footy team, hosts a billycart championship and stages monthly “Harrow By Night” light and sound shows from September to March. 

The Grampians. parkweb.vic.gov.au

Rock climbing is a big drawcard in the Gariwerd-Grampians National Park, but not everything 

here comes with an altitude. 

For a less strenuous experience, seek out the indigenous rock art sites that abound in the park’s rocky uplands. These “shelters” are where Aboriginal people camped and painted images of their life and law on sandstone walls, and Ngamadjidj, a secluded waterhole on the Grampians’ western edge, are unusual for being made with white clay. 

All the sites — not far from Halls Gap — are easily accessible and protected. 

Wyperfeld National Park, near Patchewollock.

parkweb.vic.gov.au

“Snow Drift” perfectly describes one of Victoria’s little-known natural marvels — a complex of towering, blindingly-white sand dunes in the Wyperfeld National Park, near Patchewollock, 

450km northwest of Melbourne. 

Smack-bang in the middle of an archetypal dusty, red Mallee landscape, the naturally-occurring dunes are accessible by car. Sand surfing — flying down the face of the dunes on boogie boards or even Esky lids — is the No. 1 attraction. 

The dunes were formed between 15,000 and 40,000 years ago, after the shallow sea that covered much of northwest Victoria receded. 

The area has unpowered camp sites, toilets and picnic tables.

107 Brown St, Hamilton. hamiltongallery.org

Every regional Victorian gallery has a special focus. At Hamilton Art Gallery, decorative art is the drawcard, thanks to Herbert and May Shaw who bequeathed the museum their rare 800-piece collection of 18th and 19th-century European silver, glass and porcelain. 

Asia has been also been a gallery priority, especially Chinese ceramics, and this summer Chinese-Australian artist Ah Xian enjoys an exhibition (from November 5). 

19 Sackville St, Port Fairy. wishartgallery.com.au

For some divine inspiration, pull into Glenthompson on your way through the Western District and inspect the murals inside the town’s Anglican Church. Artist Gareth Colliton decorated its walls three years ago, depicting some of the townsfolk in Biblical scenes. 

Travel south to Port Fairy and you will find Colliton — and his brothers Rhys, Bruach and Alasdair — at Wishart Gallery, Cafe and Bar. Housed in a recently refurbished heritage building, Wishart is home to art, antiques, food and a big outdoor beer garden. 

98 Parker St, Dunkeld. royalmail.com.au

Chefs at the Royal Mail Hotel in Dunkeld are always in the thick of it, returning with armfuls of fruit, vegetables and herbs. But their 1.2ha organic kitchen garden — Australia’s biggest — is open to house guests as well. Gardener Michelle Shanahan leads weekday tours. Over spring and summer, Grampians visitors can enrol in Royal Mail’s Sunday kitchen garden workshops. It’s part of a premium package ($795 per couple), which includes a gardener’s afternoon tea, dinner, overnight accommodation, breakfast and take home plantings. 

271 Pierrepoint Rd, Tarrington. pierrepointwines.com.au

Out in the Henty region, near Hamilton, the volcanic soil is good for planting pinot and chardonnay but tasting the fruits of Western District winemaking can be tricky when many cellar doors are by appointment only. That makes Pierrepoint Wines a special find. Lodged in the hills around Tarrington, west of Dunkeld, this vineyard is “open most days’’ from 11am to 6pm and you’re bound to meet owners Andrew or Jennifer Lacey. Between yarns, taste their award-winning wines, hear some live music and — if you’re overnighting — bunk down in one of the bed and breakfast rooms. 

21 Thistle Place, Port Fairy. www.timeandtidehightea.com.au

Waves are always crashing and the pot is always full 

at Time and Tide Gallery Cafe. This coastal eatery, overlooking the Southern Ocean near Port Fairy, serves afternoon tea on Saturdays and Sundays ($59). And owners Stephen and Philippa Hocking present their finger sandwiches, savoury pastries and petite treats with old-world charm.

Cape Bridgewater. sealsbyseatours.com.au

Ever wanted to go snorkelling with seals? 

You can do it off Cape Bridgewater on Victoria’s southwest coast. Seals by Sea Tours, in Portland, have long hosted Zodiac cruises out to Seal Point, home to 1200 Australian and New Zealand fur seals. But a new attraction allows visitors to jump into a dive cage moored off Bridgewater and caper with the creatures for about 90 minutes (adults $60, children $30). 

97 Martin St, corner Sterling St, Dunkeld. dunkeldoldbakery.com.au

Waking up to the aromas of just-baked bread ... that romantic notion is closer than you think if you stay at Dunkeld Old Bakery. The Scotch oven in this building has been in service since 1887 and under owners Iwona and Harry Wakeling, it is still turning out sourdough loaves, gourmet pies and country cakes. Two rooms 

in the “Baker’s House” are so close to the bakery cafe, you’re sure to be first in line for Harry’s morning bake. 

2810 Hamilton Hwy, Darlington. elephantbridgehotel.com.au

Old hands reckon it got its name from a circus that once crisscrossed the Western District. New owners of the Elephant Bridge Hotel cannot swear to that. But in reopening this classic bluestone pub on the Hamilton Highway at Darlington, they are putting an end to a period when circuses — and tourists — passed it by. “We’re offering boutique accommodation very soon,’’ says proprietor Karin Blomquist. Meanwhile, call into the hotel (c. 1842) for all-day cafe grazing, a “hunter gatherer’’ menu in the dining room, and local wines in the bar. 

A history of Melbourne
