results.title: Barnaby slammed in secret letter
results.subtitle: Barnaby Joyce criticised in letter from chief agriculture bureaucrat
results.description: DEPUTY Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce’s integrity has been questioned in a blistering letter from his chief bureaucrat, which department officials have finally revealed after an 18-month fight to keep it secret.
results.subscriptionSummary:
DEPUTY Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce’s integrity has been questioned in a blistering letter from his chief bureaucrat, which department officials have finally revealed after an 18-month fight to keep it secret. 
 The Herald Sun has obtained the letter written by former secretary of the Agriculture Department, Paul Grimes, who was sacked after firing off the furious missive to his boss back in 2015.

thumbnailImage.title: Barnaby slammed in secret letter
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 1e4a2fac-99b2-11e6-ab69-22cb8f6501a3
thumbnailImage.description: Barnaby slammed in secret letter

results.body:
The Herald Sun has obtained the letter written by former secretary of the Agriculture Department, Paul Grimes, who was sacked after firing off the furious missive to his boss back in 2015.

The letter was released after a lengthy legal fight between the Herald Sun and the Agriculture Department, which last week abandoned efforts in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to block its release.

Dr Grimes tells Mr Joyce he “no longer has confidence in my capacity to resolve matters relating to integrity with you.’’

He writes that he has come to the realisation following the events “before and following the alterations to Hansard that were made in October 2014.’’

His comments relate to Mr Joyce’s staff getting the official Parliamentary record, Hansard, changed in a way that disguised an incorrect answer Mr Joyce had given to Parliament that inflated the number of households receiving drought assistance.

So incensed was Dr Grimes that departmental staff were embroiled in the scandal dubbed “Hansardgate’’ that Dr Grimes concluded that his and Mr Joyce’s relationship was “irretrievably’’ broken.

Dr Grimes goes on to say: “As I have conducted myself appropriately at all times, I have no intention of resigning or stepping aside.’’

He then sought to withdraw the letter, and was sacked days later.

Labor’s agriculture spokesman Joel Fitzgibbon, who uncovered the doctoring of Hansard, said the Government had wasted two years and up to $1 million in taxpayer funds trying to cover up the scandal.

“No wonder Barnaby Joyce has fought tooth and nail to keep this letter secret — it’s dynamite,’’ Mr Fitzgibbon said.

“A highly respected public servant was sacked because he challenged Barnaby Joyce and the dodgy things he was doing.

“It is clear from his letter that Dr Grimes was first bullied and then sacked for trying to protect the reputation of his Department and those who serve it.”

Mr Joyce’s office said the letter described “sentiments’’ written when the relationship between a secretary and minister had broken down irretrievably.

“This letter is not a direct insight into the working relationships of the Department and the Deputy Prime Minister, and has not been for more than 17 months,’’ Mr Joyce’s spokeswoman said.

She said Mr Joyce was pleased to have a “good working relationship’’ with current Agriculture secretary Daryl Quinlivan, and he wished Dr Grimes well in the future.

A departmental lawyer advised that the appeal had been abandoned because: “While the Secretary remains of the view that the document in question is properly characterised as deliberative, it is recognised that the public interest test is multifaceted and that the passage of time can impact on how various considerations are to be weighed in the balance.’’

ellen.whinnett@news.com.au
results.standFirst: DEPUTY Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce’s integrity has been questioned in a blistering letter from his chief bureaucrat, which department officials have finally revealed after an 18-month fight to keep it secret.

results.title: Labor fury over Gleeson resignation
results.subtitle: Solicitor-General Justin Gleeson resigns after row with Attorney-General George Brandis
results.description: SOLICITOR-General Justin Gleeson has resigned after a long-running spat with George Brandis over allegations the Attorney-General “misled” Parliament.

thumbnailImage.title: Labor fury over Gleeson resignation
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 2e326974-99a9-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: Labor fury over Gleeson resignation
keywords: Legal and Constitutional Affairs References Committee
thumbnailImage.imageName: Solicitor-General Justin Gleeson appears at a Lega

results.seoHeadline: Solicitor-General Justin Gleeson resigns after row with George Brandis
results.body:
The top two government lawyers fronted a legal and constitutional affairs committee hearing in Canberra last week over allegations Senator Brandis failed to consult Mr Gleeson over a controversial new directive ruling that no-one in government, including the Prime Minister, could seek the Solicitor-General’s advice without first obtaining written permission.

Labor claimed Senator Brandis had “misled” Parliament by saying Mr Gleeson was on-board with the changes.

Senator Brandis released a statement to the media this afternoon, confirming Mr Gleeson had advised him of his intention to resign his office.

“In the circumstances, Mr Gleeson’s resignation is the proper course of action for him to have taken, as his letter acknowledges,” Senator Brandis said.

“I thank Mr Gleeson for his service as the Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth and wish him well for the future.

“I will immediately take steps to identify and recommend to the Cabinet a suitable person to be the next Solicitor-General. In the meantime, the Government will recommend to His Excellency the Governor-General the appointment of Mr Tom Howe PSM QC as the Acting Solicitor-General.”

In a powerful resignation letter to Senator Brandis, Mr Gleeson said he had come to the decision “with regret” but said his relationship with his colleague had been “irretrievably broken”. 

He said the best interests of the Commonwealth could only be served “when its first and second Law Officers enjoy each other’s complete trust and confidence with a mutually respectful relationship”.

“When such a relationship is irretrievably broken, as is the case here ... there must be some resolution to the impasse,” Mr Gleeson wrote.

“In taking this step, I make it perfectly plain that my motivation is solely to further the best interests of the Commonwealth by enabling the restoration of a functional working relationship between the first and second law officers.

“My decision does not amount to a withdrawal of my position I have taken in relation to matters of controversy between us, including before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs References Committee.”

Mr Gleeson wrote that he “rejected absolutely each and every attack and insinuation” upon himself and his office by Government members of Parliament.

He said the decision was unrelated to any finding the Senate Committee may make. 

The Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee is due to present a report to the Senate on the issue by November 8. 

Labor, who have previously called on Senator Brandis to step down over the dispute, said the wrong lawyer had resigned. 

Opposition leader Bill Shorten tweeted the Turnbull government should “hang its head in shame” over Mr Gleeson’s resignation. 

Shadow Attorney-General Mark Dreyfus said Mr Gleeson’s resignation was a direct result of the Attorney-General’s “disgraceful treatment of Mr Gleeson and his office”. 

Mr Dreyfus said Senator Brandis should be disciplined for his “reprehensible” conduct, claiming he had “pushed Mr Gleeson out of office to save his own skin”. 

“It is not Mr Gleeson who should have resigned today — it is Senator Brandis,” he said. 

“Since Senator Brandis’s move to destroy the independence of the office of Solicitor-General came to light, Mr Gleeson has conducted himself with dignity and respect at every turn.

“The Commonwealth has lost from its service a great legal mind and one of the most experienced constitutional lawyers in this country as its most senior legal adviser.”

During his tirade on Mr Gleeson’s treatment by the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus also criticised senators Ian Macdonald and Barry O’Sullivan for playing their part in hounding Mr Gleeson during the committee hearing.

He said the “proper course of action” was now for Senator Brandis to resign. 

“Senator Brandis created this mess by his own hand ... the ‘proper course of action’ is for Senator Brandis to resign, today.

“But it is clear Senator Brandis has no intention of resigning — Mr Turnbull must instead sack him.”

Shadow minister for employment, Brendan O’Connor, echoed the shadow attorney-general, tweeting: “Turnbull should have sacked AG not SG”.

Labor’s Tony Burke tweeted:
results.standFirst: JUSTIN Gleeson’s resignation as solicitor-general after a feud with the Attorney-General has infuriated Labor MPs, who say George Brandis should be sacked.

results.title: Winx off for well-earned spell
results.subtitle: Spring has seen the last of Winx with mare off to spelling paddock for well-earned break
results.description: CHAMPION mare Winx, record-breaking winner of the Cox Plate, will not race again this spring carnival.

thumbnailImage.title: Winx off for well-earned spell
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 95c4fce8-99a7-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: Winx off for well-earned spell

results.seoHeadline: Winx off to spelling paddock for well-earned break; Cox Plate winner; spring carnival
results.body:
Trainer Chris Waller confirmed on Monday that Winx will go for a spell immediately and then be set for a Sydney autumn campaign where the likely target is the $4 million Queen Elizabeth Stakes (2000m) at Royal Randwick during The Championships.

RAY THOMAS: WHY WINX’S WIN IS THE GREATEST RUN HE’S SEEN

TIMEFORM: WINX ECLIPSES LEGENDS MAKYBE DIVA, SUNLINE

COX PLATE: WHEN DAYLIGHT REALLY IS SECOND

Waller released a statement explaining the reasons behind the decision not to continue Winx’s spring campaign to include the Group 1 $2 million Emirates Stakes (2000m) at Flemington on November 5.

“The owners and I have jointly decided to spell Winx following her brilliant win in the William Hill Cox Plate (last) Saturday,’’ Waller said.

“Serious consideration was given to running in the MacKinnon (now Emirates) Stakes in two weeks; however we have carefully deliberated on what is best for the horse as well as ensuring she spends a reasonable period in the spelling paddock.’’

Winx extended her winning streak to 13 when she won the Cox Plate by a staggering eight lengths — the biggest margin ever in the race — and lifted her prizemoney to $9.34 million to be third on the all-time list of leading prizemoney earners.

But Waller has taken the conservative approach with a view to the Sydney autumn carnival and also the longevity of the mighty mare’s race career.

Waller said although an autumn race program has not been determined the “most logical races” will make up her campaign with the Queen Elizabeth Stakes the obvious focus.

“Other options such as travelling overseas and returning for a third Cox Plate in 2017 are also items the owners and I will discuss in the near future,’’ he continued.

“She has pulled up well from the race with the exception of a minor abrasion to her hind leg.

“Simple bathing and a trip or two to the beach would see it naturally heal; however I have taken the aggressive approach of treating it with antibiotics to ensure no risks are taken.’’

Waller’s careful management of Winx is likely to extend her race career into her six-year-old season.

“Longevity is the key for this mare as it will provide many more special moments over the next 12 months and beyond,’’ he said.

“I really appreciate the admiration shown to her by racing fans and the public and it is an honour to share that experience with you all.’’
results.standFirst: THE Flemington spring carnival will be without its greatest drawcard, with Winx to be sent to the spelling paddock. READ WALLER’S STATEMENT

results.title: Which NBA team should you follow?
results.subtitle: NBA 2016/17 season preview: Which basketball team corresponds to your AFL side?
results.description: WITH the return of the AFL season what seems like an eternity away, Aussies are broadening their horizons in their search for sporting sustenance.
results.subscriptionSummary:
WITH the return of the AFL season what seems like an eternity away, Aussies are broadening their horizons in their search for sporting sustinance. 
 And if you’re looking for a fast-paced, high-tempo sport to follow while you wait for footy season to return, the NBA will definitely help fill the void. 
 Here’s a handy guide to which NBA team to support, based on your AFL side.

thumbnailImage.title: Which NBA team should you follow?
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 54775e10-99a3-11e6-ab69-22cb8f6501a3
thumbnailImage.description: Which NBA team should you follow?
thumbnailImage.imageName: SALT LAKE CITY, UT - FEBRUARY 23: Aron Baynes #16

results.body:
And if you’re looking for a fast-paced, high-tempo sport to follow while you wait for the footy season to return, the NBA will definitely help fill the void.

LIVE BLOG: Bogut, Delly make NBA debuts with new clubs

We’ve come up with a handy guide on which NBA team to follow that best corresponds with your AFL team. 

Adelaide Crows = Oklahoma City Thunder

Tell us if this script sounds familiar: a star of the game, arguably going into his prime, decides to leave one title contender for another.

That’s the situation Oklahoma City found themselves in when superstar Kevin Durant decided to join the star-studded Golden State Warriors, drawing direct comparisons to Patrick Dangerfield’s move to Geelong.

The Crows and the Thunder have both faced this situation heading into a new season with fans questioning if the team can survive without its star.

Just as Adelaide had Rory Sloane waiting in the wings, Oklahoma City has a bona fide NBA superstar in Russell Westbrook.

Often considered the “other guy” behind Durant, Westbrook has constantly shown he is more than capable of winning games on his own while Durant has been injured. He definitely can go above and beyond this year.

Brisbane Lions = Chicago Bulls 

One of the most annoying thing for fans of these teams is that both have had historically incredible periods of success. 

Even people who never followed the NBA know of the Bulls three-peats in the 90s with Michael Jordan, and Lions’ fans will never forget the glorious three-peat from 2001-2003 where they were kings of the AFL. 

However last season both teams failed to make the finals/playoffs and while the Lions are attempting to rebuild, the Bulls are a couple years ahead of them with some strong drafting. 

The Bulls made some interesting veteran recruits in the off season — Dwyane Wade, Rajon Rondo, Robin Lopez — but their star draft pick Jimmy Butler is the leader of their team and they’ll be hoping more of their young talent in Bobby Portis, Nikola Mirotic and Doug McDermott can make a name for themselves.

Carlton Blues = Boston Celtics

A working class icon since their inceptions, both of these clubs have more trophies in their cabinets then you can shake a stick at.

While the Blues and Celtics have taken very different paths to get to where they are now, they are in very similar positions.

Both have an energetic young coach and are heavily invested in youth. 

And while the Blues’ fans have struggled in the lower part of the ladder for a number of years, the Celtics’ will give them something to smile about, as they are expected to be a contender in the Eastern Conference this season.

Collingwood Magpies = Dallas Mavericks

If we said to you that one of the most powerful men in the organisation was a media figurehead who seemed to be on television all the time, got in trouble for what he says and that the teams fans loved him, would you believe us if we said we weren’t talking about Eddie McGuire?

Just as Collingwood has Eddie, Dallas has Marc Cuban. The multi-billionaire seems to be on TV way more than his team, but Eddie still wins due to sheer workload.

Dallas also has Australian Olympian and NBA Championship-winning centre Andrew Bogut on its roster, so there’s a hometown element to cheer for there. 

Essendon Bombers = Los Angeles Lakers

It has been dark times for these two high-profile teams.

The Lakers are an iconic franchise that ties the NBA record for most championships won in history, but has recently fallen on hard times, and finished last in their conference in 2016. 

With the retirement of future hall of famer Kobe Bryant, the young Lakers will be looking to work their way back into relevance behind a young core, much like the Bombers are looking to do in 2017.

Player comparison: Zac Merrett — D’Angelo Russell.

Fremantle Dockers = New Orleans Pelicans

When it comes to teams with weird nicknames, Fremantle and New Orleans take the cake. They’re not ones that you only need to explain once.

Each of the Dockers and Pelicans have arguably the greatest young player in the competition in Nat Fyfe and Anthony Davis, only problem is they both struggle to stay healthy for a whole season.

If Davis can stay healthy, the Pelicans will be a thorn in the side of many opponents.

Geelong Cats = Golden State Warriors

Geelong has had a long-run of recent success, and while they didn’t manage to go all the way last season, they did manage to recruit the best player in the competition in Patrick Dangerfield.

The Warriors have done the same with superstar forward, Kevin Durant. The MVP sharp shooter made the high-profile move from Oklahoma City to join the Dubs.

Just as all eyes were on Danger, even more will be on KD this season, and see how damaging he can be alongside reigning MVP Stephen Curry. 

GWS Giants = Minnesota Timberwolves

With more top round draft picks then you can throw a stick at, the Timberwolves truly are the GWS of the NBA.

While they’re a bit further back in their development, Minnesota’s young guard is proving to be a real handful for even the most experienced NBA teams.

If Karl-Anthony Towns and Andrew Wiggins can continue to build on strong career starts, don’t be surprised if the Timberwolves rocket up the standings in the west.

NBA season preview: Record eight Australians set to take league by storm

Gold Coast = Houston Rockets

Two teams with best-in-the-competition calibre superstars in Gary Ablett Jnr and James Harden, but both have struggled to put successful talent around them to take the next step. This may be slightly harsh on the Rockets, who did make it to the Western Conference finals two seasons ago, but last year was viewed as a major disappointment for the franchise when they only just scraped into the playoffs.

The Rockets are set up to be one of the most exciting offensive teams this season under new coach Mike D’Antoni, and James Harden’s move to the point guard position will give him the opportunity to put up MVP-like numbers. 

Hawthorn Hawks = San Antonio Spurs

Both these teams have one defining characteristic over the past couple of seasons, they win. They win, they win and then they win again.

Despite numerous roster changes, both these teams are almost annoyingly consistent.

This is in part due to the legendary coaches at the helm of both teams. Alistair Clarkson has been instrumental to the Hawks recent success, Spurs coach Greg Popovich has spent 20 years building a dynasty in the Texas desert.

Both are known for being slightly short fused, but Clarko wins for putting his fist though an MCG wall. Also the Spurs have Aussie Boomers star Patty Mills, so there’s an added homegrown element to cheer for.

Melbourne Demons = Milwaukee Bucks

The future is coming. That has been the mantra in Milwaukee for the past couple of seasons. Something which many Demons fans will say sounds strangely familiar.

But with their good mix of young talent and older leaders, the Bucks can make a push up the Eastern Conference standings.

Matthew Dellavedova opens up on life ahead of his Milwaukee debut

Plus they also have a rookie turning a lot of heads in Australia’s newest NBA phenom Thon Maker

Also they have Delly, you can’t go wrong with Delly. 

What are you most looking forward to this NBA season? Tell us in the comments below.

North Melbourne Kangaroos = Miami Heat

Two teams that very quickly went from a who’s who to who’s that?

Both clubs will be going into next season without their longest serving players as Boomer Harvey and Dwayne Wade were moved on.

With the big name older players leaving, it’s time for the young brigade to step up and prove they’re good enough to do it on their own.

Port Adelaide Power = Los Angeles Clippers

Port Adelaide fans haven’t been able to enjoy much success in the past few years, but at their core they are a strong team who are still trying to find a way to retool before going back to the finals, rather than bottom out. 

The Clippers unfortunately find themselves in a difficult position, in the same Western Conference as the Golden State Warriors and San Antonio Spurs, but they are hoping that another year with a very similar roster and stronger team chemistry will help them find a way to break through.

Blake Griffin started hot last year before he missed most of second half of the season with injury, and the Clippers will be hoping he can recapture his form along with Chris Paul and DeAndre Jordan, on the way for a further playoff push.

Richmond Tigers = New York Knicks

The Knicks are one of the most popular franchises in the country, but have failed to have any legitimate success in over 40 years. They are always overhyped, being a big market team — but usually fail to live up to expectations. 

A couple of years ago, they made the playoffs, but since that time have fallen back into the bottom half of the Eastern Conference, much to the fans’ dismay.

Sound familiar, Tigers fans? 

The good news in they’ve brought in some big names: MVP Derrick Rose and Joakim Noah will slot into their starting line-up along with star forward Carmello Anthony and young stud Kristaps Porzingis. 

The potential is there Tigers’ fans, build up your expectations, just don’t be surprised if the Knicks crash and burn again this season like they have in the past. 

St. Kilda Saints = Orlando Magic 

The Orlando Magic are a young team with a long championship drought. In 2009, their star centre Dwight Howard took them all the way to the Finals, but they couldn’t get over the line, much like the Saints in 2010 against Collingwood.

The Magic made some odd moves this off-season, but they’ve acquired a lot of big man talent, and a new head coach in Frank Vogel, who has proven playoff form.

They may not be a chance to contend this season, but this could be a fun team to watch with new recruit Serge Ibaka and high-flying forward Aaron Gordon providing plenty of highlights. 

Sydney Swans = Cleveland Cavaliers

A powerhouse of the league, the Cleveland Cavaliers have the highest payroll in the NBA, and brought back hometown hero and superstar LeBron James two years ago, who delivered a championship to ‘the Land’ in the 2016 season.

Sydney has COLA, effectively giving them one of the highest payrolls in the AFL, and brought in superstar Lance Franklin on a big-money contract two years ago, hoping it will bring them another premiership.

The Cavs are a constant title contender with James, much like Sydney, who continue to find a way to go deep into the AFL finals campaign. 

The Cavs lost in 2015, before defeating the Warriors last season in a thrilling NBA Finals to win the championship, could the Swans do the same next year?

Western Bulldogs = Indiana Pacers

All the fans of the newly crowned AFL premiers can rest easy now your premiership drought is over, and instead shift their focus to a team that not many people in the NBA are talking about who have the potential to be a surprise packet this NBA season.

The Indiana Pacers have quietly retooled their roster to bring in some very savvy NBA veterans to complement some of their already strong roster.

Paul George is the unquestionable leader and star, but he now will have great help from point guard Jeff Teague, another forward to help down low in Thaddeus Young, and some bench scoring in big man Al Jefferson.

Jump on now Bulldogs fans, because this could be a team that could go a long way in the Eastern Conference come playoffs time.

West Coast Eagles = Toronto Raptors

The Raptors are sometimes the forgotten team in the NBA because they are the only team outside of the United States. West Coast has a tendency to also go under the radar to many Melbourne footy fans, but always find a way to make their way back to the finals.

The Raptors made it all the way to the Eastern Conference finals last season, before getting knocked out by the champion Cavaliers.

West Coast were bundled out of the finals last season by the eventual premiers, the Western Bulldogs. There’s no doubt that both teams will be looking to come back and make amends in coming seasons.

Don’t follow an AFL team? Utah Jazz 

If you aren’t an AFL fan, but are looking for someone to follow this year? Or don’t agree with our team comparison for your AFL side? Get on the Utah Jazz bandwagon. 

The Jazz are quietly being touted as the team in the west that will have a big leap this season, with a very deep and talented roster.

They also have two Australians on the team, in young guard Dante Exum and veteran Joe Ingles, so show some Aussie pride and back our boys as the Jazz make the leap into the playoffs. 

What do you think of our NBA / AFL comparisons? Did we get it right? Tell us in the comments below.

MORE

Matthew Dellavedova opens up on the Bucks, Boomers and more ahead of Milwaukee debut

NBA season preview: Record eight Australians set to take league by storm

Follow @BrendoCasey and @MatLandgdon on Twitter.
results.standFirst: ARE you an AFL fan looking for a sport to follow in the off season? Here’s a handy guide to which NBA team to support based on your AFL side.

results.title: Oliver’s reckless riding charge stands
results.subtitle: Damien Oliver’s reckless riding charge stands
results.description: CHAMPION jockey Damien Oliver has lost a bid to downgrade his reckless riding charge with a judge describing his attitude as cavalier.

thumbnailImage.title: Oliver’s reckless riding charge stands
thumbnailImage.subtitle: f9fed58c-99a0-11e6-8c86-36bc38a6a007
thumbnailImage.description: Oliver’s reckless riding charge stands

results.body:
Oliver still hopes to be allowed to ride at Saturday’s Victoria Derby meeting despite the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal finding him guilty of reckless riding. 

VCAT vice-president Judge Pamela Jenkins is hearing submissions on penalty on Monday with Oliver hoping to have his 20-meeting suspension reduced. 

Oliver was outed over his ride on eventual winner Flying Artie in the Blue Sapphire Stakes on October 12, when he angled out from behind the leader and made heavy contact with the horse to his outside. 

The judge said Oliver’s actions were calculated and intentional, and had created a clear circumstance of potential risk. 

“In my view, the applicant exhibited a cavalier attitude, which is not moderated by his explanation to the effect that jockeys will commonly try to take another horse out, notwithstanding the rules,” Jenkins said. 

“The applicant, as a very experienced professional jockey, is aware of the attendant dangers of placing another jockey at risk of falling and the consequential danger to other riders and horses where a fall occurs in front of a field of riders. 

“By forcing his mount into the pathway of another jockey and abruptly displacing that jockey and his mount out of the way, the applicant displayed a reckless indifference to the possible grave consequences.” 

Jenkins said Oliver displayed a cavalier attitude to the rules of racing, the paramount objectives of which were to ensure the safety of horse and rider. 

“If riders continue to test the boundaries in the hope of defying the clear and attendant risks associated with a particular course of action, then the integrity of the rules are undermined and the safety of riders and horses alike become victims of the pursuit of competitive advantage.” Oliver needs his suspension cut from 20 to 17 meetings to allow him to ride on Saturday, when he has rides booked on Flying Artie in the Group 1 Coolmore Stud Stakes and Highlad in the Group 1 Victoria Derby. 

Jenkins will hand down her decision on the penalty at 11.30am on Tuesday.
results.standFirst: CHAMPION jockey Damien Oliver has lost a bid to downgrade his reckless riding charge with a judge describing his attitude as cavalier.

results.title: Nervy VCE parents, you are not alone
results.subtitle: The trek to the end of VCE can be as emotional for parents as it is for kids
results.description: I AM part of a big group of Melbourne mums and dads who you may notice suddenly appear five years older than we are. We are among about 100,000 parents feeding, supporting and watching over a child taking his or her run-up to what feels like an Uluru-size leap: final exams for VCE.
results.subscriptionSummary: ABOUT 100,000 parents who’ve been wingmen and women for VCE kids this year are nearing the end of a long trek, Wendy Tuohy knows how you feel.

thumbnailImage.title: Nervy VCE parents, you are not alone
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 2a379040-998d-11e6-ab69-22cb8f6501a3
thumbnailImage.description: Nervy VCE parents, you are not alone

results.body:
We are tiptoeing to the end of a long, teetering walk down the tightrope of being a VCE bystander, carer, wingman or woman.

It’s a fine balancing act and one that can feel as if you’re doing it 20 storeys up in a blindfold and the wind is blowing. Hard.

You feel quite helpless and, at the same time, desperate to do something to help your loved young person get through what they and we are constantly told should not “define you”, but due to our system of letting kids into courses based on a number, they feel really does.

You know all you can do is maybe pick them up from school a bit more often to help them get to their desks quicker, feed them up well and regularly, nag them into bed after its too late for them to really be taking anything in and keep an eye on their mood.

You go to the parent info evenings, you take notes when the nice “study habits” expert comes to explain how plans, schedules and efficient note summaries work, but you know the kids have been told exactly the same information and the idea of sitting down with an 18-year-old and babying them through the finer points of revision, uninvited, is ridiculous.

There are some parents, we’re told, who go to the point of not just reading all their kids’ VCE texts but virtually doing the work alongside them, and if you’re on the highly strung or obsessive side this could be tempting for the reassurance/insurance value — but I don’t think it’s healthy.

Even so, while some may hardly feel the VCE stress, bless them, like many other parents, I don’t come from that gene pool.

I don’t consider myself a helicopter parent or a cottonwool type. I’ve tried to let all my children make mistakes — even with subject choices — and learn from them, and I don’t live their lives for them.

I shoot for attentive without being intrusive or suffocating. I want the kids to know I am 100 per cent solidly there for them but won’t do their lifting.

I’ve let them recover from their own disappointments, the test they didn’t do as well as they’d hoped, the team they didn’t make, and seen it help them build resilience.

I’ve learned you can be hands off to a level that’s good for them (and you) but you can’t not care.

When someone you love so much has something large hanging over them that, like it or not, does hold the key to their future hopes at least to a point, you wish it could be you suffering through all that uncertainty, the nerves, that general claustrophobic atmosphere the poor things live through for about nine months.

It takes about the same time to bake a fully formed VCE kid as it took to gestate him or her 17 or 18 years earlier. And unless you’re really unlucky with pregnancy I’d say that journey is infinitely easier.

It’s not just the wanting, hoping and wishing your special young person to do well enough to get into their chosen course that wrenches the heart strings of parents during VCE. It’s the underlying knowledge, I think, that this is their last real developmental stage in which you as a parent will be intimately involved.

After pregnancy and the labour you’re rewarded with a shiny new beginning, the start of a long and lovely adventure with a fresh love of your life. After VCE, if your child crosses that bridge successfully you know you are on the way to having to let go.

You know deep down that this year is your mutual destination in the long trip you have taken together from when they were a dribbling and divine three-year-old, into kinder.

You can’t escape the significance.

You don’t want to fall at the last school-parent hurdle, and yet you know you can’t run ahead of theirs, lowering them to an easy height.

It’s a happy-sad year where time seems to stretch out in the first half and every SAC test feels like anticipating a trip to the dentist, then snaps back and seems to run too fast in the countdown to the end.

Doing some of the last few school runs for my eldest son, I’ve watched bunches of those lanky, healthy young people full of potential as they lope towards the school gates to go to their last few classes.

Hooked up to music and looking faintly ridiculous as grown men and women still sporting school uniforms, they seem lost in worlds of their own — a shared limbo between being a kid inside a system and stepping off into their great unknown.

No doubt, wafting invisibly behind them is the same tailwind of love I silently send along with the adored VCE guy of my very own.

* Keep in touch with Wendy via @wtuohyor at facebook.com/WendyATuohy
results.standFirst: ABOUT 100,000 parents who’ve been wingmen and women for VCE kids this year are nearing the end of a long trek, Wendy Tuohy knows how you feel.

results.title: Why Melbourne winter just won’t quit
results.subtitle: Melbourne weather: Why winter conditions are lasting into spring
results.description: ENJOY this spell of warmish weather while you can. Victoria is set to cool off again after tomorrow with little spring-like weather to come.

thumbnailImage.title: Why Melbourne winter just won’t quit
thumbnailImage.subtitle: a6d88682-9987-11e6-ab69-22cb8f6501a3
thumbnailImage.description: Why Melbourne winter just won’t quit

results.body:
After a long, cool and wet spring so far, Melbourne is set for a sunny top of 18C today and 24C tomorrow.

But Bureau of Meteorology senior forecaster Richard Carlyon says an approaching cold front will cool things off again, with another due ahead of next week’s Melbourne Cup.

“It looks like being a drier week this week but it won’t be warming up in a hurry either,” he said.

“Today will be mild across the state and tomorrow will be quite mild, but then there is some cooler weather into the middle part of the week with a few showers mainly in the south, and then some dry days on Friday and Saturday. In fact, Saturday looks like the pick of the week.”

Mr Carlyon said a front due overnight tomorrow is weak but will lower temperatures.

“We’re not likely to have severe weather warnings for damaging winds and it’s not likely to exacerbate the flood situation we’ve got,” he said.

Melbourne’s maximum will drop back to 20C on Wednesday and 17C on Thursday, with showers possible on both days, before the sun returns with a top of 20C on Friday.

Saturday looks sunny with a maximum of 24C at this stage – perfect for racegoers at Flemington.

A stronger cold front expected on Sunday should plunge Victoria back towards winter once again, Mr Carlyon said.

What’s behind out cool spring so far?

“Spring is normally unsettled but normally you get a bit of heat involved as well,” Mr Carlyon said.

“We haven’t had too much warm weather. We just haven’t had any lengthy dry breaks. Spring is changeable but we have just had more of the cold, wet part of spring than anything else so far.”

Mr Carlyon warned that relief is a while away yet.

“At least for the next week, it looks like more of the same because quite an active front is moving through on Sunday that will bring that cold, wet and windy weather back to the state,” he said.

“There’s certainly no sign of drier or warmer conditions developing, I guess more like temperatures that you’d expect this time of year. It just looks like another active front that will bring up cold air from the southwest.”

Colder temperatures have persisted well into October. Saturday’s maximum, 13.2C, was the lowest October maximum since 2010 and the lowest recorded in the second half of the month since 2003.

Mr Carlyon says in terms of rainfall, he expects “a swag of records will fall” when statistics are tallied at the end of the month.

“And coupled with a wet, cold September, I would expect our spring to have been a cold one, but we will have to see what happens,” he said.
results.standFirst: SATURDAY was the coldest late October day in Melbourne for 13 years. So it got us wondering, why is it still so miserable and are we about to see a bunch of rain records fall?
bulletList: Wet and wild: Weather has a field day at Cox Plate

results.title: It’s extraordinary to be this average
results.subtitle: Katie Bice: It’s extraordinary to be this average
results.description: BEING ordinary has become seriously unfashionable. If it wasn’t enough that we are always being told to make over our bodies, we now have to make over our minds and our lives as well. But there’s something wonderful about being bog standard — a resident of Average-town. No need to be mindful, enlightened or reflective — just normal.
results.subscriptionSummary: BEING ordinary has become seriously unfashionable. If it wasn’t enough that we are always being told to make over our bodies, we now have to make over our minds and our lives as well.

thumbnailImage.title: It’s extraordinary to be this average
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 3cff612a-9826-11e6-90f6-b8531e8f57b9
thumbnailImage.description: It’s extraordinary to be this average
thumbnailImage.imageName: PicAdam/Ward House styles Federation house of Deborah Sutton and Jim Heaton at Ipswich. houses exterior suburban picket fence plants flowers blooms Picture: Ward Adam

results.body:
We’re told to dream of a life less ordinary. But why can’t we just be happy with being like everyone else?

The harsh reality is that most of us will never be anything more than that. We can tell our kids they’re “special” all we want, but just look in the schoolyard and you’ll see they’re exactly like the other 300 kids there.

The idea seems to be that we have to be “someone” for our lives to be worthwhile; and that when we compare ourselves with those worthy types we always come off second best.

You don’t have to be exceptional to do and achieve good things, yet it’s hard not to be drawn into the silliness of trying to be something more. Last week I read a story about a man who had spoken to 50 strangers. He found the experience profound and was struck by the ability of every one of them to remember the conversation that changed their life.

After recovering from the reeling horror I felt at the prospect of chatting to that many strangers, I tried to recall what discussion had changed my life.

Anything in my childhood was immediately out since I seem to have suppressed the whole thing.

So the next obvious thing was meeting my husband. It was at an AFL Grand Final party some time after the invention of the internet but blessedly before Tinder.

My two housemates and I wandered in the dark towards the pub on the corner to replenish our beer supply.

“So do you like him?” they inquired.

“Ahhh, I don’t know,” I replied truthfully.

“Because he definitely likes you.”

“Really?”

“For sure.”

Deep, hey?

Desperate to find anything more meaningful to hang my hat on, I skipped forward a few weeks to the moment I knew we could just be right for each other. It was easy to remember because we had both laughed until we cried ... about his mate’s cat without a tail.

But remembering that moment was the point I abandoned my quest to be philosophical, more intellectually sophisticated. I had to face facts: I’m plain ordinary.

I live a normal, delightfully dull existence in which I work too much, party too little, whittle away precious hours on Real Housewives and cooking shows and rarely worry about the thoughts of anyone outside my small circle of friends.

It won’t win me a Nobel Peace Prize, I’ll never be Australian of the Year — but I’m content with being Mrs Average. And I can’t work out why a bunch of other people want me feel bad about it. Or why so many people strive to be something more.

I’m supposed to be “mindful” when I’m still not even sure what that means. 

I’m meant to be having Shakespeare-worthy discussions on the universe and humanity when all I really want to do is make fun of my mates, have them do the same at me and tell old, dumb stories.

When you think about it, us ordinary folk sure have a lot going for us.

Want your rubbish picked up, your kids taught, your garden mowed, your truck and train driven? You can rely on Mr and Mrs Smith.

We are always the ones who dig in when the chips are down.

Need sandbags filled, money for bushfire victims, help at the school sausage sizzle — the Joe Citizens will be there.

Where are the others? Probably mindfully working on their adult colouring books.

KATIE BICE IS THE SUNDAY HERALD SUN DEPUTY EDITOR

katie.bice@news.com.au

@ktbice
results.standFirst: PEOPLE spend so much time striving to be “special” that they miss the simple pleasure of being average, a useful, content member of the pack, writes Katie Bice.

results.title: Senator shoots himself in the foot
results.subtitle: Peta Credlin: Senator Leyonhjelm shoots himself in the foot
results.description: IT is ironic that after a whole week talking about the Adler A110 lever-action shotgun, Tony Abbott is still the prime minister who banned it. And when the states finally reach agreement, Malcolm Turnbull will be the Prime Minister to lift the ban and import the gun.
results.subscriptionSummary: IT IS ironic that after a whole week talking about the Adler shotgun, Tony Abbott is still the prime minister who banned it and when the states ­finally reach agreement, Malcolm Turnbull will be the prime minister to lift the ban and import the gun into Australia, Peta Credlin writes.

thumbnailImage.title: Senator shoots himself in the foot
thumbnailImage.subtitle: f6be6444-9830-11e6-90f6-b8531e8f57b9
thumbnailImage.description: Senator shoots himself in the foot

results.body:
I’m not going to make it a habit to detail internal debates inside the Abbott government.

But Australia’s gun laws are too important an issue to stay silent.

And despite Senator David Leyonhjelm’s tweet this week that I should “STFU” (shut the f--- up), I will not. 

ADLER SHOTGUN: AUSTRALIAN STATES FAIL TO REACH A DEAL ON ACCESS

HUNTERS, FARMERS SAY GUN CONTROL ADVOCATES HIJACKING DEBATE OVER BANNED SHOTGUN

(No I am not kidding; hardly an intelligent comeback for a 64-year-old elected official).

In July last year, the Abbott government became aware that a new type of shotgun was on its way to Australia. Already over 7000 orders had been placed with the first of the seven-shot lever-action guns due to clear Customs in late August. 

To put this into perspective, if Tony Abbott hadn’t acted, these new Adler A110 guns would have almost doubled the number of shotguns in Australia in one fell swoop.

As Mr Abbott said last week, law enforcement agencies expressed concern that without a tougher classification, the mass importation of this new type of lever-action weapon would be dangerous at a time of heightened threat. 

Front of mind was the reality that the weapon used at the Lindt Cafe siege in Sydney’s CBD was a common shotgun. 

New guns, with greater capacity, more brutal efficiency and poorly classified, were a dumb idea at a difficult time. This information is in the public domain. I do not comment on National Security Committee discussions.

So on Thursday, July 23, last year, Mr Abbott agreed to put a temporary ban on the importation of the Adler A110 seven-shot shotgun, with the Justice Minister to implement it via regulation. 

The ban was designed to be temporary, with a sunset clause so that it would dovetail into the government’s review of the National Firearms Agreement due to report in early 2016. 

This review into the system we use to classify the weapons that can be bought and used by individuals in our community was a key recommendation of the government’s report into the Lindt Cafe siege. 

Mr Abbott hoped to see the Adler reclassified down from Class A (which gave lots of people ready access) to Class D — the toughest class, essentially limiting it to law enforcement agencies and professional shooters.

The news of the ban was broken by Samantha Maiden in this newspaper on Sunday, July 26. She reported that the Abbott government would ban the Adler firearm for “at least six months until the National Firearms Agreement review process was completed”.

Mr Abbott argued strongly that we had enough guns in this country to do the job farmers and others needed to be done. If there was a case for the Adler A110, then it would have to come in under a tougher classification with greater safeguards. 

Mr Abbott was not anti-gun; he was just against a big spike in our importation of guns at a time when our community was battling the risk of lone-wolf attacks.

Claims last week of a secret deal between Tony Abbott and Senator Leyonhjelm to slip these guns into Australia as the price for a vote in the Senate are therefore rubbish.

Even Senator Leyonhjelm was forced to admit he didn’t have a deal with Tony Abbott because there was no meeting, no phone call, no correspondence, no communication. 

For the record, there was nothing between Senator Leyonhjelm and me either. The story then was that he had a deal with ministers Peter Dutton and Michael Keenan and emails were produced as “proof”.

But here’s where the chronology is instructive.

If Senator Leyonhjelm is to be believed, he had a “secret” deal with minister Dutton and Keenan to get a 12-month review of the Adler gun for the price of his vote during negotiations about unrelated legislation in mid-August 2015. 

But we now know that Tony Abbott had already found the problem, sought advice, agreed to a temporary ban, worked with his minister to deal with it by regulation change and announced it in the Sunday papers three weeks earlier.

So this week, the Coalition lost time fighting about a so-called secret deal with ministers last year that was neither a deal (because it was what Abbott decided weeks earlier) nor secret (it was splashed across every Sunday paper in the country). Was anyone in the PM’s office kept in the loop as Malcolm Turnbull claimed on Senator Leyonhjelm’s “deal”? 

I don’t know, as advisers often received hundreds of emails a day, and a cc’d note hardly constitutes “in full knowledge”. But then again, it hardly matters — Senator Leyonhjelm’s so-called “secret deal” was what Mr Abbott had announced by way of the Sunday papers three weeks earlier.

The story most journalists missed this week was that Prime Minister Turnbull himself kicked off this issue on Tuesday morning by failing to rule out trading votes on guns to secure Senator Leyonhjelm’s vote on the current ABCC legislation. And it wasn’t just one question either.

By refusing to rule out a deal with the Senator, the PM left the door wide open, an activist Labor Opposition pounced and the rest of the week was Adlerised.

Malcolm Turnbull tried his best to mop it up but Senator Leyonhjelm confirmed on Wednesday night’s Sky News Bolt Report that he was indeed working with Turnbull Government ministers to cut a deal to get the Adler gun into the country for the price of his ABCC vote. 

He didn’t say he had a deal but he named the ministers in discussions. Was there a deal pending or did the government merely want Senator Leyonhjelm to think he would get one?

Despite the huffing and puffing of the Liberal Democratic Party’s front man, the Australian people will never support more liberal gun laws. 

Almost every day there’s a new story from the US about the impact of gun culture on the lives of people just going about their ordinary lives: in shopping malls, in cinemas, on university campuses and in primary schools.

I’m a country girl so I have lived with guns much of my life but I also went to high school in California. I understand the desire of so many Americans who wish they could wind back the clock on the Second Amendment of their Constitution but now fear their weapon obsession has gone too far to fix.

For them, it is over. For us, it is not.

The Canberra games over guns last week might have been sport for the political types, but for the rest of us, we want a careful balance between licensed and registered users, and safe streets and communities.

This should never be a hard choice for any prime minister. It certainly wasn’t for Tony Abbott and I don’t think it will be for Malcolm Turnbull.
results.standFirst: IT is ironic that after a whole week talking about the Adler A110 lever-action shotgun, Tony Abbott is still the prime minister who banned it, writes Peta Credlin.

results.title: No justice for my beautiful girl
results.subtitle: Mum prays for answers to daughter Maddy Murphy-West’s violent death
results.description: THE family of Melbourne mum Maddison Murphy-West hopes an inquest will finally expose what really happened to her and who was involved.
results.subscriptionSummary: THE family of Melbourne mum Maddison Murphy-West hopes an inquest will finally expose what really happened to her and who was involved.

thumbnailImage.title: No justice for my beautiful girl
thumbnailImage.subtitle: c50f34ca-98a6-11e6-90f6-b8531e8f57b9
thumbnailImage.description: No justice for my beautiful girl

results.body:
Sunday marks three years since Ms Murphy-West’s body was found at her Pakenham home, her toddler son Noah nearby.

Police later concluded Ms Murphy-West was murdered before her killer tried to manipulate the crime scene to give the appearance of a suicide. 

ANDREW RULE: CAUGHT IN A HELL SHE COULDN’T ESCAPE

Her boyfriend, Troy Boothey, is the man police suspect but has never been charged.

Investigators have sent a brief of evidence to the State Coroner, potentially meaning the case will go before an inquest.

Ms Murphy-West’s family say that if they can’t get justice for her yet, they want answers.

They have long suspected a second person was involved in trying to give the appearance Ms Murphy-West had taken her own life and that others are withholding information to protect the killer.

Her mother, Paula Murphy, said she wanted to see those people answering hard questions about what they knew.

“They’re not up at night with Noah when he’s crying. They don’t take him down to his mother’s gravestone,” she said.

“They need to face what has happened. This will never go away for us and they’ve just gone on living their lives.”

Ms Murphy said Noah, four, who she is now raising, was a loving, affectionate boy, but he could not yet comprehend what had happened.

“He just doesn’t get it and we can’t explain it properly,” she said.

“I’m getting questions like ‘why can’t I have a sleepover at my other mum’s’?”

Ms Murphy said a person capable of killing her daughter had the capacity to do the same again and had to be stopped.

She said the past three years had been terribly difficult, but giving up was never an option.

“I haven’t given up. I’m trying to keep the faith,” Ms Murphy said.

A spokeswoman for the coroner said evidence provided to them was now being ­reviewed before a decision was made on what happened next.

mark.buttler@news.com.au
results.standFirst: A MELBOURNE mum prays an inquest will finally give her answers three years after her daughter’s body was found next to her toddler son.

results.title: Caught in a hell she couldn’t escape
results.subtitle: Andrew Rule: Three years after Maddy Murphy-West’s death, her family still suffers
results.description: IT IS three years today since Maddison Murphy-West was found dead in her unit in Pakenham. She was 20. Her son, Noah, was 20 months.
results.subscriptionSummary: IT IS three years today since Maddison Murphy-West was found dead in her unit in Pakenham. She was 20. Her son, Noah, was 20 months.

thumbnailImage.title: Caught in a hell she couldn’t escape
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 960d8df8-98b4-11e6-90f6-b8531e8f57b9
thumbnailImage.description: Caught in a hell she couldn’t escape

results.body:
Hardly anyone thinks the abused young mother died by her own hand, although that’s how it was presented to the police called to the scene by her violent, drug-dealing, thieving boyfriend, Troy Boothey.

Boothey, then 24, told the police he had come in from doing something in the garage to find his partner of four years hanging from a doorknob.

The investigators doubted his story, despite his crocodile tears. They suspected the scene had been dressed up to look like suicide. Nothing has happened in the three years since to change their minds or those of the dead woman’s family.

Mum prays for answers to daughter Maddy Murphy-West’s violent death

For Boothey, his girlfriend’s violent death did not seem to divert him from a life of crime. Later the same day, instantly recovered, he was seen scoring drugs at Seaford. When someone he knew asked him how Maddy was, he lied: “Great!”

They say the leopard’s spots never vanish — they just get bigger or smaller. This week Troy Boothey appeared in Dandenong Drug Court charged with the latest of a lifetime of offences.

He admitted thefts and having illicit drugs after he was caught red-handed robbing a Dandenong South auction house in early August.

He was carrying a torch and nine grams of the drug ice after he and an accomplice had broken in by cutting a fence and smashing a window.

Three months earlier, in June, police found Boothey asleep in a car in Hampton Park, engine running and headlights on. The car was unregistered and Boothey had ecstasy pills, scales and $450 cash on him.

In the sick and selfish world of Boothey and thousands like him, cash is for necessities like drugs, alcohol, cigarettes and gambling — not to be wasted on registering cars, paying rent, buying real food or supporting children. 

Victorian courts are clogged with crimes which are symptoms of the same sort of sordid circumstances: drugs, drinking, chronic unemployment, stupidity, criminal carelessness and more drugs. Which, of course, is just another variation on the circumstances leading to the death of the neglected toddler Jaidyn Leskie at Moe in 1997.

If Jaidyn’s body had been found the night he died, instead of being successfully hidden for six months, it would have been just another sad case to be tutted over and then forgotten.

“Just another little murder,” as Phil Cleary reflects bitterly of the pre-planned butchering of his sister Vicki by a violent piece of vermin called Peter Keogh in 1987. 

Keogh, notoriously, was let off with a pathetically light jail sentence by a judge who should have known better than to humour the defence case of “provocation”.

Maddy Murphy-West, like Vicki Cleary and hundreds more, think they can change bad and damaged people — nearly always drunks or druggies with criminal “form” — into someone who can be trusted with their own lives and their children’s. We all know (or know of) someone like that.

Patting monsters doesn’t work, a point Maddy Murphy-West’s mother and uncle have had too much time to think about since they got the awful news three years ago.

A month after Maddy’s death, Boothey cut off a bus driver at a Hallam roundabout, got out of his car with a baseball bat and smashed the bus window, spattering shattered glass into the driver’s face.

A dash camera recorded the incident and Boothey was arrested soon after, identified by his mugshot. 

He could offer no reason for the attack — and claimed he could not even remember it — but in his defence it was suggested he was lashing out wildly because of his “grief” over Maddy’s death. The same excuse, incidentally, he used for various other offences.

He was either lying about not recalling the attack — or so off his face on drugs that his mind was blanked out. 

Either way, he deserved the four months’ jail he got. And more.

One way he could have proven his bona fides as a grief-stricken partner was to keep his promise to detectives to go through with a polygraph lie-detector test.

But — surprise, surprise — he didn’t. 

Maddy Murphy-West had reasons to want to escape her life with Boothey but, insist her family and friends, she would never have killed herself.

She loved Noah too much. Her mother, Paula Murphy, has always believed that her daughter’s renewed determination to leave Boothey might have sparked an ugly confrontation before her death.

“People told her to pack her bags and leave and that was a mistake — she should have walked straight out the door without packing anything,” Paula Murphy once told this reporter. 

“I told her once to just go out to buy milk and never come back.”

Maddy’s death is all the harder for her mother because she had often tried to persuade her girl to leave the fated relationship. 

But Maddy wouldn’t — even after being separated for six months early in the year she died, she had stuck by the jailbird boyfriend. Her family still believe she was too frightened to do anything else.

The day before she was to reunite with him after he got out of jail in 2013, Maddy looked sick with strain. No wonder. The year before, she had been admitted to hospital after being brutally attacked.

In texts to a friend, she confessed she had been choked in front of her little boy. The texts, sent from Casey Hospital in Berwick in late 2012, admit she was waiting on results of neck scans after being half-strangled.

She was clearly afraid that her attacker would be angry about her going to police.

“So now he’s going to kill me,” she texted. “I’m not only doing this for me and Noah, I’m doing it for him. He bashed me, choked me today. I can’t have that in front of my son.”

Her fear was clear in the exchange during her day-long hospital stay.

“If he calls you, don’t tell him anything. Not even about me being in hospital,” she wrote.

But she went back. It seemed to her she had no choice but to wade back into the quicksand she knew was going to choke her.

When Boothey left prison last January, Maddy’s aunt, Kelly Anne Murphy, took to Facebook to express her anger and concern.

“The prime suspect in Maddy’s murder is being released from prison tomorrow,” she wrote.

“I’m warning everyone because it’s not just us that are in danger, he is a danger to the community as well. Our justice system has a lot to answer for!”

Troy Boothey is only 27. How many more lives will he destroy before he destroys himself?

andrew.rule@news.com.au
results.standFirst: HARDLY anyone thinks abused young mother Maddison Murphy-West died by her own hand, but that’s how it was presented to police by her violent, drug-dealing, boyfriend, writes Andrew Rule.

results.title: Lyon set for breakfast radio return
results.subtitle: Garry Lyon set to return to radio airwaves after taking year off, plus other radio moves
results.description: GARRY Lyon is set to return to SEN, 12 years after he spoke the first words on the station as part of the Morning Glory breakfast team in January 2004.
results.subscriptionSummary:
GARRY Lyon is set to return to SEN, 12 years after he spoke the first words on the station as part of the Morning Glory breakfast team in January 2004. 
 Lyon, Bill Brownless and Tim Watson formed the original breakfast crew, making their debut on the Monday morning after David Hookes hit his head after an altercation outside the Beaconsfield Hotel and died.

thumbnailImage.title: Lyon set for breakfast radio return
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 138892be-983d-11e6-a368-50371b0b9b4a
thumbnailImage.description: Lyon set for breakfast radio return

categories.value: /taxonomy/iptc.org/economy, business and finance/tourism and leisure/hotel and accommodation/

results.body:
Lyon, Bill Brownless and Tim Watson formed the original breakfast crew, making their debut on the Monday morning after David Hookes hit his head after an altercation outside the Beaconsfield Hotel and died.

Now Lyon is set to return to the same timeslot, with Channel 7’s Hamish McLachlan earmarked as a potential on-air partner. 

JORDAN LEWIS: I’M HAPPY, DON’T FEEL SORRY FOR ME

SUPERCOACH 2017: STARS TO MAKE IMPACT IN NEW COLOURS

FAILED TRADE: GIBBS FAMILY HAD THEIR HOPES UP

McLachlan is yet to commit to the station’s plan for a makeover of on-air talent.

A Lyon-McLachlan pairing could see David Schwarz return to the drive slot in which he previously formed a successful partnership with Mark Allen. 

Allen is currently paired with Daniel Harford, a name that has cropped up as a possibility to join the breakfast crew at racing station RSN.

Lyon’s name has been linked with a series of possibilities: Fox Footy, Seven and Channel 9.

McLachlan has also been earmarked as a caller by SEN, with an obvious vacancy existing should Anthony Hudson accept an offer to join rival 3AW.

Mclachlan is also in the running to replace Dennis Cometti as Seven’s Friday night partner for Bruce McAvaney.

The station is waiting for the release of next year’s fixture before announcing its line-up.

James Brayshaw is said to have placed a call to Seven bosses, sounding out the possibility of calling football next year, with Brayshaw having told friends he doesn’t expect to have a heavy cricket schedule this summer.

Could that mean he won’t be part of Nine’s summer of cricket team, a team that will welcome the polarising presence of Michael Clarke next month?

ANSWERED, SHANE

SHANE Watson was diplomatic when asked by MC Neil Mitchell about his relationship with Michael Clarke during the week at a CPA luncheon at Crown Casino. 

Rather than respond with kind to having been referred to as a “tumour in Australian cricket”, Watson basically played a straight bat, other than suggesting if given the chance he would happily nominate Clarke for Neale Daniher’s annual Big Freeze at the MCG. 

And if the Big Freeze was suddenly transferred to the Antarctic? 

Don’t think Watson would be too fussed if Clarke had to brave those rather more severe elements.

ROOS FOR UN?

3AW breakfast host Ross Stevenson jokingly suggested on Friday that Paul Roos had been approached by the United Nations as a late replacement for Ban Ki-moon when he steps down in December. 

Stevenson’s point was it’s about the only role Roos hasn’t been linked with, such is the respect with which he is held. 

And while the UN obviously won’t be happening, don’t discount him from a role with Fox Footy who have targeted Roos and Channel 7’s Matthew Pavlich as ideal talent for next year.

NO COACHING FOR SHANE

SHANE Warne, who was busy during the week at an opening of an Advanced Hair Studio in Dubai, becomes further removed from Australian cricket as our direction becomes dictated more and more by sports scientists. 

Warne has privately expressed the view that Australian cricket is being ruined by such types, and knows he will not be a coach at national level in the near future. 

The story goes he was approached to become involved with the national Twenty20 team, but was then told it couldn’t happen because he hadn’t acquired the appropriate level of coaching accreditation. 

PICK A WINNER

THERE aren’t too many worse feelings in racing than being the underbidder on a future champion. 

To date I’ve met five who should have bought So You Think, and triple Carlton-Premiership player Jimmy Buckley was a genuine underbidder when future champion two-year-old Rancher sold for $5000 in 1981. 

Then there is Bill Cockram, who in 2014 fell in love with a Myboycharlie filly but was outbid when Ciaron Maher paid $130,000 for the yearling. 

To Cockram’s credit he found Maher after the sale and asked could he buy into the filly, one that has since won $3.67 million in prizemoney, not to mention her stud value. 

The horse? Caulfield Cup winner Jameka.

COACHING CHANGES

THE days of Victorian Amateur Football Association clubs lacking a ruthless edge would seem well gone judging by the reaction of some well performed grand finalists. 

It starts in A Grade where Old Xavierians upset the odds (again) to win the flag before promptly parting ways with joint coaches Ted Woodruff and Pat Hawkins, replacing them with former Melbourne and GWS player James “Junior” McDonald. 

Drop down a few grades and the same scenario in D1, where Old Geelong Premiership coach Jon Knight has made way for triple Old Xavierians A grade coach Nick Bourke.
results.standFirst: ANDO’S SHOUT: TROUBLED AFL personality Garry Lyon is set to return to Melbourne’s airwaves and could be joined by Hamish McLachlan.

results.title: Boyd finally feels at home in AFL
results.subtitle: Tom Boyd finally feels he belongs at AFL level as he can match it physically with senior opponents
results.description: WESTERN Bulldogs million dollar man Tom Boyd finally feels like he belongs at AFL level after a breakthrough performance in the Grand Final.

thumbnailImage.title: Boyd finally feels at home in AFL
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 4f82aab0-98ca-11e6-83b2-5b92467cfebb
thumbnailImage.description: Boyd finally feels at home in AFL

results.seoHeadline: Tom Boyd finally feels he belongs at AFL level, breakthrough Grand Final premiership performance
results.body:
Boyd was one of the matchwinners for the Bulldogs in the drought-breaking premiership victory, starring with three goals from 14 disposals and eight marks playing up forward and in the ruck.

Much maligned throughout the season and in his first two years as a Bulldog after his high-profile switch from GWS to the Whitten Oval, Boyd has quietly been going about his business and developing his body for the rigours of AFL football.

While his hefty price tag has generated the most attention, Boyd’s hard work in the gym and on the training track to become a versatile big man is finally paying off and earning him attention of a different kind.

“Over the last pre-season increasing my running power (was a focus) and being my third year in the AFL I’m starting to feel like physically and aerobically I’m really matching it with the players that I’ve got to deal with,” Boyd said. “There are a lot of older backmen still playing in the league.

“That was the main thing, getting myself to a level of conditioning so I could compete week to week.

“I suppose from a consistency point of view it’s probably been my best year.

“There was a lot of improvement and it was great to cap off the year with a Grand Final win in an unbelievable set of circumstances. I’m really proud.”

Twelve months ago Boyd was playing VFL as the Western Bulldogs qualified for an unlikely finals appearance but now the 38-game veteran is a key part of coach Luke Beveridge’s team. 

ROUND 1: PIES, BULLDOGS SET FOR BLOCKBUSTER

GOOD FRIDAY: ROOS COULD HOST DOGS IN GAME ON HOLY DAY

SUPERCOACH: TRADED STARS TO KEEP AN EYE ON

He has found his niche as a tall forward who can go into the ruck, with his mobility around the ground making him the perfect modern-day back-up.

Boyd, 21, is working towards making that role more permanent, and will tailor his training over the pre-season to maintain strength and build on his endurance.

“I was really big when I was up there (GWS), I did a lot of weights and I was strong but you still need to be able to cover the ground,” Boyd told the club’s website.

“I’m somewhere in the middle — increasing my running power (is a focus) and finding a way to be strong enough and mobile enough to be able to play both ruck and forward is really important.”

Travis Cloke will join Boyd in the Bulldogs forward line next season, with the former Magpies All-Australian keen to start working with the young star.

The opportunity to join forces with the former No.1 draft pick, who earned votes for the Norm Smith Medal, was one of the main reasons why Cloke chose the Bulldogs as his new home.

“I’ve taken a bit of an interest in his football over the last few years, since he made the move to the Dogs, it’s been well publicised, the pressure that he’s under,” Cloke said. “He’s got so much potential and I’d love to help him out where I can.

“Sitting back and seeing the way Boydy played in that Grand Final was fantastic. For me to work with him and develop both our games together is what I’m here for.”
results.standFirst: WESTERN Bulldogs million dollar man Tom Boyd finally feels like he belongs at AFL level after a breakthrough performance in the Grand Final.
