results.seoHeadline: Moto3 grand prix crash video red flag: Riders crash out of Moto3 GP at Phillip Island
results.body:
The field was dropping down into MG Corner when bikes and riders spread across the track, bringing out the red flag.

Brit John McPhee was taken away by ambulance.

Enea Bastiannini was one of the riders taken down and was hit at the bottom of the hill by Andrea Migno.

MORE: All the action from Phillip Island

Jorge Navarro was the other entrant down in the chaos.

A total of 12 riders crashed in the opening five lap in a dramatic start.

The race was restarted but shortened to just 10 laps to go, South African Brad Binder emerging victorious.
results.standFirst: WE’VE had carnage in the Moto3 at Phillip Island, with 12 of the 34 riders involved in stacks in the first five laps. WATCH THE BIG CRASH HERE

results.title: Cahill goal puts A-League on world stage
results.subtitle: Tim Cahill’s wondergoal puts the Hyundai A-League on the world stage
results.subscriptionSummary: TWENTY-seven minutes into his first A-League game with Melbourne City, Tim Cahill scored a goal that made the world take notice.

thumbnailImage.title: Cahill goal puts A-League on world stage
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 0d6dba1c-9833-11e6-a368-50371b0b9b4a
thumbnailImage.description: Cahill goal puts A-League on world stage
thumbnailImage.imageName: A-League Rd 2 - Melbourne Victory v Melbourne City 614791648

results.body:
In England, it was 10.07am and Vincent Kompany, captain of City’s sister club Manchester City, was watching the Melbourne derby.

An excited Kompany retweeted a clip of Cahill’s goal before posting, “Congratulations @MelbourneCity with yesterday’s win. No better feeling than a derby win!” to his 2.66 million followers.

It was much earlier in New York, but former Melbourne City player David Villa, from another sister club, New York City, tweeted: “Congrats @MelbourneCity for a big win in the #MelbourneDerby #Cityfamily.”

In Shepparton this weekend, 1500 children are dreaming of replicating Cahill’s heroics at a massive annual junior tournament in AFL heartland.

Teams were turned away and all 3000 beds were booked out two months ago, forcing some families to stay in scout halls over an hour away and even over the border in NSW.

Football Federation Australia has struggled to convert the record two million soccer participants into A-League fans, but Cahill’s arrival has turbocharged the competition.

And the Socceroos superstar is aware of his all-encompassing role.

“I will be in among everything. People say my name and double-take and ask for photos, but this is what I’ve embraced and I feel comfortable,” Cahill said.

“I’ve taken heaps of photos with kids in Melbourne, around Southbank and it’s awesome. I want them to be able to have a connection with me and I don’t want to be this elusive guy. I want the kids to get what they see on TV.”

Melbourne City’s owner, City Football Group, identified Cahill as the missing piece of its Melbourne jigsaw, likening him to former French international player Patrick Vieira, now cutting his coaching teeth at New York City.

Sydney FC rejected CFG’s approach in 2013, so the Abu Dhabi group switched the focus of its Asian plans to Melbourne City.

CFG has invested more than $70 million in the club after buying it for $11.25 million in January 2014.

Cahill, who is a big name in China after stints at Shanghai Shenhua and Hangzhou Greentown, is a key part of the growth strategy, and City insiders say he made a huge impression on CFG chairman Khaldoon Al-Mubarak during a long meeting in Abu Dhabi six weeks ago.

Cahill is as comfortable moving in business circles as he is negotiating the penalty area, but his on-field exploits have opened the doors.

His ability to stand up on the big occasion is unparalleled and his derby goal rippled around Australia.

Tennis legend Lleyton Hewitt led the applause on Twitter: “We shouldn’t be surprised @Tim_Cahill You legend! #AgeIsNoBarrier.” And former cricket stars Adam Gilchrist (“Unbelievable @Tim_Cahill That’s why ... #MelbDerby”) and Brett Lee joined the chorus of approval.

High-profile recruits are not uncommon in the A-League, with Harry Kewell (Melbourne Victory), Alessandro Del Piero and Dwight Yorke (Sydney FC) among them, but no club has been better placed than Melbourne City to capitalise on Cahill’s widespread appeal. Signing and managing superstars is its forte — with Villa, Frank Lampard and Andrea Pirlo in New York and Sergio Aguero, Kevin De Bruyne, and Carlos Tevez in Manchester.In Cahill, City and the A-League could not have a better statesman. Three days before the Melbourne derby, on the morning after the Socceroos’ 1-1 draw with Japan, Cahill did three hours of interviews, photoshoots and autograph signing — all with a smile on his face, when many others would have lost it.

His arrival at City has come at a time of renewed calls for boldness from the game’s stakeholders and leaders, led by Socceroos boss Ange Postecoglou, who was influential in bringing him to the A-League.

Expansion is on the agenda. And a high-profile overseas club is understood to have shown interest in investing in the A-League.

With a new TV deal being negotiated, increased revenue streams and more blue-chip investment, the league is better placed than ever to attract stars.

Media outlets from the UK, France, Portugal, Spain, the US, Turkey and Sweden featured Cahill’s stunning derby goal, several years after Sydney FC’s signing of Italian star Del Piero won global exposure.

“Tim is our headline act and he put out a No. 1 hit single last Saturday night,’’ FFA chief executive David Gallop said. “He’s not a one-hit wonder, either. He puts them out nearly every time he goes on to the big stage. That goal went around the world and that showcases the 
A-League, and to get it in a Melbourne derby was magical.

“Domestically, it couldn’t have come at a better time as the season starts and the media rights negotiations are under way.’’

While many of his Socceroos golden generation teammates have fallen by the wayside, Cahill has not only survived but flourished under Postecoglou and become Australia’s record goalscorer. At 36, the carrot of playing in the 2018 World Cup in Russia is dangling before him.

“People watching now are waiting to see some sort of slip in standards or in his ability to do what he does, but he’s still there,” Postecoglou said.

“He’s still a very important part of what we do and more importantly, as everyone continues to see, he’s still very motivated.”

After a 3-2 loss to Perth Glory on Friday night, City hosts Adelaide United in the A-League on Friday nigh, but a bigger priority is beating Melbourne Victory on Tuesday in an FFA Cup semi-final, with CFG desperate for a piece of silverware.

Fox Sports commentator Andy Harper said the A-League had to leverage the Cahill effect.

“Tim’s probably repaid the investment with that one goal because that sets the benchmark for the league and his contributions,” he said. “It’s only one piece of the puzzle, and one of my ongoing laments of the league is a lack of a co-ordinated marketing and publicity and lack of imagination in taking stars like Bruno Fornaroli and Thomas Broich to the marketplace.

“We’ve relied on the Del Piero and Cahill factor and Timmy delivered big time. The challenge is to spread that load with a more concerted effort and make Fornaroli a big name in Melbourne and get people talking about Bruce Kamau.”

City may have made the big investment but the game — from Sydney to Shepparton and beyond — looks set to reap the rewards.

david.davutovic@news.com.au

results.title: The night Molly would rather forget
results.subtitle: The night that almost saw Molly Meldrum leave Australia for good
results.description: AT THE start of October 1995, Sony boss Denis Handlin called me in New York.
results.subscriptionSummary: IT was meant to be a night of celebration for one of the most influential men in Australia’s music history, but it almost saw Molly Meldrum leave Australia for good.

thumbnailImage.title: The night Molly would rather forget
thumbnailImage.subtitle: ca82d41a-9820-11e6-a368-50371b0b9b4a
thumbnailImage.description: The night Molly would rather forget
thumbnailImage.imageName: Ian "Molly" Meldrum at his home. Picture Bruce Ma

categories.value: /taxonomy/iptc.org/economy, business and finance/tourism and leisure/hotel and accommodation/

results.body:
“Mol,” he said, “we want you to come to Sydney for a party for Tina Arena. She’s doing a show, it’s also her birthday and we’re giving her an overseas award, which we’d like you to present to her.”

Denis then told me it was a secret — Tina knew nothing about the award. The only problem was, at the time of the planned gig, Polygram Records had organised an overseas trip for me to interview some of their artists for Hey Hey It’s Saturday. When I explained this to Denis, the line went silent.

“Right,” he said. “Leave it with me.”

When I got home, there was a message from Polygram Records, saying my trip had been postponed. 

I called Denis and told him I was good to go to Tina’s party.

I flew to Sydney and went to one of my favourite hotels. About 2pm, Steve Millard from Sony called to say he was coming to the hotel to keep me company and brief me on what was going to happen at the party. 

“Don’t worry about it,” I told Steve. “I’m just going to go to the hotel gym to work out.”

“I’ll come over and work out with you,” Steve said, which was a little strange because Steve had never worked out in his life.

Shortly after Steve’s call, Mushroom’s Denise D’Sylva rang and said she was also coming over.

So, with Steve and Denise by my side, my afternoon was swallowed up. Steve explained the plan: Tina’s event was happening in the ballroom at the Sebel Townhouse. 

After a meet and greet with the retailers, she’d perform a song and I’d then walk out with the award. 

“No problems,” I said. “A piece of cake, let the show begin.”

We drove over to the Sebel and I was ushered into a private room and miked up by the crew. In the function room, I could hear Denis making a speech and then introducing Tina. She sang and sounded brilliant, as usual. Then I walked out, carrying her very heavy crystal award. I then started making a speech and went to give Tina her award. But instead of taking the trophy, she launched into a speech about me. She said how much she loved me and how much I’d done for the industry. It was very flattering, but very embarrassing, so I grabbed the microphone and said, “Cut the crap, Tina, this thing’s heavy … I’ll have to throw it at you.”

Tina stopped, then looked at the crew and said, “Oh s---, I’m going to have to do this again?”

She then proceeded to make the same speech about how great I was. I thought the poor girl had lost her marbles.

Then, out of the corner of my eye, I saw Mike Munro creeping onto the stage. Aha, now it all made sense — they’re doing a This Is Your Life on Tina!

“Yes, go ahead,” I said to Mike, as I stepped back and started to walk off stage.

Tina looked suitably surprised and confused. Then Mike stepped in front of me and uttered seven words that totally shook me: “Ian ‘Molly’ Meldrum, This Is Your Life.”

I was so shocked, my legs literally gave way.

I couldn’t believe it. 

As I sat on the side of the stage, people were slapping me on the back, saying, “Congratulations! Congratulations!” But all I could think was, “What the f---’s going on? There’s no way they’re doing a This Is Your Life on me.” 

I kept saying, “No way, I’m not doing it!”

Much of it’s a blur now, but I remember someone saying, “Molly you have no option — the studio is full of all your friends and Channel Nine has spent a lot of money putting all this together.”

I felt like I was drowning.

I was driven to Channel Nine and given the VIP dressing room. But tonight it felt like a prison — I was trapped, and couldn’t get out to see what was going on.

Finally, the floor manager summoned me and I was taken to the side of the studio.

The doors slid open and I was greeted by Mike Munro’s grinning face. I tried to muster at least half a smile as Mike patted me on the back.

Now I was in the middle of a circus.

I know this sounds strange coming from a guy who’s been on TV for 50 years, but I’m actually a very private person. I’ve always shielded my family and friends from public scrutiny. I meant it when I said to Mike, “Over my dead body!” And on the show that night, I was slowly dying.

To be fair to Mike and my friends, they didn’t know the timing was bad — I was dealing with a lot of dramas at the time. I was arguing with Jan, the mother of my adopted son Morgan, over a few issues. And I was fighting with Peter Andre, trying to convince him to spend more time in Australia and focus on his career here. 

My friends thought the show was a wonderful tribute and a celebration of my life, and it was. I was being ungracious. But it was seriously the last thing I needed in my life at the time. I overreacted to just about everything — including Denise Drysdale claiming she was the first person to call me Molly. Of course, people have different memories, but 
I know for a fact that radio legend Stan “The Man” Rofe was responsible for my Molly name .

You know the drill on This Is Your Life — you hear a voice and then the screen slides back to reveal who it belongs to. Looking back, my friends and family actually had some funny things to say that night. 

I’d been trying for days to track down my mate and Mushroom boss Michael Gudinski. We needed to sort out our problems with Peter Andre, but I was told Michael was in London and couldn’t be contacted.

Then the screen slid back — and there was Michael. As we embraced, I hissed, “Mmmm, we’re in London, are we?” But my surprises didn’t end there. The next guest said: “I first met Molly five years ago when I was on . Molly was a judge and after my performance, he turned around and offered me a [recording] contract live on air. So he gave me my initial break and is responsible for where I am now. We’ve had our good times and our arguments, but he’s certainly the kind of person that if he believes in you, he’ll support you all the way.”

They were kind words, but I was furious. I’d been trying for days to speak with Peter Andre, calling him all around the world with no success. Now here he was, smiling and surprising me on This Is Your Life.

After the show, I also discovered there’d been some dramas backstage. Peter Andre apparently said something derogatory about Australia — that he didn’t care about the local market because he was breaking big in the UK. Deni Hines didn’t appreciate Peter’s attitude and she slapped him.

There was more drama in this one episode of This Is Your Life than an entire season of Neighbours.

Fortunately, Peter flew back to London that night, otherwise he would’ve copped a serve from me.

Just when I thought the night couldn’t get any worse, the door opened to reveal the night’s final guest: my 10-year-old adopted son, Morgan.

I was stunned and devastated. How could Morgan’s mum have allowed him to appear on national television?

Don’t get me wrong, I’ve always been so proud of Morgan. Morgan calls me Dad, and I’m proud to call him my son. But I have always protected him from the media. 

I’d been offered up to $60,000 to do “exclusive” stories with him, but declined every media request, except for a  story, which I did for free when Morgan was four, to make other magazines and reporters less interested in the story.

When the taping finished, I was fuming. And I was looking for someone to blame.

“Who the f--- organised this?”

I then spotted my boyfriend, Rui, in the audience. We’d only just started going out, and he was beginning to think he’d walked into a scene from One Flew Over The Cuckoo’s Nest — especially after the show, when he shared a taxi with me, Jan, Morgan and Denise Drysdale, and Jan and I had a horrible argument. Rui got out of the car and went straight to the airport, sleeping at the Ansett Lounge until the first flight back to Melbourne.

Denis Handlin had left the taping of the show to go to Tina’s birthday dinner at the Sebel, which was also the location for my “after party”. 

On the steps of the Sebel, Denis spotted Michael Gudinski, who warned him, “Denis, don’t go near Molly, all hell’s broken loose. It’s a disaster — the whole thing’s gone wrong. He hates all of us!”

But Denis, never one to take a backward step, went to find me. As soon as I saw him, I told him he’d ruined my life. 

 I ran out of the hotel, declaring, “That’s it, I’m leaving Australia for good!”

Worried about my wellbeing, Denis drove to all the local bars and clubs over the next few hours, trying to find me.

About 7 the next morning I called Denis at home. “That’s it,” I told him, “I’m quitting the industry. I’m leaving Australia. You’ll never see me again.” 

I slammed the phone down. Denis called me back; I hung up again. Over the next 90 minutes or so, we exchanged about a dozen calls.

Denis later told me it was “a ride through hell”.

I also called my oldest friend, Sandy. She tried to explain that my friends had organised the show because they loved me.

“Well, you’ve all had your 15 seconds of fame,” I spat, before I told her how much I hated her and that I was going to move to Bangkok.

“Well, p--- off then,” she said. 

When I flew home to Melbourne I immediately booked a flight to Bangkok. I called  producer, Pam Barnes.

“That’s it, I’m off.”

“You can’t,” Pam replied. “You’re doing Hey Hey this week.”

“F--- Hey Hey!”

Fortunately, Thailand has always been good for my health. After a week, I was again thinking straight, and felt ashamed about how I’d treated my friends. 

I might have overreacted.

The only thing I really objected to was Morgan’s appearance.

Funnily enough, to this day, Morgan says appearing on This Is Your Life with me is one of his proudest moments.

For me, well, it’s a night I’d rather forget. But as they say, time heals all wounds. About 18 months after my ill-fated appearance, I called Sandy — who later described the whole episode as “an unfortunate series of incidents” — with some news.

“Guess what I’ve got to do?  for Richard Tyler.”

Ah Well, Nobody’s Perfectby Molly Meldrum with Jeff Jenkins. Published Monday by Allen & Unwin. RRP $34.99
results.standFirst: IT was meant to be a night of celebration for one of the most influential men in Australia’s music history, but it almost saw Molly Meldrum leave Australia for good.

results.title: Jesinta pushing beauty and balance
results.subtitle: Jesinta Campbell says she owes Buddy Franklin ‘one hundred cuddles’ for allowing her to write her book
results.description: JESINTA Campbell’s is one of Australia’s most successful models, but she doesn’t diet and insists beauty comes in all shapes and sizes.
results.subscriptionSummary:
JESINTA Campbell’s is one of Australia’s most successful models, but she doesn’t diet and insists beauty comes in all shapes and sizes.Picture: Patricia Niven 
 Picture: Patricia Niven

thumbnailImage.title: Jesinta pushing beauty and balance
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 54f4d4f6-97fc-11e6-a368-50371b0b9b4a
thumbnailImage.description: Jesinta pushing beauty and balance
thumbnailImage.imageName: Live A Beautiful Life, Jesinta Campbell, Hachette

results.body:
Her new book, Live a Beautiful Life, reveals she starts the day with a Healing Turmeric Juice, has an Alkalizing Green Smoothie if her skin is breaking out and goes to bed dreaming of Matcha Energy Balls.

She is also passionate about exercise and advocates readers follow a punishing workout routine that involves a 15km bike ride along with 80 bum lifts, 120 reverse lunges and 100 deep squats on the first day.

Other beauty secrets of this former Miss Universe Australia include taking turmeric and black pepper tablets, drinking up to three litres of water a day and rubbing a mixture of vodka, bicarb soda and coconut oil on her skin.

Although she cooks most meals from scratch, Ms Campbell does rely on supplements like spirulina, Udo’s oil, fish oil and magnesium.

In the book, which will be released next week, she writes that she loves to leave the gym “a hot sweaty mess”.

“I push myself as hard as I can and leave nothing in the tank at the end,” she says.

Ms Campbell writes that she is “not ashamed to say” that she sees a mental health professional regularly.

“I’ve found it really helpful and I feel so much better after a session, I got to download all my worries and stresses,” she says.

She also details the “plethora of pressures” she’s faced, which include living a life in the public eye after winning Miss Universe Australia, media scrutiny and her fiance Buddy Franklin’s battle with mental illness.

Ms Campbell also says she was an ugly duckling at high school and bullied by the popular girls.

“As a teenager I was the girl with the longest school skirt, I wore glasses and had braces, was teased for being studious and called a teacher’s put on numerous occasions,” she writes.

Ms Campbell recounts a time at high school when one of the “popular pretty girls” excluded her when handing out invitations for her party.

“I remember feeling so small that day. I cried when I got home from school. I knew I hadn’t been invited because I didn’t drink and wasn’t cool and would have been seen as a downer at the party. I was only fifteen,” she writes.

The book, published by Hachette, is dedicated to Mr Franklin, whom she calls her “best friend and soulmate”.

“Thank you for not complaining once when the computer was set up in the lounge room for months on end as I typed away while you watched TV. I owe you one hundred cuddles for every time you went to bed and I stayed up working on this. X,” she writes.
results.standFirst: JESINTA Campbell reveals in her new book she doesn’t diet, starts her day with a Healing Tumeric Juice and owes Buddy “one hundred cuddles” for allowing her to work on her book.

results.title: Carrie Bickmore: why I find Christmas difficult
results.subtitle: Carrie Bickmore: why I find Christmas so difficult
results.description: A few weeks ago, I saw fruit mince pies in the supermarket. I felt two things upon seeing those delicious parcels of pastry. Firstly, isn’t it only September? And secondly, a pang in the pit of my tummy. It’s the same pang I feel every year. It’s not that I dislike Christmas. It has just always made me emotional.
results.subscriptionSummary: As an adult, I know exactly why I find Christmas hard. It’s the time of year I lost someone I loved dearly; it’s a time I am reminded of those wonderful humans who shaped my past but no longer sit at the table with us..

thumbnailImage.title: Carrie Bickmore: why I find Christmas difficult
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 51aa3022-9746-11e6-a368-50371b0b9b4a
thumbnailImage.description: Carrie Bickmore: why I find Christmas difficult

results.seoHeadline: Carrie Bickmore: Why Christmas packs a hefty emotional punch
results.body:
As a kid, I had many textbook-happy Christmases. In fact, I had only happy Christmases. Some years we’d have a big lunch at our house; other years we’d visit family interstate. Fishing in Port Lincoln, going to midnight mass, giggling as Mum belted out O Come, All Ye Faithful, eating pav and custard till I’d burst. 

There was always swimming. Oh, and randoms. Mum always invited people from church or the neighbourhood who had nowhere else to go. As kids it was equally as amusing as it was confusing that we had to pull a bonbon with people we didn’t really know. 

Whatever we did for the festive season, it was filled with lots of people and we created wonderful memories.

So why then did I always feel teary around Christmas? Lonely even. That sounds ridiculous, doesn’t it, given the experiences I just described? 

Maybe it was because our family was scattered across different states. My parents were divorced and lived on opposite sides of the country, so I could never be with both of them. Who knows what it was? 

As an adult, I know exactly why I find Christmas hard. It’s the time of year I lost someone I loved dearly; it’s a time I am reminded of those wonderful humans who shaped my past but no longer sit at the table with us. I miss their cinnamon-smelling hugs, their bad jokes, their funny Christmas videos. Christmas is not the same without them. Every day is not the same without them, but at Christmas it feels amplified. 

Don’t get me wrong, I still make Christmas fun for the kids. We spend weeks cooking bauble-shaped biscuits, making decorations; there are always presents under the tree and cousins to share their new toys with. But when I close my eyes feeling full and tipsy at the end of the day, the overwhelming feeling is one of relief. It’s over.

We are told how Christmas should make us feel, but for many that’s not the case. Life gets in the way. Death, financial stress, physical and mental illness, unresolved fights, the list is endless.

So as I walked through that supermarket feeling weird/sad/annoyed that Christmas had started in spring, I wondered: “What do we do… cancel Christmas?” 

I am not the Grinch. Can we ask supermarkets to at least wait till November? That’s not going to happen. Should we push advertisers to reflect the real Christmas, recognising the sadness, longing and loneliness some people must bear? Sadness doesn’t sell tinsel.

Maybe my mum had it right when she invited strangers to Christmas. It was always less about presents, decorations and indulgence, and more about inclusion, reaching out and offering the best gift possible – the chance for people not to feel lonely. 

I should count myself lucky I have a family to share fruit mince pies with. But I’ll buy mine in December. 

Carrie co-hosts The Project, 6.30pm weeknights, on Network Ten.
results.standFirst: WE ARE told how Christmas should make us feel, but for many that’s not the case, writes Carrie Bickmore. And it doesn’t help that the supermarket is already selling mince pies.

results.title: Ex-footballer ‘naked in garage’
results.subtitle: Ex-footballer fronts court after being found naked in a garage
results.description: A FORMER AFL player has appeared in court over a ­bizarre incident where his ex-lover found him naked in her garage.
results.subscriptionSummary: A FORMER AFL player has appeared in court over a ­bizarre incident where his ex-lover found him naked in her garage.

thumbnailImage.title: Ex-footballer ‘naked in garage’
thumbnailImage.subtitle: d8b79176-98af-11e6-90f6-b8531e8f57b9
thumbnailImage.description: Ex-footballer ‘naked in garage’

results.body:
The ex-footballer, who played for several Victorian clubs in the 1990s and 2000s, was found in the garage of a Heidelberg West unit on Friday night, sitting naked in a dog’s bed, the court heard. 

Victoria Police prosecutor Sgt Brooke Shears said the woman returned home around 7.30pm and heard noises coming from the garage. 

“The accused was sitting naked in the dog’s bed, grunting incoherently,” Sgt Shears said.

She said the accused called the woman “a wh---” and threatened to slash her tyres.

The man, in his 40s, said the statement was false and that he was only naked because he’d gotten caught in the rain.

“These aren’t even my clothes,” he said of the outfit he was wearing in court.

Magistrate Ross Betts refused the application for bail and the man continued to swear under his breath as he was led out of the dock. 

He was remanded to appear at the Heidelberg Magistrates’ Court on Friday.

bridget.davies@news.com.au
results.standFirst: A FORMER AFL player has appeared in court over a ­bizarre incident where his ex-lover found him naked in her garage.

results.title: Lucky escape as car ploughs into home
results.subtitle: No injuries as car ploughs into Lilydale home
results.description: AN elderly woman is lucky to be alive after a stolen car veered off the road and ploughed into her Lilydale home this morning, before the driver fled from the scene.

thumbnailImage.title: Lucky escape as car ploughs into home
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 97d3a45a-98b5-11e6-90f6-b8531e8f57b9
thumbnailImage.description: Lucky escape as car ploughs into home

results.body:
81-year-old Maureen DuBois was asleep in her bedroom when a silver ute ran off the road at 4.40am and smashed into her Beresford St house.

Maureen’s son, Jon DuBois said it was a narrow escape for his mother who lives by herself and who was only meters away from impact. 

“She’s shaken obviously, but she’s OK,” he told the Herald Sun. 

“The entire lounge room is absolutely demolished; it’s a big pile of rubble.”

Police are searching for a man they believe was involved in the incident.

“A car travelling east along the road has struck a parked vehicle then travelled over the nature strip, through two fences and into a house,” Victoria Police spokeswoman Natalie Webster said.

Ms DuBois was not injured in the incident but will stay with family tonight.
results.standFirst: AN elderly woman is lucky to be alive after a stolen car veered off the road and ploughed into her Lilydale home this morning, before the driver fled from the scene.

results.title: Best-kept secrets of Loddon Mallee South
results.subtitle: Little-known must-visit spots in Victoria’s Loddon Mallee South region
results.description: THINK you know the best the Loddon Mallee south region has to offer?
results.subscriptionSummary:
THINK you know the best the Loddon Mallee south region has to offer? 
 We’ve searched high and low to find the hidden gems across our great state.

thumbnailImage.title: Best-kept secrets of Loddon Mallee South
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 60ac01e6-9759-11e6-83b2-5b92467cfebb
thumbnailImage.description: Best-kept secrets of Loddon Mallee South

results.seoHeadline: Victoria’s hidden gems: Loddon Mallee South, secret hot spots, sights, cafes, shops
results.body:
We’ve searched high and low to find the hidden gems across our great state.

From secret swimming holes to a hip wall-to-wall wine bar, here’s some lesser-known gems this Victorian hub has to offer.

HIDDEN GEMS OF MELBOURNE’S WEST

65 Brooke St, Inglewood.agedbeef.com.au

Fans of Inglewood Aged Beef think nothing of a four-hour round trip from Melbourne to buy some of the best beef and lamb in Victoria. Inglewood is famous for links to the eucalyptus oil industry, but a humble corner butcher — selling aged beef and Rockwood lamb direct from the farmer — has people flocking.

11 View St, Bendigo

Not all vintage stores are created equal. And Julie’s is one of the state’s best. It’s like a long-forgotten suitcase of grandma’s best dresses, bursting with vintage goodness. The store is filled with quality pieces; from heavy, one-off fur jackets and intricately beaded 1920s flapper dresses, to real rabbit collars, devoré silk velvet wraps, polka-dot chiffon dresses and retro jewellery. 

9 Walker St, Castlemaine.millcastlemaine.com.au

It’s hard not to be transported to Vienna in the opulent surroundings of Das Kaffeehaus. The cafe is in a revitalised precinct near the old Castlemaine Woollen Mill that features a brewery, sourdough bakery and vintage and makers’ market. The cafe serves dishes such as goulash, sausage and boiled eggs with soldiers — and maybe the meanest coffee in regional Victoria.

Bridgewater

The Loddon River is the lifeblood of the town of Bridgewater. On the water, there is a dedicated ski area, as well as a slalom and ski jump area. But it’s the pretty swimming hole — with a grassy picnic area, deck and bathing platform, and barbecue — that’s one of Victoria’s best secret spots for a hot day. 

Cnr Sailors Gully and Peg Leg roads, Eaglehawk. starcinema.org.au

If the thought of watching an arthouse film on the big screen — sitting on a comfy couch with a glass of wine — sounds appealing, add Star Cinema to the bucket list. The cinema, in the Eaglehawk Town Hall, is run by volunteers and uses the hall’s original projection room. 

Boort-Pyramid Rd, Boort

It plays second fiddle to better-known Lake Boort next door, but Little Lake Boort is just as pretty. The best way to see the lake is via a 3.7km trail, which takes about an hour. Nearby Lake Boort Reserve is Australia’s largest scarred tree site, with about 900 trees scarred by the Dja Dja Wurrung people. 

Terrick Terrick National Park, Mitiamo.parkweb.vic.gov.au

Apart from a few silos or majestic gums, the landscape at Mitiamo, between Bendigo and Echuca, is pretty unremarkable — until Mitiamo Rock comes into view. The 187m granite outcrop rises above the plains, offering panoramic views of farmland and bush. The rock is a great nature-based day out. 

50 Station St, Clarkefield

Located on a dead-end street off the Melbourne-Lancefield Rd, the Coach and Horses Inn is becoming known as one of Victoria’s most haunted hotels. Legend has it a Chinese man who was hung and an Irishman shot out the front visit the two-storey bluestone hotel.

results.seoHeadline: Templestowe bus crash: truck and van involved in collision
results.body:
A 40-year-old man was trapped in the mangled wreckage of the bus, but ambulance crew managed to get him out and he has been taken to Austin Hospital with leg injuries.

Another two passengers have also been taken to hospital. The extent of their injuries are not known at this stage but they are believed to be in a stable condition.

The collision was on the corner of Foote St and Williamsons Rd at 11.50am.

A woman who was on the bus, which was carrying only a few passengers, was treated by paramedics but wasn’t taken to hospital.

Doncaster police were on site directing traffic.

The driver of the van was taken to hospital with injuries. He is in a stable condition.

More to come.
results.standFirst: SEVERAL people have been taken to hospital after a bus, a truck and a van collided at a junction in Melbourne’s east.

results.title: Car ploughs into man in front yard
results.subtitle: Car ploughs into man and son in Corio front yard
results.description: A MAN has been flown to hospital after a car ploughed through a brick fence and into the yard of a Geelong home.

thumbnailImage.title: Car ploughs into man in front yard
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 0c5800b8-935d-11e6-be1d-605c61a8be5f
thumbnailImage.description: Car ploughs into man in front yard

results.body:
The man and a teenage boy were in the yard of a Corio house when the Holden Commodore struck the front fence before hitting the pair.

The car then continued on over a garden bed before coming to rest against a garage roller door at the Kosciusko Ave property.

The teenager was treated at the scene by paramedics.

Detectives from the police Major Collision Investigation Unit are expected to be on the scene this afternoon as an investigation gets underway into how the female driver lost control of the car.

Victoria Police spokeswoman Amelia Penhall said a 42-year-old man had been flown to hospital with serious injuries following the crash, which occurred about 12.35pm. 

“The female driver of the car has been taken to hospital with minor injuries and is assisting police with their inquiries,” Ms Penhall said. 

Anyone with information on the collision is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

andrea.hamblin@news.com.au

results.title: Turnbull delivery begins at last
results.subtitle: Peta Credlin: Malcolm Turnbull’s delivery begins at last
results.description: AFTER a poor campaign and an unsteady start to the term, the Turnbull Government  is starting to make headway. But as last week showed, its wins risk being overshadowed by avoidable mistakes and Labor’s clever politics.
results.subscriptionSummary: AFTER a poor campaign and an unsteady start to the term, the Turnbull Government  is starting to make headway. But as last week showed, its wins risk being overshadowed by avoidable mistakes and Labor’s clever politics.

thumbnailImage.title: Turnbull delivery begins at last
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 23e2329c-92a6-11e6-bdcd-5e2af82bec59
thumbnailImage.description: Turnbull delivery begins at last

results.seoHeadline: Peta Credlin on Malcolm Turnbull
results.body:
On the plus side of the ledger, the Government passed legislation protecting volunteer firefighters from union control, and giving tax cuts to middle-income earners.

These are sensible changes which fulfil commitments the Coalition made at the last election. These wins should be cause for quiet confidence among all of us that this term might actually be, as the Prime Minister has pledged, one of “delivery”.

Unfortunately, by week’s end “own goals” from the Government overshadowed their legislative achievements and yet again put the spring in Labor’s tactical step.

COALITION EMBARRASSED AFTER CRITICISING ITSELF IN OPPOSITION MOTION

ANDREW BOLT: MALCOLM TURNBULL TRAPPED IN NO-MAN’S LAND

Financial Services Minister Kelly O’Dwyer has been in the parliament for eight years and is a Cabinet minister. She’s no rookie but she keeps making rookie mistakes. This surprises me as she’s a former senior staffer and she’s smart. But letting Labor embarrass you by passing a second reading amendment isn’t smart. And not being ready for one is dumb because second reading amendments are the stock in trade of Oppositions. After all, we used them often.

Minister O’Dwyer claimed it was just a “procedural mistake” and Leader of the House Christopher Pyne called it a mere “inadvertent error”. Seriously. It is not a sackable offence despite Labor’s overreach but as we’re told this is the first time its happened in more than 100 years, it’s not “nothing” either. 

Added to the lost votes in the first sitting week and the failure to have any real business for the Senate to get on with in the second week, it reinforced the impression of a Government that’s not quite on top of things.

With Christmas comes the reshuffle season and everyone in Canberra knows that Malcolm Turnbull has a short fuse and doesn’t suffer fools. With the House back next week and only a handful of sitting weeks left this year, both O’Dwyer and Pyne need to lift their game in the chamber. Calling them stunts is all well and good but when the news bulletins run the chaos story before any hard-won achievements, then the Government’s got a problem that must be fixed.

But this wasn’t the only error.

By giving four federal seats to the Coalition, the Victorian Labor Government’s attempt to bully volunteer fire fighters helped save Malcolm Turnbull’s prime ministership. The Coalition’s legislation stopping industrial agreements from restricting the work of volunteers is common sense. As well as the actual policy substance, being able to get something through the difficult Senate is a real achievement and protecting the 60,000 Victorian Country Fire Authority volunteers from operational emasculation was a great win for the Coalition.

But Channel 7’s report on this good news focused not on the win but on another stuff-up: there was an ACT fire truck at the Government’s media event for which no official permission had been obtained. 

Perhaps the PM’s staffers anticipated a refusal from ACT authorities and decided to risk it and go ahead anyway. Savvy operators would have held the event just 10 minutes across the border in Queanbeyan where a fire truck could have turned up with the blessing of the NSW Coalition Government. It was another unforced error for a Government that can’t afford to have its good news dropped out of the bulletin by elementary mistakes.

Still, there are signs that the Turnbull team is finding its line and length. Julie Bishop had a standout week in Question Time and put Bill Shorten under real pressure.

Again there are calls for her to help out domestically not just overseas. The PM is becoming more assured in parliament and on a good day, the waffle is subdued. More importantly, he’s been focusing on something that matters to everyday people, namely keeping the power on and prices low.

When the lights went out across South Australia, Turnbull ignored his previous enthusiasm for renewable energy at any price and instead attacked the state government, and Labor more generally, for putting their green obsession ahead of jobs and cost of living. 

South Australia now gets 40 per cent of its power from renewable energy. That’s on a good day. On a bad day — when the wind doesn’t blow or blows too hard — it relies on energy imported from the brown coal power stations of Victoria.

And that’s the problem with renewables — you’ve got to have a backup for when the wind doesn’t blow or the sun doesn’t shine. There has to be enough non-renewable baseload capacity in the system to kick-in on the days when renewable energy isn’t there. 

No power company can rely on renewable energy alone or even mainly. Labor knows that cost of living matters to voters. That’s why every Question Time last week started with claims that the Government is cutting Medicare. It reinforces the dishonest scare campaign that was so effective during the election and their questions get under the Prime Minister’s skin. 

But Labor is fooling itself if it thinks that it can promise 50 per cent renewable energy and a 45 per cent cut in emissions by 2030 without consumers noticing. Energy Minister Josh Frydenberg said this week that it would cost nearly $50 billion to build enough windmills. Coupled with much more ambitious emissions targets, this means a carbon tax.

Sooner or later, Labor’s effective populism is going to collide with its actual policies. You can’t further boost renewable energy without skyrocketing power prices. You can’t increase taxes, even on so-called wealthy investors, without making ordinary people pay. Sooner or later, Opposition Leader Bill Shorten will have to confront the unions and the green-left activists within his own party and tell them that they can’t have everything they want. Or he’ll stay in opposition.

Right now Bill Shorten’s not under any policy pressure but if the Government was on its strategic game, this is where they should take the fight. That, and smartening up their collective act so that dumb mistakes are a thing of the past.

THUMBS UP

NSW Premier Mike Baird did the right thing reversing his greyhound racing ban. We can’t demand our political leaders listen to us and then criticise them when they do.

THUMBS DOWN

The race for the US presidency should be a contest of the best and brightest. It isn’t. Neither candidate is outstanding but Donald Trump’s repeated offensive slurs against women show how unworthy he is. It’s over, Donald.
results.standFirst: IT HASN’T been all plain sailing for Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull but good signs are starting to emerge, writes Peta Credlin.

results.title: Fire Brigade leaders jump ship
results.subtitle: Metropolitan Fire Brigade in crisis as leaders jump ship
results.description: THE Metropolitan Fire Brigade has lost 70 years of experience in a month as half its senior leadership team quit on the eve of the fire season.
results.subscriptionSummary: THE Metropolitan Fire Brigade has lost 70 years of experience in a month as half its senior leadership team quit on the eve of the fire season.

thumbnailImage.title: Fire Brigade leaders jump ship
thumbnailImage.subtitle: a57e7dca-92be-11e6-bdcd-5e2af82bec59
thumbnailImage.description: Fire Brigade leaders jump ship

results.body:
Chief officer Peter Rau, deputy chief officer David Youssef, people and culture executive director Danielle Byrnes and property and assets executive director Craig Lloyd have all resigned.

Assistant chief fire officers Darren Davies and Andrew Zammit are also on indefinite leave amid a growing exodus linked to ongoing tensions with the United Firefighters Union.

Emergency Management Commissioner Craig Lapsley admitted he was concerned at the string of departures after the CFA lost its board, chief executive and chief fire officer over the bitter industrial dispute.

“It’s a concern ... because I’ve got a changing team, so I’ve got to work harder at ensuring that the teams we operate in ... achieve great results,” Mr Lapsley said.

He said he was conscious of the need to strengthen co-operation with the CFA and MFB’s new leaders, adding there had been “a lot of noise” about instability but there was depth in the ranks.

“When the call to action is there, in the preparedness or the response, they’ll be there and they’ll do it extremely well,” Mr Lapsley said.

He said recent “bumper rainfalls” had led to significant growth in fuel loads, paving the way for “critical fire days” once dry conditions set in.

Mr Lapsley said grass fires loomed as the biggest danger this summer and urged people to cut the fuel around their homes and properties.

Opposition Leader Matthew Guy said the departure of MFB bosses — who he said were on a UFU “hit list” — meant the fire services were missing 300 years of collective senior experience.

“On the eve of fire season, Victoria is haemorrhaging emergency services professionals because of Daniel Andrews’ pigheadedness,” Mr Guy said. “Victorians will be right to question whether they are more or less safe on the eve of fire season.”

The government said: “Victoria’s fire fighters are among the best in the world and are well prepared for the coming fire season.”

It comes as the MFB begins its search for a new chief officer after Peter Rau quit and filed a WorkSafe complaint about alleged bullying by the UFU.

The decision will be politically difficult, given acting chief fire officer Paul Stacchino raised the ire of government MPs last month when he slammed the brigade’s current workplace agreement with the UFU, saying parts of it were unworkable.

He told a parliamentary inquiry the union’s new log of claims would give them “an effective veto” and limit his powers.

The government said recruitment decisions were a matter for the MFB.

tom.minear@news.com.au
results.standFirst: THE Metropolitan Fire Brigade has lost 70 years of experience in a month as half its senior leadership team quit on the eve of the fire season.

Premier Daniel Andrews warned UFU boss behaviour unacceptable

results.body:
As we crossed the road and walked past the SCG, we peeked through to the Sheffield Shield game, which had started. South Australia were batting, and ­Hughesy was opening. If there’s going to be one silver lining to all of this, it might be that Hughesy gets my Test place.

As we look through the gate, I see that he is into the twenties. Perfect! I’ll go home for a shower and change, then come back to watch him bat. I know he’s in for a big one. He loves punishing his old Blues teammates. He’ll make a hundred and the selectors will have to pick him. 

When I get out of the shower, there are five missed calls on my phone. Strange. A couple are from Malcolm Conn, at Cricket NSW. 

Malcolm and I go a long way back. When he was chief cricket writer for The Australian and then The Daily Telegraph, we would be blueing one minute about something he’d written, and the next minute we would be collaborating, with him ghostwriting my columns for the paper. It typifies the up-and-down relationship I’ve had with the media through my career. 

Malcolm has now moved from journalism to our side of the fence, as a communications officer for Cricket NSW and Cricket Australia. 

I’m moving around my bedroom getting my things ready to go. “What’s going on?” I ask Mal.

His voice is flat. “Have you heard about Hughesy?” 

“What?” I laugh. “Has he got a hundred already?”

“He’s been hit on the head and a helicopter’s about to land on the SCG.”

I stop moving. I’m almost too shocked to speak. “Is he all right?”

“We don’t know.”

Everything else empties out of me. All the arguments that have been spinning around my head for days and weeks, everything that has been driving me crazy and putting the cricket world into a lather — it’s all gone. There’s nothing in me except one thought: Hughesy.

I must run every red light between home and the inner city. I’m going like a race car driver. 

In the car, I speak to Dave Thompson, the Cricket NSW operations manager.

“He’s not at the SCG,” he says.

 “Where’s he been taken?” 

“He’s been put in an ambulance and is going to St Vincent’s ­Hospital.”

I whiz to St Vincent’s, which is only a few minutes from the SCG. Out of my mind, I park in the ambulance area and run into emergency. Tim Nielsen, my old Cricket Australia coach who’s now South Australia’s head of high performance, and some other SA Cricket people are there.

“Where is he?” I say to Tim.

Before he can reply, a member of the hospital staff grabs me. “He’s been taken for a CT scan. Come through, his family’s in here.”

As I’m being taken to the room where they are waiting, Hughesy is being wheeled past on a trolley. He looks normal. There’s still a sheen of sweat on his face, and his hand, when I hold it, is hot. He has a scratch on his face from where he fell forward onto the pitch. I notice a little bit of facial swelling, but not much. My first thought is, he’ll be right.

Hughesy’s mum Virginia, his brother Jason and his sister Megan are all in tears. When I come into the room, they get up and we’re just ­hugging and crying for a long time. Virginia’s asking me a lot of questions about what happens next. I don’t have a clue. All I can say is “he’s in the best hands”. 

They begin explaining the shot Hughesy was playing when he was hit. NSW were bowling short to stop Hughesy scoring. He went to hook a bouncer but got through his shot too early. The ball hit him in the back of his head or the top of his neck, just beneath the rim of his helmet. He was 63 not out.

At this stage, we’re unaware of what is going on in the outside world. Everything has shrunk down to this hospital ward. We don’t know that they have called off the game entirely, as none of the players could bring themselves to go back on the field. 

Nor do we know that the full round of Sheffield Shield matches around the country, and the Indians’ game in Adelaide, will be abandoned. It’s not the time for cricket. Nor will it be for a long while.

When Hughesy is taken up to the next floor for more scans, we follow and are put in another waiting room. It’s all a blur. Virginia’s barely able to speak, she’s crying so much. Greg, Hughesy’s dad, is up at his farm near Macksville on the north coast. 

Someone has rung to organise him a flight down, but there are no seats out of Coffs Harbour, so the plans have been changed and he’s driving to Port Macquarie to fly from there. 

A surgeon comes to us, sits us down, and says, “We’ve had the scan results. There’s been a bleed and we’ve got to release the swelling as quickly as possible.” In order to do so, they have to ­operate.

Time dissolves. I don’t know how long has passed. After the surgery, the doctor comes out and tells us the ­operation hasn’t been able to slow the swelling. ­Hughesy’s family are suffering ­intensely, and the doctor isn’t sure that they’re able to take in what he’s telling them.

“Michael,” he says, “Can we have a word privately?”

He wants to take me aside and spell it out, so that I can pass it on to them. He thinks there’s a better chance that they will be able to focus on what I’m saying. The swelling’s going up, he explains.

I keep asking, “Can you give me more information?” 

I am feeling kind of clear on the outside, but empty within, like what he’s saying is just echoing around inside me. I need to hear it more than once before I can comprehend it.

The doctor tells me that there is a lot of swelling in Hughesy’s brain, and they need to release it. They will operate again and then place him in an induced coma.

After a few more hours of waiting, we jump to our feet as the doctor reappears. He says the news is better. “The swelling has slowed down, which is a good sign. We’re going to keep him in the coma overnight and see how much more it comes down. We’ll keep our fingers crossed, but won’t know much until the morning.”

By now it is eight or nine in the evening, about six hours since ­Hughesy was hit. Inside the waiting room, Greg has arrived and the family go through periods of quiet. Outside, the corridors are silent. I pace up and down the corridor outside ­Hughesy’s room for hours. ­

At about 3.30am, I find my car and drive home. I’m only thinking, Will he be right to play cricket again? That’s all. I’m still focused on cricket, nothing bigger than that. 

I lie on my bed, and my mind is still squirrel-wheeling around in this little circle. Will he be OK for the Test match? If not, will he be right for the Second Test? I’m not reflecting on Hughesy and our friendship. That would be like allowing too much in. I can only focus on what the doctors will tell us tomorrow.

Trying to sleep is pointless. At 5.30am, I’m back in the car. At St ­Vincent’s, ­Hughesy’s family are where I left them, going through lulls in between bouts of crying.

It’s midmorning when a doctor comes in and tells us there has been a change since the optimistic news last night. They can’t control the swelling and have increased his medication. 

We don’t know what to do or say. But every piece of news that doesn’t say, he’ll be OK, he’ll be playing again soon, is shattering. After staying with the family for a while, I go back in and see him. Last night, his face was swelling up but he was still recognisable, still Hughesy. Now, in the morning, he’s much more puffed up.

This is the first time I look back at him and see that it isn’t him. He is still breathing, through the tube feeding oxygen into his mouth, but it isn’t him. He doesn’t have that typical warm Hughesy sweat across his forehead and cheeks, like he had yesterday. The beat of his heart and the flow of oxygen — it’s like the machine is doing it, keeping him alive, more than his own body is.

I stay in the room with him for a fair while. Hours. I just hold his hand and urge him to come back to us. Am I saying goodbye? No. I’m fogged up by shock, just saying the same encouraging words over and over again. If I move off from that topic, I talk about cricket: how he’s going to play in the Test match, how I’ve lost my battle with CA, but we’re going to get justice because Hughesy’s going to go out there as my replacement and score a hundred. No, a double hundred.

Later, we will be told that on impact, in that split second when the ball hit him, he was effectively gone. I won’t be able to accept that. That’s too tough for me to take. 

Right through that first afternoon and evening in hospital, for all the hours I’ve been talking to him, I’ve never let anything like this filter into my head. It’s only cricket. He might be out of the game for a few weeks. But he can’t die.

I know what my friendship with Phillip Hughes was. Over the days following his passing, my role as Australian captain overlapped with my personal grief at losing one of my best mates. It was hard to separate the two. 

Managing the scene in the hospital, bringing players together, giving a eulogy at his funeral, and then, after long negotiations, taking the field in a Test match two weeks later — I had no chance to retreat into my private space and grieve for the bloke I regard as my little brother.

My Story — Michael Clarke, published by Macmillan Australia, is out on Tuesday. Be one of the first 200 readers to buy My Story for $39.95 and receive a signed copy. 
Order at heraldsun.com.au/shop or call 1300 306 107 from 10am on Monday

results.title: Brown walks out on Pies for Saints
results.subtitle: Collingwood defender Nathan Brown has joined St Kilda as a free agent
results.description: COLLINGWOOD’S backline stocks have taken another hit with 2010 premiership defender Nathan Brown walking out on the club.

thumbnailImage.title: Brown walks out on Pies for Saints
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 65ac29ba-9343-11e6-be1d-605c61a8be5f
thumbnailImage.description: Brown walks out on Pies for Saints

results.seoHeadline: Nathan Brown Collingwood trade: St Kilda
results.body:
Brown has agreed to join St Kilda as a free agent, with the Magpies confirming they would not match the Saints’ offer. 

Brown played 130 matches across nine seasons in the black and white.

St Kilda chief operating officer Ameet Bains said the experienced defender is a welcome addition to the Saints.

“Nathan is a handy acquisition for the club and will obviously strengthen our defence,” Bains said.

“Bringing Nathan in as a free agent also allows us to fill a key need without compromising our overall trade position; an important consideration given the trades we have completed during this exchange period.

“His ability to hold down a key defensive post makes him an attractive prospect for where our list is currently placed.

“In addition to his experience and leadership on the field, Nathan is a terrific person off the field and we look forward to him joining our ranks.”

Brown’s departure is another blow for the Pies who have now lost three key position defenders this off-season. 

Jack Frost requested a trade to Brisbane after the Lions offered him a three-year contract. The Pies and Lions are expected to agree on a deal this week. 

Promising youngster Jonathon Marsh informed the Pies last week he wanted to return home to Perth for personal reasons. 

Small defender Marley Williams is currently without a contract. 

Matthew Scharenberg and Tom Langdon are recovering from long term injuries while Alan Toovey has retired.

That leaves Collingwood to rely on Ben Reid, who has played 26 matches across the past three seasons, and Lachie Keeffe who is returning from a one-year suspension. 

The Pies were initially hoping Keeffe would partner Darcy Moore in the Collingwood forward line but that may need a rethink. 

The Magpies have been busy this trade period, with Daniel Wells and Chris Mayne joining the club. 

Travis Cloke will be traded to the Western Bulldogs this week.
results.standFirst: COLLINGWOOD defender Nathan Brown has played his last game for the Magpies. Brown has joined St Kilda as a free agent.

results.title: Four dead as truck lands in park
results.subtitle: Four dead when a pick-up truck drives off bridge and lands in a crowded park
results.description: A PICKUP truck plunged 18 metres off a bridge in California and landed on a crowd gathered at a park below, leaving at least four people dead.

thumbnailImage.title: Four dead as truck lands in park
thumbnailImage.subtitle: f9d6fb1e-9349-11e6-bdcd-5e2af82bec59
thumbnailImage.description: Four dead as truck lands in park

results.seoHeadline: San Diego, California: four dead as truck lands in Chicone Park
results.body:
The truck veered off the Coronado Bay Bridge in San Diego on Saturday afternoon (Sunday AEST) and landed in Chicano Park where a biker rally was being held, Fox San Diego reported.

California Highway Patrol (CHP) Officer Jake Sanchez said the person behind the wheel of the pick-up truck, suspected of driving under the influence, hit a guard rail, rolled and landed on the crowd of people, NBC San Diego reported.

“It’s horrible, it’s horrific,” said Sanchez, describing the scene. “There’s people down below, bodies — just innocent people that are just down here having a good time and now they’re gone. We feel for their families.”

Witnesses said the truck landed on a vendor tent set up for La Raza Run, a motorcycle ride that ends with a celebration at the park and typically draws hundreds of participants. the crash happened in front of a stage where a rockabilly band was playing.

“I saw a truck come right off the freeway. It was going so fast it flow over the stage and landed in front of the stage on a tent, a booth that was set up," Chase Dameron told San Diego Union-Tribune.

He said four people in the booth were crushed by the pickup.

“It was like a movie. It was like in slow motion,” Dameron said. “Where it hit, there was dust and debris and instant chaos and panic. People running crazy.”

Dameron’s friend, George Rodriguez, said, “It’s something I won’t forget as long as I live.”

A witness told NBC San Diego that he heard truck’s tyres screeching as it ploughed into the park below.

“I [saw] that truck come flying off the ramp here and onto the people that were underneath hem. I was that close to them,” he said. “It’s terrible.”

Another witness said she saw parts of the car being scattered everywhere.

“Pieces of car parts were flying all over the place. When we got up, we turned around, everybody started running over there because we realised, there were people sitting there — there were people sitting right there,” the woman told NBC San Diego.

“We were trying to get in to see if we could maybe lift up the car, move the car out of the way to see if we could get the people out. There were so many people crowded by then.

San Diego Fire-Rescue Department spokesman Lee Swanson said the truck driver suffered major trauma and is now being treated for his injuries. Along with the driver, another person was also seriously hurt, while five others suffered minor injuries, Swanson said.

The injured victims were taken to either UC-San Diego or Scripps Mercy hospitals for treatment.
results.standFirst: A PICKUP truck plunged 18 metres off a bridge in California, and landed on a crowd gathered at a park below, leaving at least four people dead.

results.title: Dogs not happy with Libba antics
results.subtitle: Western Bulldog Tom Liberatore hasn’t changed since winning an AFL premiership
results.description: THE Western Bulldogs will make contact with Tom Liberatore in Vietnam to discuss his outrageous off-season antics.

thumbnailImage.title: Dogs not happy with Libba antics
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 4c126fa4-933a-11e6-b17b-cefc9a8ab3fc
thumbnailImage.description: Dogs not happy with Libba antics

results.seoHeadline: Tom Liberatore video: Western Bulldogs star’s weird haircut in AFL off-season
results.body:
Footage emerged over the weekend of the premiership Bulldog playing in the AFL Asia competition.

Liberatore was snapped on the bench having his head shaved, but also taking a ruck hitout and kicking a goal.

Bulldogs list manager Jason McCartney today said the club would remind Liberatore of his responsibility as a contracted player during the off-season.

“Definitely. Definitely the club I’d imagine will be making contact with him just to... as a contracted player, and he’s come off an ACL 12 months ago, you’re not supposed to be doing those things,” McCartney told RSN.

“You can’t put yourself at risk so I’m sure someone will be just reminding him that enjoy the next six weeks but no more footy, mate.” 

Liberatore might be in hot water with the Dogs, but he’s a hit on social media.
