results.seoHeadline: Victoria’s hidden gems: Gippsland hidden hot spots, Melbourne
results.body:
Here’s the list of the best hidden gems Gippsland has to offer.

Check back tomorrow for more hidden gems from a different region.

MORE: HIDDEN GEMS IN MELBOURNE’S CBD

RELATED: MELBOURNE BAR AMONG WORLD’S BEST

MORE: WHY EVERYONE WANTS A GOON SUIT

BURGER BEST: WHERE TO FIND MELBOURNE’S BEST VEGGIE BURGER

3260 South Gippsland Hwy, Tooradin.wingsandfins.com.au

Tooradin Airport has a joy flight like no other — delivery of live crayfish from Flinders Island. Nola de Lorenzo, who runs the airport’s Wings and Fins bistro, says: “Soon as those crays hit the tarmac, we’re loading them on to forklifts and getting them into tanks.’’ Locals have long known about Tooradin’s crayfish sales but as word spreads — thanks to an appearance on Channel 9 show The Hotplate — de Lorenzo is cooking and serving more cold-water crustaceans than ever. 

parkweb.vic.gov.au

Pristine and untamed, Croajingolong National Park is perfect for beachcombing, birdwatching and boating. But between river and ocean, near Cann River, there is a network of sandy trails that visitors to this corner of Gippsland often overlook. The Thurra River sand dunes soar 30m high in places, offering spectacular views of Croajingolong’s wilderness coastline. And while camping options close by are plentiful, you can also stay in a clifftop keeper cottage at Point Hicks lighthouse. Whale sightings are common. 

71 Tarraville Rd, Port Albert.

A sleepy seaside village it might be, but Port Albert, Gippsland’s oldest port (c. 1841), has a gem of an eatery in its midst. To bypass the Port Albert Cafe and Wine Bar is to miss some of the best fish and chips in all of South Gippsland, not to mention the display of humungous cakes that proprietor Kim Wherrett makes almost daily. Then there’s the cellar. Wherrett — just as likely to be in the kitchen as serving dishes — has sourced almost every wine from Gippsland 

and sells them by the glass. 

Neerim South.neerimbower.com.auvisitvictoria.com

Deep in the rolling green hills of West Gippsland, Neerim South is your typical country town. Or is it? There’s nothing typical about the bright blue sculpture that frames the town as you drive in. The Neerim Bower was inspired by birds and conceived by local artists. But its creation in 2014, as part of Victoria’s Small Town Transformations program, has encouraged other artistic projects in the district.

Freestone Creek Rd, Briagolong. 

It’s an open secret down Briagolong way that Blue Pool is one of Victoria’s best places for cooling down ... and jumping into. But out-of-towners are still discovering this Gippsland waterhole north of Maffra and falling for its aquatic charms. The emerald-green colour of the water comes from Freestone Creek winding its way through rain-soaked forest. 

75A Nicholson St, Bairnsdale. ifoundthefoundry.com

Foundry hides its light under a considerable bushel. To find this unusual retail store, you go down a lane beside a supermarket, then look for the back of a bakery. But the artist collective representing 35 East Gippsland artists is worth seeking out for its handmade ceramics, jewellery and design objects. “Everything we put on the shelves is made in the district,’’ says co-founder Jes John. Ranging in price from $2 to $400, you’re sure to find something that suits. 

Mitta Mitta River, Omeo. raftingaustralia.com

The Mitta Mitta River is well known for its whitewater thrills. Rafting Australia has been negotiating its rapids for years. But owners Linton and Tracey Smith, who know the river like the back of their oars, are still discovering new things about Granite River Gorge. Sign up for a one-day Mitta Mitta journey to see this wonder while riding 18km of crystal-clear mountain water. Led by experienced guides out of Omeo, the tour ($220 a person) suits novices (children from 12) and includes river equipment, river transfers and lunch.

Traralgon Creek Rd, Loy Yang.visitlatrobecity.com 

Plumes of steam curling into the sky signal the presence of Loy Yang power station. But it’s only when you get off the South Gippsland Highway and drive up to Miners View lookout that the epic scale of this site comes into focus. The lookout, equipped with telescopes, takes in Loy Yang’s huge cooling towers and the open-cut mine next door, a great gouge in the ground where electric-powered bucket wheel dredgers can be seen toiling in the distance. 

150 Johnson St, Maffra. wellington.vic.gov.au

It’s tucked in a library but when it comes to art, Maffra Exhibition Space can punch above its weight. This “access gallery’’ (closed Sunday and Tuesday) focuses on Gippsland artists. In coming months, look out for landscapes by Graeme Myrteza. Around the corner, in Foster St, Maffra Bakery bakes the best pies in town. 

246 Samuel Amess Dr, Churchill Island.visitphillipisland.com

Perused the penguins? Spotted the seals? It’s time you crossed the bridge from Phillip Island to Churchill Island Heritage Farm. This 57ha oasis has been farmed since the 1850s and was once owned by the mayor of Melbourne. Today, it’s active once more with restored farmhouses, cottages and gardens giving visitors a glimpse into the lives of early settlers.
results.standFirst: WE’VE searched high and low to find the best hidden gems across each region of our great state so you don’t have to. From swimming in the Blue Pool to live crayfish, here’s the best of Gippsland.

results.title: Cops hunt 600 men over mum’s murder
results.subtitle: Police hunt through 600 men in statewide manhunt to catch Tracy Connelly’s killer
results.description: AN unprecedented statewide manhunt to catch the killer of mum Tracy Connelly will see hundreds of men asked to undergo forensic testing in a bid to break open the case.
results.subscriptionSummary: AN unprecedented statewide manhunt to catch the killer of mum Tracy Connelly will see hundreds of men asked to undergo forensic testing in a bid to break open the case. Police have compiled a list of more than 600 men who were in St Kilda about the time of Ms Connelly’s murder and each of them can expect a knock on the door from police.

thumbnailImage.title: Cops hunt 600 men over mum’s murder
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 022224ca-6c5c-11e6-be68-d851631c36a3
thumbnailImage.description: Cops hunt 600 men over mum’s murder
thumbnailImage.imageName: Tracy Connelly, 40, with boyfriend of 19-years Tony Melissovas. Tracy, a sex worker, was killed in Greeves Street, St Kilda. She was found in a van she lived in on Sunday July 21.

results.seoHeadline: Police hunt through 600 men in statewide manhunt to catch Tracy Connelly’s killer
results.body:
Police have compiled a list of more than 600 men who were in St Kilda about the time of Ms Connelly’s murder and each of them can expect a knock on the door from police.

They will work to find a match between samples obtained from the men and crucial evidence located inside Ms Connelly’s white Ford Econovan, which she worked out of as a sex worker.

Over the past three years police have compiled the persons of interest list from police databases, social media, records of people in the area at the time and up to 3000 car registration numbers recorded by Ms Connelly’s long-time partner, Tony Melissovas, in the 18 months leading up to her death.

Police across the state are taking part in the operation to track down those identified who could potentially be linked Ms Connelly’s case.

Tracy’s van where she was found in St Kilda.

The investigation will spread across the state but a cluster of people to be contacted remain in the Port Phillip region of Melbourne.

Most of those have never had their forensic samples recorded by police although it is possible the man investigators are looking for may have had their profile destroyed despite being convicted of serious crimes.

Ms Connelly’s body was found in her van which she used as a home and where she took sex clients in Greeves St, St Kilda on July 21, 2013.

The massive project demonstrates a great level of commitment to finding Ms Connelly’s murderer.

Concerns, however, have been raised about the possibility the killer’s DNA could be missing from the police DNA database.

The Herald Sun exposed after the death of Jill Meagher in 2012 that Adrian Bayley’s DNA was not on the force’s database despite it being taken from him by police more than decade earlier.

Police command looked into the issue after the homicide squad looked for his DNA on its system and were shocked to find it was missing.

Tracy Connelly with son, Bill in 1993.

The Sunday Herald Sun is not suggesting Ms Connelly’s killer has previously produced a sample for police or that it has been lost or destroyed.

Bayley’s DNA was taken from him after he was arrested for the rape of sex workers in the St Kilda area in 2001, many of whom had to be convinced to work with police.

Because of an administrative issue, an unknown quantity of DNA samples have been destroyed because of a failure to apply for court orders to keep offenders’ DNA permanently on file.

In Bayley’s case, he was not automatically retrospectively put on the Sexual Offenders Register’ because his history of offending was not against children, as legislation stipulated, although one of his victims was a minor.

He had, however, been convicted of multiple rapes and sexual assaults years apart which should have led to his DNA being kept.

Ms Connelly worked and lived on the streets with her partner and her death sparked wide public reaction to violence against women.

Police did not hold an appeal for information to coincide with the third anniversary of her death this year as it began the painstaking task of conducting the wide-scale door knock.

Homicide Inspector Mick Hughes last month vowed to catch Ms Connelly’s killer.

Flowers and tributes to Tracy Connelly at the site of her murder.

Victoria’s homicide squad has consistently worked towards identifying suspects in the Tracy Connelly murder case, following several leads, but none have identified a prime suspect.

It is not known if investigators were able to identify a man or a dark Ford XR6 ute caught by CCTV cameras near the crime scene in the early hours of the morning when Ms Connelly was attacked.

Shortly after the murder former homicide Inspector John Potter was confident they would catch the killer, declaring after his squad had found DNA: We’ve got good evidence from the scene, from the van,’’ he said. I’m confident we will make an arrest in this case.’’

Several men known to police, both sex offenders and clients, have been cleared.

Male DNA found at the scene was also tested against 192 countries through Interpol after national databases came up without a match.

Last (SAT) night, Victoria Police released a statement from Homicide Squad chief Detective Inspector Mick Hughes saying there was “significant work to do.”

“We still have significant work to do on the investigation into to Tracy Connelly’s death,” it read.

“I want Tracy’s family and friends as well as the broader community to know the Homicide Squad is committed to bringing this investigation to a successful conclusion.”

Anyone with information is asked to phone Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000. 

Tracy Connelly with son, Bill in 1991.

TRACY Connelly’s killer must be brought to justice so her family can finally move on, they say.

Tracy’s brother, Les Toft, who lives in Queensland, yesterday told the Sunday Herald Sun how important it was to the family that her killer be found.

“If someone has done something wrong, they should be held accountable,” he said.

“People know they should think twice before committing such an atrocity, that they will get caught.”

Mr Toft said his sister was a kind woman with a wicked sense of humour, who “didn’t hurt anybody but herself”.

“It’s hard to remember these things because you always expect your family to be with you right through your life,” he said.

Mr Toft said Tracy’s son was now 25.

“He’s very much like her ... very intelligent, very funny,” he said.

Mr Toft added the whole family were praying for a breakthrough in the cold case.

“It would bring us some closure to know what happened, but it doesn’t change the fact that, from our point of view, like everyone else who has suffered loss, it won’t bring her back. Nothing will ever change that.”

He said his sister now had a resting place after her ashes were buried in a serene plot in Queensland last year.

“We just feel now that she’s home,” he said.

“She’s still in our memories. It’s good if they find something, but it’s not going to change anything.

“She’ll always be with us.”

Tracy’s father, Bryan Connelly, has never given up hope his daughter’s killer will be caught.

Mr Connelly, who also lives in Queensland, yesterday said police had informed him the investigation had been ramped up.

“We are just so appreciative that people are still thinking about her outside of the family.

“We are very grateful for all the support that the media and other people in the community are giving, especially Victoria Police, who seem to be very tireless. It’s really good,” Mr Connelly said.

But he added: “If they catch him, it’s not going to change the reality.”

Three years ago Mr Connelly fronted a media conference with Tracy’s long-term partner, Tony Melissovas, appealing for witnesses to come forward.

At that 2013 media conference, Mr Connelly said Tracy’s killer needed to be stopped.

“We really need to get him and bring him to justice, whoever it is,” he said.

Mr Connelly said he wanted people not to judge his daughter for her choice of profession.

“I didn’t judge her. I don’t expect anyone else to judge her either,” he said.

kath 

powley

- Kathryn Powley and Elissa Doherty
results.standFirst: AN unprecedented statewide manhunt to catch the killer of mum Tracy Connelly will see hundreds of men asked to undergo forensic testing in a bid to break open the murder case.

results.body:
Sports fans at next year’s event will enter through a revamped grand entrance with the Tanderrum Bridge carrying fans from Birrarung Marr to a new-look tennis precinct like no other.

The traditional main entrance to Melbourne Park via steps leading to Rod Laver Arena will be off-limits from next year with spectators instead urged to enter from the opposite end of the precinct.

Australian Open director Craig Tiley said it would “turn the focal entry or front of the site from the river to the city’’.

“The connection to the city is what we’re all about and this makes it more formal and more specific,’’ he said.

He said the site would be “switched around’’ so the main entrance faced the CBD with construction of the new footbridge expected to be finished next month and turnstiles installed this summer.

“This will of course be our primary entrance,’’ he said.

Alternative gates will be opened next to HiSense Arena and at the existing tram entrance through Garden Square.

In other changes, Grand Slam Oval will be turned into a food and entertainment precinct themed on London, New York and Paris in tribute to Wimbledon and the US and French Opens.

The precinct, previously a popular band zone, will feature a Paris Quarter with crepes, macaroons and wine, an English pub and garden zone and a “Big Apple’’ area with hotdogs and burgers.

As revealed in the Herald Sun last week, nightly bands will be moved to a larger site at Birrarung Marr and rebranded The Open Sessions.

A free two-day music festival will rock the site before next year’s event starts on January 16.

And, for the first time, a mini theme park called The Ballpark, will offer a dedicated kids zone featuring a Lego Land, Nerf Battlezone and Adventure Park.

Open organisers will undertake the biggest push to lure Asian tourists in the event’s history in the lead-up to January’s Grand Slam with event launches in China, Japan and Singapore for the first time.

It comes as an economic impact study into this year’s event found 48 per cent of fans were from outside Melbourne.

About 26percent were from interstate, 13percent from overseas and nine per cent from regional Victoria.

Visitors in town for the tournament stayed an average 5.11 nights in Melbourne hotel rooms and spent $181 per day, the report found.

peter.rolfe@news.com.au

@rolfep
results.standFirst: A NEW main entrance and pedestrian bridge to the Australian Open will next year move the focus of Melbourne’s Grand Slam towards the city.

results.title: Sexting backfire for concerned dad
results.subtitle: Victorian man convicted after reporting stepdaughter’s sexting
results.description: A DAD who reported his stepdaughter to police and her school for sexting has himself been convicted of child porn offences and placed on the sex offenders register.
results.subscriptionSummary: A DAD who reported his stepdaughter to police and her school for sexting has himself been convicted of child porn offences and placed on the sex offenders register.

thumbnailImage.title: Sexting backfire for concerned dad
thumbnailImage.subtitle: c72534cc-8e14-11e6-a02d-d7bd6eef8010
thumbnailImage.description: Sexting backfire for concerned dad
thumbnailImage.imageName: 04/11/2012 NEWS: Teenage girls, students texting on mobile phones, text message, school. Generic, thinkstock Pic. Supplied

results.body:
The man must now report to police annually, disclose all computer usernames and social media accounts and notify authorities if he wants to go on holidays for more than a weekend.

Sentencing him last week, County Court judge Jane Patrick said the case was completely different to the usual child pornography cases heard by the court.

“This is a very unusual case. The law says that people may not keep images of a sexual nature of children. Usually such images are kept for sexual motivation,” she said. 

“That is not the case in your situation. You kept the images, I am satisfied, because you were very concerned about what had been going on and foolishly decided that this was the way to deal with it 

“Nevertheless the message has to get out to everybody that sexual images of children must not be kept on computers or any other form of equipment.”

The man caught his teen stepdaughter sexting her boyfriend, confiscated her phone and reported the matter to her school, and police. 

Before returning the girl’s phone the man copied the 18 images to a USB and computer because he wanted police to investigate the matter further. 

He reported the images to the girl’s school and the education department.

The man said he kept the images until he received a “satisfactory response” by police who had warned him that keeping the pictures stored was an offence. 

Ultimately police searched the man’s home and seized two USBs and a laptop containing the images then charged him with possessing child pornography. 

He pleaded guilty to possessing child pornography and was this week placed on a good behaviour bond, but was required to be placed on the sex offenders register for eight years.

“I didn’t even understand it fell under child pornography,” the man told the Herald Sun.

“I also made a copy for the school and the police. The police then interviewed me and my step daughter separately but said it appeared to be consensual. 

“No one told me that this is child pornography so delete it. My solicitor made the point ‘why would he go to the police if he had anything to hide?”

Judge Patrick said the case highlighted danger associated with sexting, that she said was becoming more prevalent among teens.

She said the offending was at the lowest end of its kind.

“There’s no suggestion of any exploitation of them by anybody. You made no attempt to conceal the images from anybody.”

The man said being placed on the sex offenders register was tough and dented his chances of getting a job.

“What’s hard for me is this register thing,” he said. 

“I didn’t create this stuff, I didn’t distribute it. By law it’s mandatory that they put you on this register. But I could tell that the judge didn’t really want to do it,” he said.

shannon.deery@news.com.au

@s_deery

results.title: Fury over Whincup’s trail of destruction
results.subtitle: Garth Tander slams Jamie Whincup after late-race crash ended his Bathurst 1000 hopes
results.description: GARTH Tander has slammed Jamie Whincup’s “pretty desperate” move that triggered a disastrous chain-reaction, sending the Holden Racing Team driver crashing into the wall and ending his Bathurst 1000 hopes.

thumbnailImage.title: Fury over Whincup’s trail of destruction
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 56d15a68-8df9-11e6-a02d-d7bd6eef8010
thumbnailImage.description: Fury over Whincup’s trail of destruction
thumbnailImage.imageName: Supercars - Bathurst 1000: Practice & Top Ten Shootout 613281138

results.seoHeadline: Bathurst 1000: Garth Tander slams Jamie Whincup after late-race crash
results.body:
And HRT team owner Ryan Walkinshaw didn’t hold back either, saying the team had been “robbed” after the dramatic three-car incident on lap 150 that ended the race hopes of Tander, Scott McLaughlin and Whincup at Mount Panorama.

It all started when Whincup tried a passing move on the inside of McLaughlin, forcing the Volvo driver off the track. When McLaughlin found his way back onto the track he then collided with Tander, who was wedged in behind Whincup, forcing the HRT veteran crashing into the wall.

CRASHES: ‘Metal Grate’ sparks Bathurst carnage

THE RACE: Bathurst 1000 sealed with a shoey

SUPERCARS: Trailblazer Simona is chasing podiums

HOLDSWORTH: ‘Everyone is devastated to start like that’

Whincup was hit with a 15-second penalty for the driving infringement, while McLaughlin was to face post-race investigation for dangerous re-entry.

Tander, who was fourth and in pursuit of his second enduro win after his stunning victory at Sandown, said immediately after the incident he blamed Whincup for starting the chain reaction.

“Whincup unloaded McLaughlin then decided to jump on the brakes to try and re-address it and then Scotty came back on and there was contact,’’ Tander said.

“Whincup started it all so they probably should look at that.

“It’s a bit surreal at the moment. It was obviously a fuel race, we were saving a lot of fuel, we were way ahead of target.

“Jamie was being pretty desperate, Scotty made a small mistake at forest elbow and Jamie decided to pounce but it wasn’t on.’’

A shattered Tander was not the only one left seething, with Walkinshaw taking out his frustrations on Twitter after the race.

“A @Holden_racing Bathurst win robbed from us with 10 laps to go by two people running out of talent who should know better. Gutting,’’ Walkinshaw tweeted.

“So take out a car then block the car behind you whilst attempting to redress, causing the two cars involved to crash. 15 second penalty.’’

Tander, whose future is unclear after losing his seat at Walkinshaw Racing for next year, later said he would have expected more from a six-time champion. 

“It was a disappointing end to what was looking like a promising race. It’s a shame we got caught in other people’s dramas and you would expect more from a six time champion and a four-time winner of this race. To drive the way he did was disappointing,’’ Tander said.

“I can’t change the result but at least it shows we were in for the win, we had plenty of fuel up our sleeve and we could have pressed on to the end but it just wasn’t to be.’’

HRT team principal Adrian Burgess said the team had been cruelled by “someone’s ambitious manoeuvre” and “dangerous re-entry”.

“Clearly we are all a bit devastated. We didn’t have the quickest car this weekend but we’ve got a bloody good team here and we bought ourselves a ticket to the last 20 laps with Luffy (Warren Luff) and GT. We were in a good position and we were good on fuel,’’ Burgess said. 

“Those around us were definitely in a lot more pain than we were and we get taken out by someone’s ambitious manoeuvre and someone else’s dangerous re-entry.

“But this is Bathurst and they don’t call it heartbreak hill for nothing. We are all gutted but this is motorsport, we’ll pick ourselves up and go to the Gold Coast with a spring in our step and try and repeat what we did there last year.’’
results.standFirst: A DEVASTATED Garth Tander has unloaded on rival Jamie Whincup, accusing the Red Bull star of ending his Bathurst 1000 hopes with a “desperate” move.

results.title: AFL trade period ultimate guide
results.subtitle: AFL trade period 2016: who is in demand and who wants out at every club
results.description: THE AFL’s silly season kicks off on Monday morning and we’ve got you covered.
results.subscriptionSummary:
THE AFL’s silly season kicks off on Monday morning and we’ve got you covered. 
 Find out which players at your club are in demand and who wants out.

thumbnailImage.title: AFL trade period ultimate guide
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 1714a79c-8df7-11e6-b259-f7666b0e5afb
thumbnailImage.description: AFL trade period ultimate guide

results.body:
Find out which players at your club are in demand and who wants out.

Don’t miss a trade or rumour with our live blog running every day throughout the fortnight.

LIVE BLOG: DON’T MISS A DEAL ON DAY ONE

TRADEHQ: LATEST NEWS AND WHISPERS

ADELAIDE

GONE: Nathan van Berlo, Matthew Jaensch (retired), Luke Lowden, Keenan Ramsey (delisted) 

IN PLAY: Out-of-contract swingman Ricky Henderson is surplus to Adelaide’s needs and should find a new home during the trade period. Jarryd Lyons will test the market after not being happy with the offer on the table. The 24-year-old has been linked to Gold Coast.

THE TARGETS: Been sniffing around Carlton star Bryce Gibbs for a long time, but a move appears unlikely. 

NATIONAL DRAFT PICKS: 13, 50, 68, 86, 104

BRISBANE LIONS

GONE: Justin Clarke, Trent West, Daniel Merrett (retired), Jackson Paine, Hugh Beasley, Billy Evans, Josh Watts, Josh McGuinness (delisted)

IN PLAY: Pearce Hanley appears to have out-stayed his welcome and could be off to cross-town rival Gold Coast or to Geelong. Captain Tom Rockliff’s name continues to come up in trade talks. How will his meeting with new coach Chris Fagan go?

THE TARGETS: Collingwood’s Jack Frost will head north on a three-year deal. The Lions are also keen on Melbourne defender Lynden Dunn.

NATIONAL DRAFT ORDER: 2, 19, 21, 29, 48, 57, 75

CARLTON

GONE: Matthew Dick, Jayden Foster, Clem Smith (delisted), Michael Jamison, Andrew Walker, Cameron Wood (retired)

IN PLAY: Zach Tuohy has baulked at a two-year deal, with North Melbourne and Geelong circling for his services. 

THE TARGETS: Caleb Marchbank will get to the Blues, but at what price? The Blues will want to hold onto No.5, or at least secure a later first-round selection in return. Expect GWS to try and bundle in James Stewart with Marchbank in a direct swap for No.5. That would place seven former Giants on the Stephen Silvagni’s list.

NATIONAL DRAFT PICKS: 5, 24, 42, 55, 78, 96

COLLINGWOOD

GONE: Tim Golds, Matthew Goodyear, Darrean Wyatt (delisted), Brent Macaffer, Dane Swan, Alan Toovey (retired)

IN PLAY: Travis Cloke’s move to premiers Western Bulldogs appears a fait accompli and should go through relatively quickly. Jack Frost is set to sign with Brisbane, while Jarrod Witts is likely to join Gold Coast. Whisper is restricted free agent Nathan Brown will reject North Melbourne’s offer to stay put.

THE TARGETS: Have dangled big-money multi-year deals at free agents Chris Mayne and Daniel Wells and both should get done as a matter of course. Giant Will Hoskin-Elliott also been courted by the Pies promising greater playing prospects.

NATIONAL DRAFT PICKS: 26, 44, 62, 80, 98

ESSENDON

GONE: Jason Ashby, Ryan Crowley, Matt Dea, Shaun Edwards, Nathan Grima, Sam Grimley, James Gwilt, Mark Jamar, James Kelly, Sam Michael, James Polkinghorne, Jonathan Simpkin, Tom Wallis (delisted), Adam Cooney, Tayte Pears (retired)

IN PLAY: Michael Hibberd’s trade to Melbourne will get done with the cost likely to be second-round pick. 

THE TARGETS: Bulldogs midfielder Koby Stevens remains unsigned and could make the switch to Tullamarine. Could look at contracted Brisbane Lions skipper Tom Rockliff should he decide to leave the Gabba for a fresh start.

NATIONAL DRAFT PICKS: 1, 20, 38, 56, 74, 92

FREMANTLE

GONE: Matthew Pavlich (retired), Sean Hurley, Tanner Smith, Anthony Morabito, Tendai Mzungu, Matt de Boer, Clancee Pearce, Jack Hannath, Brady Grey, Josh Deluca (delisted)

IN PLAY: After seven years out west, Michael Barlow is unlikely to remain a Docker. Hayden Ballantyne has been linked with a move to West Coast and will likely head east if a trade to the rival can’t be struck. Chris Mayne will join Collingwood.

THE TARGETS: Hawthorn’s Brad Hill is set to join brother Stephen at the Dockers, most likely at the cost of the compensation selection received for Mayne. After sitting out the 2016 season, Cam McCarthy is likely to return to football with Fremantle and the Dockers could also target fellow West Australian Shane Kersten. Interest is rising in premiership defender Joel Hamling, another local product.

NATIONAL DRAFT ORDER: 3, 40, 58, 76

GEELONG

GONE: Corey Enright (retired), Zac Bates, Cameron Delaney, Padraig Lucey, Tom Read, Jock Cornell (delisted)

IN PLAY: Steven Motlop is under pressure after a slim September campaign. Out-of-favour forward Shane Kersten has been linked with a move to Perth and Nathan Vardy could be another tall on the way out.

THE TARGETS: The Cats want to add another star midfielder and are targeting one of Brett Deledio, Daniel Wells or Pearce Hanley. Could Hayden Ballantyne slot into Geelong’s forward line?

NATIONAL DRAFT ORDER: 35, 39, 53, 71, 88, 89

GOLD COAST

GONE: Seb Tape, Luke Russell, Danny Stanley, Tom Keough (delisted)

IN PLAY: Jaeger O’Meara wants to head to Hawthorn and Dion Prestia has nominated Richmond. Will they end up there? The Suns will play hardball on O’Meara, but expect both trades to get done.

THE TARGETS: Who isn’t a target? It feels like the Suns are after anyone and everyone in this year’s trade period. Docker Michael Barlow could find himself on the Gold Coast and the Suns are still in the hunt for Pearce Hanley and Jarrod Witts. Missed out on Lin Jong and Hamish Hartlett.

NATIONAL DRAFT PICKS: 4, 8 (from Melbourne), 22 (from Fremantle), 23, 25 (from Richmond), 28 (from Port Adelaide), 41, 59

GWS GIANTS

GONE: None as yet

IN PLAY: Quite a few. Midfielder Jack Steele wants to play for St Kilda, Caleb Marchbank has requested a move to Carlton and homesick forward Cam McCarthy wants to head home to WA. Wingman Will Hoskin-Elliott is in Collingwood’s sights while James Stewart is likely to end up at the Magpies or Blues.

THE TARGETS: The Giants would love to snatch this year’s No.1 draft pick to secure Sandringham Dragons jet Andy McGrath in addition to another sparkling academy bunch, led by Will Setterfield and Harry Perryman.

NATIONAL DRAFT PICKS: 7 (from Collingwood), 15, 16 (from Geelong via Carlton), 32 (from Adelaide), 34, 52, 70

HAWTHORN

GONE: Shem-Kalvin Tatupu (retired)

IN PLAY: Brad Hill wants to play alongside brother Stephen at Fremantle and will likely net a draft pick in the early 20s. Luke Breust’s name has been raised as possible trade bait to help land slick midfielder Jaeger O’Meara. Premiership player Will Langford could also be on the move while clubs are talking about promising forward James Sicily. Promising defender Kaiden Brand should re-sign.

THE TARGETS: Blockbuster trade period coming up with deals to be done for Jaeger O’Meara and Tom Mitchell. Ty Vickery, a restricted free agent, will join the Hawks on a two-year deal worth close to $1m, as long as Richmond doesn’t match the offer.

NATIONAL DRAFT PICKS: 14, 33, 51, 69, 87, 105

MELBOURNE

GONE: Jack Grimes, Matt Jones, Dean Terlich (delisted)

IN PLAY: Chris Dawes is yet to receive a fresh contract offer while Lynden Dunn is tipped to join Brisbane Lions after falling out of favour.

THE TARGETS: Michael Hibberd is the man and is expected to only cost pick No.27, delivering a lean draft year for the Demons. A back-up ruckman to Gawn is also on the wish list.

NATIONAL DRAFT PICKS: 27, 45, 63, 81

NORTH MELBOURNE

GONE: Nick Dal Santo, Drew Petrie, Robbie Nahas, Farren Ray, Brent Harvey, Michael Firrito (retired)

IN PLAY: Daniel Wells looks to be on the move to Collingwood on a three-year mega deal. Brad McKenzie and Joel Tippett might struggle to hold their spots on the list with no contracts on the table.

THE TARGETS: The Roos have trumped Carlton with a four-year deal to lure Zach Tuohy, yet to sign a three-year deal to stay at Princes Park. North has its eye on young Crows forward Harry Dear. They also want Collingwood key defender Nathan Brown.

NATIONAL DRAFT PICKS: 11, 30, 66, 84, 102

PORT ADELAIDE

GONE: Alipate Carlile (retired), John Butcher, Jay Schulz, Kane Mitchell, Sam Colquhoun (delisted)

IN PLAY: The Hamish Hartlett saga is set to fizzle with the expensive midfielder now likely to stay. Matthew Lobbe’s value has gone through the floor while unsigned defender Cameron O’Shea is also on the market. Lobbe is rated a 50-50 chance to stay with Paddy Ryder set to take the No.1 ruck mantle.

THE TARGETS: A salary cap squeeze means the draft is likely to be the main target for the Power. Ryder and Angus Monfries are effectively 2017 recruits after serving drug bans.

NATIONAL DRAFT PICKS: 9, 46, 64, 82

RICHMOND

GONE: Troy Chaplin, Reece McKenzie (retired), Liam McBean, Adam Marcon (delisted)

IN PLAY: The Brett Deledio trade talk refuses to go away with Geelong keen on the star Tiger. Richmond is unlikely to match Tyrone Vickery’s free agency offer from Hawthorn. Ben Lennon requested a trade as soon as the season was over. Reece Conca is also likely to find a second home.

THE TARGETS: Dion Prestia will be at Tigerland next year. The only question is, how much will he cost? Tigers would love to find a way to land Prestia and hold onto pick No.6, and Deledio could be the answer.

NATIONAL DRAFT ORDER: 6, 43, 61, 79

ST KILDA

GONE: Luke Delaney, Tom Curren, Josh Saunders, Brenton Payne (delisted)

IN PLAY: St Kilda has plenty of ruck depth and rival clubs have enquired about Billy Longer. The club says he is a required player.

THE TARGETS: The Saints have already had a win with GWS midfielder Jack Steele declaring he wants to join the club. Don’t rule out another inside midfielder lobbing at Seaford.

NATIONAL DRAFT ORDER: 10, 47, 65, 83

SYDNEY SWANS

GONE: Ted Richards, Ben McGlynn (retired), Tom Derickx, Kyle Galloway (delisted)

IN PLAY: The big one is Tom Mitchell, who is set to declare his intentions on Monday. Hawthorn looms large, but the Swans won’t let him go without a fight. Ruckman Toby Nankervis may also head to Richmond.

THE TARGETS: The Swans don’t need a whole lot, but they surely would love to get up the draft order given their first pick is at 17. Swans are also having a look at Zach Tuohy.

NATIONAL DRAFT PICKS: 17, 36, 54, 90

WEST COAST

GONE: Xavier Ellis, Damien Cavka, Kane Lucas, Patrick McGinnity (retired), Jamie Bennell, Brant Colledge, Alec Waterman, Corey Adamson (delisted)

IN PLAY: Key defender Eric Mackenzie is on Essendon’s radar where he would link up with former coach John Worsfold. Mitch Brown looks likely to leave in free agency.

THE TARGETS: With Nic Naitanui set for a long stint on the sidelines, the Eagles are chasing delisted Roo Drew Petrie. Would they take a look at Will Minson? Fremantle forward Hayden Ballantyne could also make the switch to the Eagles. 

NATIONAL DRAFT ORDER: 12, 31, 49, 67, 85

WESTERN BULLDOGS

GONE: Jed Adcock (retired), Luke Goetz (delisted)

IN PLAY: Premiership defender Joel Hamling remains unsigned as his value rockets. Midfielder Koby Stevens looks set to leave, as does uncontracted small forward Nathan Hrovat. Will Minson retired from the club but would go another season elsewhere, while All-Australian Matthew Boyd’s future remains unclear.

THE TARGETS: The Travis Cloke trade should be fairly straight-forward. He is expected to cost the Dogs just pick No.72, with Collingwood happy to free up salary cap space by offloading their hulking goalkicker. Other than that expect a quiet October, with the Dogs’ list strategy now geared around retention.

NATIONAL DRAFT PICKS: 18, 37, 55 (from Carlton), 60, 72 (from Sydney), 73

results.title: Mitchell ready to request Hawks trade
results.subtitle: Tom Mitchell is set to tell Sydney he wants to be traded to Hawthorn
results.description: TOM Mitchell is set to tell Sydney he wants to be traded to Hawthorn, where he is expected to sign a lucrative four-year contract tying him to Waverley until 2020.
results.subscriptionSummary:
TOM Mitchell is set to tell Sydney he wants to be traded to Hawthorn, where he is expected to sign a lucrative four-year contract tying him to Waverley until 2020. 
 Mitchell’s manager Phil Mullen, of Stride Sports, will meet Swans’ officials and an announcement is expected late Monday or early Tuesday.

thumbnailImage.title: Mitchell ready to request Hawks trade
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 7878a0fc-8df1-11e6-b259-f7666b0e5afb
thumbnailImage.description: Mitchell ready to request Hawks trade

results.seoHeadline: AFL trade rumours, news: Tom Mitchell is set to tell Sydney he wants to be traded to Hawthorn
results.body:
Mitchell’s manager Phil Mullen, of Stride Sports, will meet Swans’ officials and an announcement is expected late Monday or early Tuesday.

Mullen denied a deal had already been struck with the Hawks.

LIVE BLOG: DON’T MISS A DEAL ON DAY ONE

SEASON REVIEW: SYDNEY SWANS’ 2016 REPORT CARD

ALASTAIR CLARKSON: ‘GET READY, WE’RE COMING AGAIN IN 2017’

“People know more than we do,” Mullen said.

“We’re still in negotiations, we’re meeting with Sydney (Monday).

“We made an agreement that we would talk to Sydney at the end of the season, and we will do that.”

The Hawks are armed with draft pick No.14 but if they swap that for Mitchell it would place more stress on striking a trade with Gold Coast for Jaeger O’Meara.

The Herald Sun understands Mitchell, 23, met with at least one other Victorian club last week in a certain sign the Grand Final was his final performance for the Swans.

Swans chief executive Andrew Ireland, who flew to Rome on Saturday, was not aware of Mitchell’s future when contacted by the Herald Sun.

TRADEHQ: LATEST NEWS AND WHISPERS

The Swans will officially learn Mitchell’s plans on Monday. 

Hawthorn coach Alastair Clarkson and captain Luke Hodge both declared how proud the Hawks were to be a destination club at Saturday night’s best-and-fairest count.

Clarkson said: “Wrighty (list chief Graeme Wright), get to work lad. You’ve got some important stuff to do over the next couple of weeks.

“Players want to come to our footy club because of (fitness coach) Andrew Russell and his team.

“That’s really, really special in terms of being a destination club. A lot of it has got to do with our medical and conditioning team.”

Clarkson signed off with a warning: “Get ready, we’re coming in 2017” with the Hawks set for a busy off-season.

Richmond will not match Hawthorn’s offer for Tyrone Vickery, meaning the forward will this week join the Hawks on a two-year contract worth close to $500,000 per season.

Silky midfielder O’Meara, 22, and inside ballwinner Mitchell will help regenerate Clarkson’s ageing engine room.

Mitchell enjoyed a career-best season, averaging 28 disposals and recording his best finish in the Bob Skilton Medal — eighth. 

Mitchell led the Swans in tackles and slotted 15 goals, including two during his team’s second-quarter Grand Final burst.
results.standFirst: TOM Mitchell is set to tell Sydney he wants to be traded to rivals Hawthorn, while Richmond will allow Ty Vickery to walk away as a free agent.

results.title: Turia Pitt completes Hawaiian Ironman
results.subtitle: Burns survivor Turia Pitt completes Hawaiian Ironman
results.description: INSPIRING burns survivor Turia Pitt has successfully tackled the world’s toughest Ironman race in Hawaii.
results.subscriptionSummary: INSPIRING burns survivor Turia Pitt has successfully tackled the world’s toughest Ironman race in Hawaii.

thumbnailImage.title: Turia Pitt completes Hawaiian Ironman
thumbnailImage.subtitle: a79be2aa-8dff-11e6-a02d-d7bd6eef8010
thumbnailImage.description: Turia Pitt completes Hawaiian Ironman

results.body:
Pitt was among 2000 athletes at the starting line of the gruelling 226.2km journey — a 3.8km swim, 180km of cycling and 42km run — yesterday.

The courageous Aussie athlete was backed by her fiance, Michael Hoskin, and support crew.

Doctors told Pitt she would never run again when she suffered burns to 65 per cent of body in 2011 after being caught in a freak firestorm in Western Australia during an ultra-marathon.

Yesterday, she looked confident when she entered the final run, which passes through infamous lava fields and proves the biggest challenge for competitors.

Before the race, Pitt said the final section of the Ironman World Championships would be tough test. 

“Because of my burns, I can’t regulate my own body temperature. I have to make adjustments or use standard tri gear in different ways ... I will need things such as cooling sleeves and white suits to deal with the heat in Kona,’’ she said.

“I’d rather take a crack at it and fail than not even try at all.”
results.standFirst: INSPIRING burns survivor Turia Pitt has successfully tackled the world’s toughest Ironman race in Hawaii.

results.title: Aussie held in Bali drug charge
results.subtitle: Australian man Guiseppe Serafino and a UK man held in Bali over drug possesssion
results.description: AN Australian man and his British friend have been locked up by police in Bali, accused of possession of 17.41 grams of hashish.

thumbnailImage.title: Aussie held in Bali drug charge
thumbnailImage.subtitle: 90111086-8dfc-11e6-b259-f7666b0e5afb
thumbnailImage.description: Aussie held in Bali drug charge
thumbnailImage.imageName: Supplied Editorial Fwd: Photo of suspects

results.seoHeadline: Denpasar, Bali: Australian Guiseppe Serafino and UK man in drug arrest
results.body:
The two men were arrested on the weekend and are now in custody at Denpasar police station facing interrogation on drugs possession laws which carry a maximum 12-year jail term.

The Australian man was identified by police as 48-year-old Guiseppe Serafino and his companion, known only as DM, is a 54-year old British journalist born in the town of Shrewsbury in Shropshire, England. Police said both had been living in Bali for five years.

The men were both arrested on Saturday after what police say was a tip off from the community about a man at the address of the Australian, who allegedly often used drugs.

Denpasar police chief, Hadi Purnomo, said police had gone to the home of the. Australian, in Sanur, where they allegedly found Serafino and hashish weighing 7.2 grams inside a black bag.

Mr Purnomo claimed the Australian told police he got the drugs from his friend, DM, who he agreed to meet, in an apparent police sting, in the nearby ON ON Bar.

At the bar DM was arrested and hashish was allegedly seized. He was then brought to his home, also in Sanur, where more hashish was allegedly seized along with a bong. The total hashish allegedly seized at the bar and at DMs home was 10.09 grams.

Police allege that DM told them he got the drugs from someone whose identity he didn’t know.

Both men are now being held at the Denpasar police stations drug squad holding cells pending further investigations. They are yet to be fully interrogated with a translator.

They are being investigated under article 112 of Indonesia’s harsh anti-drugs laws for drug possession, which carries a maximum 12-year term.

This is the same police station where Australian woman Sara Connor and her British boyfriend David Taylor have been held since August 19 as suspects in the murder of a Bali police officer.

Prosecutors in their case are expected on Monday to make a decision on whether the brief of evidence agains the couple is completed and the case is ready for court.

The two drugs suspects are being held in holding cells in the drug squad section of the police station. Connor and Taylor are now in the general downstairs holding cells.

If prosecutors pursue charges against the pair, they will be transferred to Kerobokan jail to await trial as soon as the case is declared complete and ready. 

Indonesia has harsh anti-drugs laws and the Australian man arrested on the weekend is the latest of his countrymen to find himself behind bars for a small amount of drugs. Even small amounts are not tolerated in Indonesia and can earn people months of jail time. Large amounts can see life sentences and even the death penalty imposed.
results.standFirst: AN Australian man and his British friend have been locked up in Bali, accused of possession of 17.41 grams of hashish.

results.title: Rinehart to buy Kidman and Co
results.subtitle: Gina Rinehart and Shanghai Cred enter bid for nation’s largest private landholding
results.description: AUSTRALIAN mining magnate Gina Rinehart and Chinese Real Estate company Shanghai Cred have entered into a bid implementation agreement to make a takeover offer for the nation’s largest private land hold S Kidman and Co.

/taxonomy/iptc.org/economy, business and finance/company information/merger, acquisition and takeover/

results.body:
An agreement has been reached under a joint venture company Australian Outback Beef Pty Ltd (AOB) owned 67 per cent by Mrs Rinehart’s company Hancock Prospecting and 33 per cent by Shanghai Cred.

The offer is condition on the transaction being permitted to proceed in its current form under Australia’s foreign investment regime and is subject to People’s Republic of China (PRC) government approvals.

It is also conditional of completion of the divestment of the Anna Creek station and the Peake by Kidman to other Australian grazing interests. The proceeds from the sale of Anna Creek and the Peake will be paid to Kidman and retained in the company for the benefit of AOB, effectively reducing the “net price” being paid by AOB for the remaining Kidman portfolio to approximately $365M.

Hancock Prospecting chairwoman Gina Rinehart said she was pleased to have the opportunity to invest further in Australia’s cattle holdings through the acquisition of the Kidman stations and was looking forward to working with the Kidman management and staff to grow and develop the operations.

“Kidman is an iconic cattle business established more than a century ago by Sir Sidney Kidman. It is an operation founded on hard work and perseverance by an outstanding Australian, and is an important part of Australia’s pioneering and entrepreneurial history,” Mrs Rinehart said.

Hancock CEO Garry Korte said the quality of the Kidman herd and channel country properties complemented Hancock’s existing northern cattle properties, and aligned well with Mrs Rinehart’s plans to build a diversified cattle holding in Australia, taking advantage of integration opportunities.”

The Hancock family started their first cattle station in North West Australia, and founded the first port in the area at Cossack on the West Pilbara Coast to enable the cattle trade.

Since then Mrs Rinehart has extensively grown the Hancock portfolio of cattle stations including legendary Kimberley Station Fossil Downs, a 400,000ha property in Western Australia.

Shanghai CRED principal Gui Guojie said that partnering with leading local business Hancock had already proved to be a productive approach and that he looked forward to having the opportunity to work with Hancock through the Kidman investment.

More than 600 interested parties have held discussions with sale manager Ernst & Young since the iconic Kidman landholding went on sale almost 18 months ago.

S. Kidman & Co Ltd is one of Australia’s largest beef producers, with an average herd carrying capacity of 185,000 cattle. The company has pastoral leases covering 101,000sqkm across South Australia, Western Australia, Northern Territory, and Queensland.
results.standFirst: MINING magnate Gina Rinehart and Chinese Real Estate company Shanghai Cred have entered into a bid implementation agreement to make a takeover offer for the nations largest private land hold S Kidman and Co.
